HEADLINE: Winning the Peace in Afghanistan 

 BODY:
Congress has handed the Bush administration a chance to live up to its noble rhetoric about rebuilding Afghanistan. Last week legislators authorized the spending of more than $3 billion over the next four years on reconstruction and expanded peacekeeping for that war-ravaged country, far more than the White House has previously sought. Mr. Bush should call on the new Congress to appropriate these urgently needed funds without delay when it convenes in January. 
 Afghanistan requires substantial outside help to avoid returning to the lawlessness that opened the door to the Taliban a decade ago. The same conditions made it possible for Osama bin Laden to use the country as a headquarters and training ground for international terrorism. 
 Much of Afghanistan's infrastructure is in ruins, its people are without constructive employment and its new central government barely rules beyond Kabul's city limits. A generation of Afghan men has known little but incessant warfare since Soviet troops invaded the country in 1979. Afghanistan's women were long shut out of education and employment. 
Those who survived and the millions of refugees now returning need help re-establishing their lives and moving back to the land. Agriculture remains the base of Afghanistan's economy and its most promising source of new jobs. Decades of war ruined irrigation projects, scattered seed stocks and destroyed the roads needed to transport agricultural goods to market. The central government also needs help paying the salaries of civil servants and establishing its authority throughout the country. Schools must be rebuilt and children inoculated against polio and other diseases. Other countries are willing to help, but America must lead the way.
The new legislation authorizes $425 million a year for such recovery projects and sets up an enterprise fund that could provide a total of $300 million in seed money to start and sustain new businesses. It also provides authority for spending on security needs, including $1 billion that the administration should use to expand peacekeeping forces beyond Kabul. President Bush has vowed not to repeat the mistake of the late 1980's when America abandoned Afghanistan after the Soviet military withdrawal. By using the new spending authority Congress has handed him, Mr. Bush can keep that promise.

HEADLINE: U.S. Officials Will Try to Help Tame Afghanistan Border Trade 

BYLINE:  By CARLOTTA GALL 

DATELINE: LAHORE, Pakistan, Nov. 20 

 BODY:
A Treasury official said today that in an effort to help Afghanistan gain control of customs revenues, the department would be sending customs officials to assess the chaotic and largely unregulated system at the country's main border crossings. 
 The decision came in response to a request that President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan and his finance minister, Ashraf Ghani Ahmedzai, made of Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill on Monday in Afghanistan, the official said. 
 Mr. O'Neill, continuing his trip in the region, met with officials today in Pakistan, which as Afghanistan's main trading partner will feel the effects of any changes at the border. The customs officials could be out examining border crossings and depots before the end of the year. 
Security arrangements have yet to be worked out, but Treasury officials mentioned a plan to establish an American presence in Afghanistan's main regional cities, staffing outposts with consular, development and security officials. The western city of Herat and the southern city of Kandahar, both of which have heavy customs traffic, were cited as likely locations for such outposts. 
The officials will focus on volume of trade at important border crossings, watching for bottlenecks and other problems that may be delaying the movement of goods. The plan is part of a broader strategy to help Afghanistan and other countries in the region -- particularly Pakistan -- bolster their economies by improving trade. It was a theme Mr. O'Neill touched upon several times here today, notably in a speech at the Lahore University of Management Sciences. "I hope for a day when Pakistan and its closest neighbors, Afghanistan and India, will enjoy more fully the benefits of open regional trade," he told students. 
Later he said, "The more people can work with each other, visit each other's places, create jobs in each other's homelands, the more we can reduce the threat of misunderstandings and wars." 
The Afghan government has also requested a World Bank assessment of trade potential in Afghanistan and the region as a whole, Mr. O'Neill said. He added that the World Bank and customs studies would most likely proceed in tandem. 
Afghanistan has for centuries been a famous through-route for trade, which goods traveling overland along the silk road and Afghans have always been successful traders and merchants. Trade has surged again since the defeat of the Taliban, with imports pouring in, from all directions, the bulk arriving via Iran to the west and Pakistan to the east. There have also been some imports from Central Asia, Russia and China. But American customs officials assessing border crossings will find a completely unregulated system, much of it controlled by regional warlords who bypass the central government. 
As Mr. O'Neill put it during an interview between meetings today, "In this part of the world there is a combination of formal trade barriers and informal passage collections, and half of them occur simultaneously." 
He added: "The finance minister told me it costs $200 for a truck to go from Pakistan to Kabul. And that is not collected by the government, but by patrols under the bridge." 
He described the injury caused by this system as twofold: Not only is the government missing out on its revenue, but the levy itself damages commerce and hurts the consumer.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
UBS Closes Trading Floor That It Acquired From Enron
Less than a year after acquiring Enron's energy trading operation, UBS Warburg said that it would reduce the size of the unit and shut down the trading floor in Houston. The operation, which had about 630 employees when UBS acquired it, is expected to be reduced to fewer than 100 employees, all of whom will be moved to Stamford, Conn.
 The decision comes during a sharp downturn in the energy trading business and after some large trading companies have announced plans to scale back their operations or exit the business. Page C4. 

Making a BMW a Conversation Piece
Christopher E. Bangle, BMW's first non-German design chief, wants each BMW to be a conversation piece known as much for design as precision engineering. He is trying to make the yuppie dream car as idiosyncratic as it once was predictable. And a lot of longtime BMW lovers hate him for it. A1.

Europe Halts Review of Pfizer Deal
European antitrust regulators have suspended their review of Pfizer's proposed $60 billion acquisition of Pharmacia, possibly delaying completion of the deal until early next year. C4.

Vivendi Expected to Sell Part of Unit
The French utility Electricite de France is expected to buy part of Vivendi Environnement, Vivendi Universal's water and waste management group. World Business, Section W.

The Italian oil giant Eni has agreed to buy oil and gas properties in Norway and the North Sea from the Finnish energy company Fortum. World Business, Section W.

BMG Tries to Simplify CD Royalties
BMG announced an overhaul of its royalty accounting practices that the music label said would assuage concerns that performers were being shortchanged on their earnings. C10.

Housing Starts Fall in October
Housing starts fell 11.4 percent in October, the largest monthly drop since January 1994. Economists cited heavy rain in October as a potential factor for the slide. C10.

The Nasdaq increased 44.84 points, to 1,419.35. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 148.23 points, to 8,623.01. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 17.41 points, to 914.15. C11.

Qwest Offers to Exchange Debt
Qwest Communications offered to exchange new debt for $12.9 billion of bonds as part of its effort to reorganize its balance sheet and avoid bankruptcy. The news sent Qwest's stock sharply higher. Bondholders who participate in the exchange would receive a higher interest rate and stronger security in exchange for reduced face value on the debt. C6.

Sites Remove Information on Sales
Several online shopping sites have removed information about post-Thanksgiving sales after retailers threatened legal action. C6.

Trying to Lure Younger Coffee Crowd
Mr. Coffee is the market leader in coffee makers, but more expensive models like Braun and Krups have been nipping at its heels. So Sunbeam is trying to ensure that Mr. Coffee maintains its lead by attracting a younger coffee drinker. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C10.

Fed Takes the Optimistic View
The Federal Reserve gave the economy a lift by cutting interest rates, and it pointed out that it expected the economy to accelerate. But business leaders do not share the Fed's optimism. Hal R. Varian: Economic Scene. C2.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene; 
When it comes to crystal-ball gazing, the Fed trounces the private sector.

BYLINE:  By Hal R. Varian; Hal R. Varian is an economics professor and dean of the School of Information Management and Systems at the University of California at Berkeley. E-mail:hal@sims.berkeley.edu.

 BODY:
THE Fed gave the economy a flu shot earlier this month by cutting interest rates half a point. But it was quick to point out that, as with a real flu shot, this was intended only as a preventive measure.
 "The economy's most likely projection is to come out of this soft spot and to start accelerating," the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, told Congress. 
 Other Fed officials are also positive about the economy. Gary H. Stern, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis, said, "There is no question that an economic expansion, an economic recovery, is under way." And Roger W. Ferguson Jr., the Fed's vice chairman, said, "The pieces are in place to engender a gradual strengthening in economic activity." 
Unfortunately, business leaders do not share the Fed's optimism.
According to a report by the Business Roundtable, 60 percent of executives surveyed said they planned to eliminate jobs next year, while only 11 percent thought they would add jobs. Similarly, 19 percent expect to increase their investment next year, while 24 percent expect to reduce it.
Whom should we believe: the Fed or the executives? After all, the executives are actually making economic decisions, while the Fed is only trying to forecast what they will do. What do those guys in Washington know, anyway?
Plenty, it turns out.
For evidence, turn to "Federal Reserve Information and the Behavior of Interest Rates," a paper in the American Economic Review in June 2000 by Christina and David Romer, two economists at the University of California at Berkeley. 
The Romers ask whether the Fed has an advantage in predicting economic variables and, if so, what the source of that advantage is. The answer to the first question is a resounding yes. The answer to the second is a bit more tentative: the Fed is better at forecasting than the private sector, but we're not sure why.
The Romers look at two variables: inflation and output growth. Both attract intense interest in Washington and on Wall Street.
Forecasts for both variables are prepared by the Fed staff before each meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, which uses these forecasts to help set economic policy. The forecasts are closely guarded secrets and are released to the public only after five years.
How good are the Fed's forecasts? To answer this question, the Romers compare the forecasts from 1965 to 1991 with those of several private forecasting services.
The Romers first look at how well private forecasts have predicted inflation, then ask whether the forecasters could have improved their performance if they had been given access to the Fed forecasts. The researchers find that the Fed forecasts offer big improvements over the private ones. In fact, if you had access to both forecasts, a good rule of thumb would be to rely exclusively on the Fed and ignore the private predictions.
Why are the Fed's forecasts so much better? There are several possible explanations. First, the Fed may have inside information about the course of monetary policy since setting that policy is one of its most important jobs.
The problem with this explanation is that monetary policy has little effect on the economy in the short run -- it takes three to four quarters to show up in aggregate statistics. Yet the Fed's forecasts are better than the private sector's even for very short-term forecasts.
Perhaps the Fed gets official data earlier than the private sector? This is also an unconvincing explanation, as the Fed chairman gets access to current economic data just the night before it is released to the public.
The most likely explanation for the Fed's superiority in forecasting inflation, the Romers say, is that the Fed devotes "far more resources to forecasting than even the largest commercial forecasters."
It's not that it has better information about the state of the economy, or secret forecasting methods -- it simply looks at a lot more information, has a lot more staff and has a lot more experience. So it is not too surprising that the Fed does better.
These days the big economic uncertainty is not so much about inflation (or deflation) but about output. Everyone wants to know when the economy will resume robust growth. Does the Fed's forecasting superiority extend to G.D.P. growth?
The answer is yes: the researchers find that the Fed is also substantially better at predicting output growth than the private sector. But the Fed's advantage in this case is not so large as with predicting inflation. In the case of output growth, the optimal forecast would combine both the private and the Fed forecasts, though it would give more weight to the Fed's forecast.
In the case of output forecasting, the Romers suggest that the Fed's advantage may in fact be, at least in part, a result of better access to data since the Fed manages the collection of information used to compute the index of industrial production.
Note that the Berkeley economists' study is mostly pre-Greenspan; Mr. Greenspan joined the Fed in August 1987, while the Romers' data ends in 1991. Mr. Greenspan is well known for reading a variety of economic tea leaves, but most of the data he uses appears to come from reports available to the private sector. His forecasting success seems to come not from special ingredients, but from a finely tuned sense of how ordinary ingredients should be combined.
As he indicated last week, the economy is in a soft spot. Consumers have grown more cautious, and businesses have not yet resumed robust investment spending. The Fed's worry now is that excessive pessimism on the part of executives will dampen, or even stall, the current recovery.
This was probably part of the reasoning that led the Fed to make the unusually large cut in interest rates last week. The cost of borrowing is now at a historic low, which should encourage even the most pessimistic executives to think about investing.
Let's hope the rate cut works, for the sake of the economy -- and the Fed's forecasting record.

HEADLINE: Its Eyes Fixed on Terrorism, Congress Put Off Many Bills 

BYLINE:  By CARL HULSE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 

 BODY:
The 107th Congress will conclude a tumultuous two years on Friday when a few House members gather to give quick final approval to legislation creating the Department of Homeland Security. That measure, born out of the Sept. 11 attacks, illustrates how the terrorist assaults defined the Congress and diverted lawmakers from domestic issues to national security and foreign affairs.
 With its attention fixed on terrorism and the midterm elections, Congress was never able to resolve its differences on prescription drug coverage for older Americans, overhauling welfare, energy policy or even the routine spending bills that finance government operations. Those issues have been pushed over to the Congress that will convene next year under full Republican control. 
 "A lot of what we will do in the first part of next year is finish up work undone," Senator Trent Lott, Republican of Mississippi, the incoming majority leader, said today as he waved a facsimile report card giving the Democratic-led Senate a failing end-of-the-session grade. 
Despite the focus on what was not done, lawmakers approved President Bush's tax cuts, tightened corporate oversight, passed a sweeping antiterrorism law, authorized President Bush to act against Iraq, overhauled the campaign finance system, passed a trade bill and agreed on the new antiterrorism agency. A bipartisan House-Senate inquiry also produced evidence of intelligence lapses preceding the Sept. 11 attacks.
Those ends were achieved against a background of partisanship that grew out of a presidential election that was thrown into the courts, as well as the sudden shift of power to Democrats in the Senate in May 2001 caused by Senator James M. Jeffords' decision to leave the Republican Party. Then came the Sept. 11 assaults, followed weeks later by an anthrax attack on Capitol Hill.
"A lot of turmoil, a lot of disruptions," said Senator John B. Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana. "It has been a very emotional two years and yet some good things were done."
Others were less charitable. Senator Jon Kyl, Republican of Arizona, said that besides the tax cuts and supporting the president in the effort against terrorism, "I am hard pressed to express a great deal of pride in anything else we did."
Assessing the Congress today as the Senate was gaveled into adjournment by 99-year-old Senator Strom Thurmond, the retiring South Carolina Republican, lawmakers in each party credited the House and Senate, in concert with the White House, for the response to the terrorist attacks. Yet Republicans and Democrats expressed frustration over their legislative failures and blamed the opposition for obstructionism.
"I believe the Democrats decided not to allow certain issues to pass," said Senator Jeff Sessions, Republican of Alabama, who said the intent was to deny Republicans successes. But Mr. Sessions said the plan backfired, as demonstrated by the election results that put Republicans in charge of the House, Senate and the White House come January.
Senator Tom Daschle, the Democratic leader who has been the target of Republican criticism for his management of the Senate, said Republicans were responsible for the gridlock of the last months of the session, before a flurry of bills was adopted in the post-election session.
He said Republicans made a "calculated political decision" to hold up the approval of the domestic security measure and other initiatives to bolster their chances in this month's elections. "The same compromises and agreements that we were seeking before the election, we got after the election," said Mr. Daschle, who said he hoped the spirit of working together extended into 2003. 
Some Democrats say they are bracing for a "rough and tumble" Congress next year should Republicans try to use their new muscle.
"The next Congress could end up being very unproductive," said Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut.
But Republicans say they intend to try to work with Democrats, though they may have no choice but to do so given the still narrow margins in the House and Senate.
"Our attitude is we will continue to reach out to people, we will try to bring people in," said Nicholas E. Calio, the top White House lobbyist on Capitol Hill, who said President Bush believes that voters want accomplishment, not argument.
Mr. Calio said that from a historical perspective the White House considered this an "extraordinarily productive session." He said most new presidents in their first engagement with Congress get "one or none of their major issues through." But he ticked off the budget that laid the ground work for the tax cuts, education changes, the legislative response to Sept. 11, new trade promotion authority and the Iraq resolution. 
He and others said Republicans would start the new year concentrating on an economic growth package, drug coverage for older Americans and the stalled spending measures.
Relations were strained between Republicans and Democrats from the start given the protracted fight over the election.
President Bush met with Democrats in early February and promised to reach across the aisle, but Democrats said his bipartisan overtures clashed with the way he pushed through his $1.3 trillion tax cut on a near party line vote in the House. He did attract some Democratic backing in the Senate. And he worked with Democrats on an education measure that promised more money for schools while instituting new testing, though critics say the administration still has not fully financed the bill. 
The political terrain shifted drastically when Senator Jeffords, a moderate from Vermont, announced that he would become an independent and vote with Democrats, abruptly throwing Republicans out of their chairmanships and giving Democrats a critical power base. That decision left the Senate as the focal point in Congress while House Republicans, enforcing strict party discipline, were able to move ahead on issues like prescription drug coverage and energy policy.
The attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon temporarily closed the partisan divide and lawmakers quickly provided the president money and authority to act against the terrorists, giving law enforcement broad new investigatory powers. Democrats did fight successfully to reduce the president's ability to employ military force and limit some of the new police powers. But most members of Congress thought the immediate post-Sept. 11 period was a model of cooperation.
With elections that would determine Congressional control looming, reaching agreements became much more difficult in 2002. Weeks of Senate time were devoted to a fruitless search for a prescription drug compromise. Negotiators were unable to devise an energy program, which before Sept. 11 was a top White House priority, as the Senate adamantly opposed opening the Arctic refuge to oil drilling. 
The Senate failed to adopt a budget and the appropriations process collapsed in differences over spending. Revelations of corporate wrongdoing did spur a substantial change in laws governing the accounting and securities industries.
Then President Bush in June reversed himself and came out for a sweeping reorganization of federal agencies into the new Homeland Security Department. As progress faltered, Democrats accused Republicans of trying to turn the legislation into a campaign weapon by proposing changes in rules governing federal workers; Republicans accused the Democrats of trying to thwart the president on domestic security. 
The lame-duck session ended on another stalemate when the House and Senate were unable to agree on an extension of unemployment benefits, which will run out on Dec. 28.

EMERGENCY SPENDING -- December 2001Provides $40 billion in emergency spending, earmarking $17.2 billion for defense, $11.1 billion to help recovery in New York and $9.9 billion for domestic security. BIOTERRORISM -- May 2002Expands government stockpiles of antibiotics and vaccines and tightens federal regulation of laboratories handling deadly microbes. ARMED PILOTS -- September 2002Authorizes commercial airline pilots to carry guns in their cockpits. SEPT. 11 COMMISSION -- November 2002Establishes an independent commission with broad subpoena powers to investigate why the Sept. 11 attacks were not foiled. The 10-member panel will report after 18 months. HOMELAND SECURITY DEPARTMENT -- November 2002Creates a department that consolidates tasks now spread over 22 federal agencies and focuses on preventing terrorist attacks and responding to those that occur. TERRORISM INSURANCE -- November 2002Establishes a three-year federal program to cover the losses of insurance companies as result of future terrorist attacks. The government would pay 90 percent of the cost of a terrorist attack after losses are greater than $10 billion, rising to $15 billion in the third year. OTHER LEGISLATION Passed TAX CUT -- June 2001Lowers taxes by $1.3 trillion over 10 years by cutting tax rates, doubling the child credit, reducing the estate tax and providing relief to married couples. EDUCATION -- December 2001Increases federal aid to schools with large numbers of poor children and requires annual testing in reading and math. CAMPAIGN FINANCE -- March 2002Bans large unlimited donations to political parties known as soft money and imposes new rules on advertising by outside groups. Increases the limit on how much an individual can give to federal candidates to $2,000 from $1,000. FARMS -- May 2002Approves $180 billion over 10 years including a $40 billion increase in grain and cotton subsidies and an 80 percent rise for environmental and conservation efforts. CORPORATE ACCOUNTABILITY -- July 2002Overhauls the nations accounting, securities and corporate-fraud laws. Creates a board to oversee and discipline auditors, establishes new ground rules for prosecuting executive wrongdoing and expands civil-court protections for defrauded investors and corporate whistle-blowers. TRADE -- August 2002Allows President Bush to negotiate trade agreements that Congress cannot amend. ELECTION LAW REFORM -- October 2002Authorizes $3.9 billion over three years to help states buy new equipment, train poll workers and establish statewide lists of registered voters. IRAQ -- October 2002Authorizes President Bush to use armed forces "as he determines to be necessary and appropriate" to defend the nation against "the continuing threat posed by Iraq" and to enforce "all relevant" United Nations Security Council resolutions on Iraq. WELFARE -- November 2002Extended landmark welfare law until March 31, 2003. Not Passed BANKRUPTCY -- A bill intended to make it harder for people to escape debts by filing for bankruptcy. RELIGIOUS CHARITIES -- An initiative to put religious groups on equal footing with other charities for federal funding. PATIENTS RIGHTS -- A bill to establish a wide range of patients' rights. MEDICARE DRUG COVERAGE -- A bill to provide prescription drug benefits to the elderly. ENERGY -- A wide-ranging proposal calling for greater domestic fuel production and new conservation measures. APPROPRIATIONS -- 11 of 13 appropriations bills.

 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk; Pg. 34

LENGTH: 4585 words

HEADLINE: ART GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

Museums

"A LEGACY IN LANDSCAPES," New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue at 42nd Street, (212) 869-8089 (through Jan. 4). More than 100 additions to the library's voluminous print collection by nearly 60 artists, from Fragonard and Pissarro to present-day practitioners like Alex Katz, Roxy Paine and Terry Winters are on display. Mostly traditional printmaking methods are used and the choices are fairly conservative at the contemporary end. So Sylvia Plimack Mangold's drypoint and etching "Maple Tree" (1998), for instance, a close-up rendering of intersecting bare-tree branches, keeps good company with William Delamotte's etching of almost 200 years earlier, "Beech in Windsor Forest." (1805-6), a stagey old monster whose thick, knotty ramifications are examined in minute detail. But the continuity is pleasurable. All in all, the library has chosen well. Hours: Tuesdays and Wednesdays, 11 a.m. to 7:30 p.m.; Thursdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Free (Grace Glueck).

* "THE ADVENTURES OF HAMZA," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, 718 638-5000 (through Jan. 26). If Great Books were judged great by size and illustrations alone, the "Hamzanama," or "Story of Hamza," made for the Mughal emperor Akbar in 16th-century India would be one of the greatest of all. It was originally more the 1,200 pages long. Each page was two feet tall. The paintings, which tell of the encounters of the mythical warrior-prince named Hamza with demons, dragons and giants, are fantastic. The book exists only as fragments now, but about 200 of the finest surviving pages have been brought together from around the world for this exhibition. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. (until 11 p.m. the first Saturday of each month). Admission: $6; $3, students and 62+ (Holland Cotter).

"AN AMERICAN LEGACY, A GIFT TO NEW YORK," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3600 (through Jan. 26). The Whitney trustees pooled their pennies, acquired $200 million worth of postwar American art and gave it all to the museum as a gift. The 87 works, dating from the 1940's through the 1990's, enhance and subtly reshape the museum's account of American modernism. And they are all temporarily on view in this showcase, which ranges from classic Abstract Expressionist painting (Kline, Pollock, Still) to early Pop (pre-silkscreen Warhol), with lots and lots of Jasper Johns. Most of of the choices are predictably canonical; the show perks up with odd-duck contributions by Jay DeFeo and Lucas Samaras. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays, Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 1 to 9 p.m. Admission: $10; $8, students and 62+ (Cotter).

* "DRAWING NOW: EIGHT PROPOSITIONS," Museum of Modern Art, Queens, 45-20 33rd Street, at Queens Boulevard, Long Island City, (212) 708-9400 (through Jan. 6). This generous sampling of work by 26 young artists provides a sweeping, even opulent view of drawing at the threshold of the 21st century. The variety of techniques and materials, the mix of large-scale feats of draftsmanship with clusters of framed works, the breadth of sources (from American quilt patterns to Japanese anime to 19th-century illustration) and the range of narrative ambition create an exhilarating sense of possibility. Some of the artists illustrate rather than fully embody the curators' categories, and there is an excess of fashionable, even overexposed artists from a handful of hot galleries. Nonetheless, "Drawing Now" is required viewing for anyone remotely interested in today's art. It sets a standard for future shows of its kind. Hours: Thursdays through Mondays from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m; until 7:45 p.m. on Fridays. Admission: $12; $8.50, students and 65+ (Roberta Smith).

* "CARROLL DUNHAM: PAINTINGS," New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway, near Houston Street, SoHo, (212) 219-1222 (through Feb. 2). Also, "Carroll Dunham: Drawings, 1985-2002," Nolan/Eckman, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, SoHo, (212) 925-6190 (through Dec. 20). Two midcareer surveys of Mr. Dunham trace his arc across two decades from psychedelic abstraction toward a figuration of escalated nuttiness and technical panache. He is squarely at the heart of the modern cartoon aesthetic; its pathos may turn out to be the signature of our age. In his case, abject subject matter and woolly psychodrama are tempered by low-key amiability. When his works fail, they fail in the direction of too-easy decoration and cheerful psychedelia. Otherwise, they succeed on the bases of sly humor, self-mockery and a kind of sneaky, unpretentious charm. There is no preaching or political doctrine. His paintings emerge from the act of painting; they are Process Art of a peculiar kind and they deliver us into a funny-sad realm, conjured up to purge a few ghosts, maybe, and to provide us with pleasure. That, and the sense of wit to recognize our essential folly, is plenty. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; Thursdays, to 8 p.m. Admission: $6; $3, students, artists and 65+ (Michael Kimmelman).

"GREAT MASTERS OF MEXICAN FOLK ART FROM THE COLLECTION OF FOMENTO CULTURAL BANAMEX," National Museum of the American Indian, at the United States Custom House (Smithsonian Institution), 1 Bowling Green, Lower Manhattan, (212) 514-3700 (through March 15). This big, lavish crowd-pleaser offers a colorful and entertaining selection of more than 500 works by 181 contemporary Mexican artisans, and it includes sculpture, furniture, ceramics, weavings, toys, religious objects, glassware, beadwork, leatherwork and much more. Fine craft predominates, but there are works of compelling imagination, too, like the wonderfully animated wooden fantasy animals of Manuel Jimenez Ramirez; the magical, intensely patterned ceramic assemblages of Alfonso Castillo Orta; and the crowded miniature bullfight scene carved from a log by Hipolito Vazquez Sanchez. Hours: Daily, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays until 8 p.m. Free (Ken Johnson).

* "KAZARI: DECORATION AND DISPLAY IN JAPAN: 15TH-19TH CENTURY," Japan Society, 333 East 47th Street, (212) 832-1155 (through Dec. 31). The hard-to-grasp term kazari refers to the decorative arrangement of objects. And it is demonstrated with enchanting results in a show that demolishes the cliche of Japanese art as inherently minimalist. Here everything is layered: something is always in front of or behind or above something else, and each something has its own painted, incised or embroidered intricacies. This results in a total environment of conspicuous but elusive richness, encompassing painted screens, samurai jackets and Kabuki costumes that sag under acres of padded silk and gilded thread. It's maximalism all the way. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $5; $3, students and 65+ (Cotter).

* "THE LEGACY OF GENGHIS KHAN: COURTLY ART AND CULTURE IN WESTERN ASIA, 1256-1353," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Feb. 16). You may arrive expecting a little more razzle-dazzle from an exhibition that is supposedly about a bloodthirsty conqueror, but Genghis Khan doesn't actually have much to do with this. The show is really about his heirs, including Kublai Khan, the founder of the Yuan dynasty in China, and Hulagu, who subdued Baghdad and established the rule of the Ilkhanids. The interchange between China and Iran under Mongol rule is the show's leitmotif. There are textiles, works of gold and silver and illuminated books, which are astonishing. (There are 21 illustrated pages from the Great Mongol Shahnama, one of the masterworks of Islamic art.) Hours: Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 9 p.m. Admission: $12; $7, students and 65+ (Kimmelman).

"PAINTED SAWS: JACOB KASS," American Folk Art Museum's Eva and Morris Feld Gallery, 2 Lincoln Square, Columbus Avenue near 66th Street, (212) 595-9533 (through Dec. 1). After six decades as a decorative painter of commercial trucks in Brooklyn, Kass (1910-2000) retired to Vermont and began painting landscapes on old handsaws and other tools. Thus he transformed himself into a modern folk artist. Most compelling is the way the tapered saw blade becomes a trapezoidal window through which to view bucolic landscapes painted with a sensuous, skillful but not too fussy touch. Crisscrossing perspectives in urban scenes creates compositions bordering on Cubism. Avoiding gimmickry and excessive sentimentality, Kass produced objects of forthright charm. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 7:30 p.m.; Mondays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Free (Johnson).

"DAGOBERT PECHE AND THE WEINER WERKSTATTE," Neue Galerie, 1048 Fifth Avenue, at 86th Street, (212) 628-6200 (through Feb. 10). This survey of the Austrian designer Dagobert Peche (pronounced DAH-go-bert PEH-kuh) is a case study in the use of material objects to effect cultural reform. And the installation is as lively as any design show New York has seen. Peche, who died in 1923 at age 36, represented the second generation of the Wiener Werkstatte, whose designers regarded decorative objects as ideological vessels. But his highly ornate work is in full contrast to the spartan aesthetic associated with the movement. With more than 400 drawings and objects on view, the show is a tumble of stylized flora and offers an equal range of materials: fabric, wallpaper, precious metals, ceramics, wood and glass. How did Peche get away with it? Though Baroque in sensibility, his work was not historicist. It was a light, individual interpretation of a massive court style. Like Philippe Starck and Ettore Sottsass today, Peche designed rooms of inner nature, enclosures for emotion. Hours: Fridays, 11 a.m. to 9 p.m.; Saturdays, Sundays and Mondays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $10; $7, students and 65+ (Herbert Muschamp).

* "POUSSIN, CLAUDE AND THEIR WORLD: 17TH-CENTURY FRENCH DRAWINGS FROM THE ECOLE DES BEAUX-ARTS, PARIS," Frick Collection, 1 East 70th Street, (212) 288-0700 (through Dec. 1). The Ecole des Beaux-Arts, the world's oldest surviving art school (founded in 1648), assembled an enormous collection of works to instruct its students in the discipline of drawing. Those from the 17th century, the great age of Nicolas Poussin and Claude Lorrain, are especially outstanding. The 71 here survey French drawing from 1620 to 1680, when classicism came to French art, aiming to restore High Renaissance ideals of clarity, order and balance, with the Italian painter Raphael as a revered model. The emphasis is on the works of Poussin (1594-1665) and Claude (1604-1682), a history painter and a landscapist. But lesser-known masters like Simon Vouet, Eustache Le Sueur and Charles Le Brun are also included. Wicked doings in the Bible, sex in mythology, the ordered schematics of French architecture and the pomp and circumstance of the French court are some of the subjects covered in the drawings, which should send any aficionado to the Frick on the run. Hours and admissions: Tuesdays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 9 p.m.; Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 6 p.m. Admission: $12; $5, students; $8, 62+ (Glueck).

* "BILL VIOLA: GOING FORTH BY DAY," Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500 (through Jan. 12). An ambitious meditation on the epic themes of human existence, this frescolike video installation consists of five panels, shot using the latest technology and projected simultaneously on the walls of one huge gallery. Each deals with a specific theme: rebirth, journey through life, disaster, death and resurrection. Except for a few scenes, the action is almost in slow motion, suggesting the stasis of looking at paintings and allowing the viewer to shift attention from panel to panel without losing focus. The work was mostly shot before the Sept. 11 disaster but is amazingly prophetic of it. If some of the imagery is corny, it is still a deeply felt and provocative piece of work. Hours: Saturdays through Wednesdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m. Admission: $12; $9, students and 65+ (Glueck).

Galleries: Uptown

* "ART OF THE SAMURAI," Scholten Japanese Art, 63 East 66th Street, (212) 585-0475 (through Dec. 6). Militaristic samurai culture produced some of the wildest looking armor ever made. You'll get a full sense of its extraterrestrial oddity and delicacy in this show, where complete suits of armor are supplemented by displays of helmets, swords and woodblock prints. It's a dynamite show (Cotter).

* "MADE IN CHICAGO: CIRCA 1970," Adam Baumgold, 74 East 79th Street, (212) 861-7338 (through Nov. 30). This engrossing selection of works by Chicago Imagists includes beautiful paintings of anxious encounters between weirdly deformed men and women by Jim Nutt; a numinously nostalgic farmscape by Roger Brown; antic watercolors of striving tubular people by Gladys Nilsson; a mysterious, fetishistic painting by Christina Ramberg; and H. C. Westermann's first "Death Ship" (Johnson).

Galleries: 57th Street

LOUISE BOURGEOIS, Susan Sheehan, 20 West 57th Street, (212) 489-3331 (through Nov. 30). Sketchy prints from the 1990's by this eminent sculptor afford fleeting glimpses of a mysteriously elusive mind. A suite of drypoints is devoted to spiders, who symbolize the artist's mother; one comical howling arachnid is shown giving birth. "Anatomy," a 12-piece portfolio, includes a torso with multiple pneumatic breasts; a picture of sultry, slightly crossed eyes; and a naked woman hanging by her long hair from a laundry line (Johnson).

"JAMES BROOKS: FIVE DECADES," Joan T. Washburn, 20 West 57th Street, (212) 397-6780 (through Nov. 30). Brooks (1906-92) came to Abstract Expressionism after a period of Cubist-influenced figurative painting. Quieter and gentler in style than most of his colleagues, he experimented with "accidents" of pigment splotches more to enlarge his painter's vocabulary than to reveal his psyche. The most interesting painting here is "Evine" (1982), a beautifully balanced, majestic canvas with adventurous color harmonies, which shows what a good painter Brooks was at his best (Glueck).

WILLIAM CLUTZ, Katharina Rich Perlow, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 644-7171 (through Dec. 7). Since the late 1950's, Mr. Clutz has been painting the street life of New York, simplifying its complexity to the brink of abstraction. The canvases in this five-decade survey call to mind Edward Hopper's romantic nostalgia and Alex Katz's suave modernity (Johnson).

Galleries: Chelsea

JORDAN CRANDALL, "Trigger," Henry Urbach Architecture, 526 West 26th Street, (212) 627-0974 (through Dec. 1). Projected on opposite walls, this 18-minute video montage features two naked muscular men, one black, the other white, stalking each other with rifles in a shadowy, theatrical setting suggestive of a war-torn city. Part soft pornography, part political allegory and part Modernist play with media, it is a heavy-handed sermon about masculinity, sex, surveillance and violence (Johnson).

JERALD IEANS, Lucas Schoormans, 526 West 26th Street, (212) 243-3159 (through Dec. 14). This young, self-taught painter produces economical, well composed arrangements of biomorphic forms on medium-large canvases. With their overlapping, amoeboid shapes in shades of gray or muted pastels, finely combed textures and sharp edges, Mr. Iean's paintings have great decorative appeal. Slyly sophisticated updates of Miro-style Surrealism, they are formally restrained yet funky (Johnson).

* BRUCE NAUMAN, Van de Wegh Fine Art, 521 West 23rd Street, (212) 929-6633 (through Dec. 14). This three-decade survey administers a substantial dose of Bruce Nauman's cerebrally punishing visual poetry. Neon signs feature flat-footed word play; one, for example, blinks "war" one way and "raw" the other. Most repellant are sculptures made from the animal forms used by taxidermists: a mobile has dangling cast-aluminum dogs with legs cut off and re-attached in reverse (Johnson).

LISA ZWERLING, First Street Gallery, 526 West 26th Street, (646) 336-8053 (through Dec. 7). Ms. Zwerling paints romantic fantasies of harmony among humans, animals and nature in a delicately naturalistic style. The main attraction here is a rocky landscape in which a naked child armed with a violin casts a musical spell over such savage beasts as a bear, a lion and a pair of wolves (Johnson).

Galleries: SoHo

ENID BAXTER BLADER, "Letter From the Girl, Mailed at the Gas Station," Location One, 26 Greene Street, (212) 334-3347 (through Dec. 28). Cerebral film buffs might find in Ms. Blader's 18-minute video projection all kinds of inside references and jokes about film noir, B movies and other sorts of low-end cinematic Pop. A puzzling montage of scenes set in a rural wasteland features a woman in a trench coat on the run, a mysteriously menacing 1980's-style bar girl and an overweight bleached blonde looking for someone who remains unspecified. Instead of plot, there's a curious blend of suspense and tedium (Johnson).

"DAN KEPLINGER, A K A KING GIMP," Phyllis Kind, 136 Greene Street, (212) 925-1200 (through Dec. 7). The subject of the 2000 Oscar-winning documentary, "King Gimp," Mr. Keplinger has cerebral palsy, which keeps him in a wheelchair and requires him to paint using a brush attached to his head. Despite these obstacles he paints and draws with ambitious verve, creating aggressively expressionistic self-portraits in acrid, muddy colors. This is the 29-year-old artist's second New York solo, and it shows a heartening determination (Johnson).

PAUL NOBLE AND GIOVANNI BATTISTA PIRANESI, Susan Inglett, 100 Wooster Street, (212) 343-0573 (through Dec. 14). Among the most impressive works in the Museum of Modern Art's "Drawing Now" exhibition are Mr. Noble's huge architectural fantasies. His two etchings on view here, though ordinary in scale, are similarly absorbing in their detail and narrative lunacy. They are well matched by four views of ancient ruins by Piranesi, the great 18th-century printmaker and architectural visionary (Johnson).

"ROSIE LEE TOMPKINS: AFRICAN-AMERICAN QUILTMAKER," Peter Blum, 99 Wooster Street, (212) 343-0441 (through Dec. 28). Ms. Tompkins's ravishing quilts connect to several traditions, including African bark cloth paintings, American textiles and, not least of all, modernist painting. But look, don't think. These pictorial powerhouses are like multifaceted jewels spread flat before the eye yet turning in the light, their sparkling shards of color and mutating geometries full of mystery and life (Smith).

Galleries: Downtown

"ALIVE AND KICKING: THE COLLAGES OF CHARLES HENRI FORD," the Scene, 42 Rivington Street, (212) 674-0508 (through Dec. 12). Ford, who died in September at 94, was an early version of today's global artist. Born in Mississippi, he moved back and forth among America, Europe and Asia, producing copious amounts of poetry, but also films, sculptures and, in the early 1990's, a series of small, Surrealist-tinged collages. He seems to have clipped material from design, nature and soft porn magazines, then pieced the visual data together with shrewd wit, binding the series with the motif of half-abstract figures resembling those found in early Dubuffet. Someday we'll get a retrospective; meanwhile, this show makes an important contribution (Cotter).

VIRGIL MARTI, Participant, 95 Rivington Street, (917) 488-0185 (through Dec. 22). Participant is Manhattan's newest nonprofit alternative space and for its inaugural show Mr. Marti, a Philadelphia artist, has covered the walls in sheets of reflective mylar, the kind used to raise plants (notably marijuana) in hydroponic gardens. Each sheet is imprinted with images of flowers and patterns of broken linear grids. Suspended from the ceiling are chandeliers made from colored resin casts of deer antlers, with blossoms at the tips. The results merge pop culture, weird science and the psychedelic wooziness of a funhouse mirror, disconcertingly crowned by trophies of a kill (Cotter).

CLAUDIA AND JULIA MULLER, Maccarone, 45 Canal Street, (212) 431-4977 (through Dec. 5). The New York solo debut of a Swiss-born sister team includes large scale collaborative drawings done from found objects (pizzeria menus, rock club posters) and photographs (Carnival revelers, children dressed as American Indians), and a projected video of drawings. The video image is of a nuclear family -- two adults, two children -- that continually alters in appearance. Figures fade in and out, changing sex and race so that various combinations of heterosexual "differences" are played out in a gentle acknowledgment of a social and genetic revolution that is, in fact, in progress (Cotter).

VINCE ROARK, ATM Gallery, 170 Avenue B, near 10th Street, (212) 375-0349 (through Nov. 24) Mr. Roark is in his 70's and lives in Kansas City, Mo., where he has been producing elaborate geometric drawings, along with related sculptural constructions, for some 40 years. His tools are simple: pencil, pen, colored markers, compass and protractor. But his ideas about dimensional exploration -- ones that jibe with utopian scientific theories of early modernists like Malevich and Kandinsky -- are complex, and the largest, densest, most labor-intensive of his drawings shimmers with a kind of exalted concentration (Cotter).

Other Galleries

* "THE AGES OF MANKIND: TIME TO HOPE," Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, at 112th Street, Morningside Heights, (212) 932-7347 (through Dec. 6; daily, 9:30 a.m. to noon and 1 to 5 p.m.). All but unheralded, this show seems to have dropped into New York like an unbidden gift, and what a gift: 100 superb examples of Spanish religious art, which is some of the most rapturous and wrenching religious art ever made, seen in a perfect setting. The works include Romanesque madonnas, Gothic crucifixions, paintings of saints by El Greco and Goya, and a handwritten letter by St. Teresa of Avila, all from churches, monasteries and museums in the Spanish provinces of Castile and Leon. The images, among them life-size polychrome sculptures, are sexy, gruesome and above all theatrical, projecting big, primary emotions. The effect is gloriously intense (Cotter).

* "BETWEEN WORD AND IMAGE: MODERN IRANIAN VISUAL CULTURE," Grey Art Gallery, New York University, 100 Washington Square East, Greenwich Village, (212) 998-6780 (through Dec. 7). This no-frills exhibition is about the dynamics of cultural borrowing, the inseparability of art and politics and the interplay of modernism and Islamicism. It begins with painting and sculptures from the 1960's in which Western styles and Iranian themes merge. It continues with riveting photographs documenting the arrival of the Iranian Revolution in 1979. And it ends with art that the revolution produced: political posters inspired by both the Western counterculture and militant Islamic ideology. Depending on the amount of reflective synthesis you're willing to do, the results can seem richly layered, or disjointed and undercooked. But the materials and the ideas on display are fascinating (Cotter).

ALEX GREY, Tibet House, 22 West 15th Street, Flatiron district, (212) 807-0563 (through Jan. 3). Mr. Grey's painting, with its tantric symbolism, medical-illustration finesse and New Age optimism, might be described as psychedelic realism. In it, the human figure is rendered with X-ray or CAT- scan transparency, the way Aldous Huxley saw a leaf when he was on mescalin. Mr. Grey's images have been appropriated by a countercultural audience: they have shown up on promotional posters for rave events and on paper used for blotter-style LSD. But they look right at home at Tibet House, where contemporary versions of religious tankas, meant for esoteric instruction and meditation, often hang (Cotter).

Last Chance

* PAUL FEELEY/PETER CAIN, Matthew Marks, 522 West 22nd Street, Chelsea, (212) 243-0200; PAUL FEELEY, Lawrence Markey, 42 East 76th Street, (212) 517-9892 (both through tomorrow). Linking Mr. Feeley, an associate of the Color Field painters of the 1960's, and Mr. Cain, who in the 1990's made paintings of surrealistically compacted cars, makes Matthew Marks's two-part exhibition a memorable exercise in contemporary taste-making. Feeley fans may see more canvases and works on paper at Lawrence Markey (Johnson).

* "JUMP," the Painting Center, 52 Greene Street, SoHo, (212) 343-1060 (through tomorrow). Organized by the painter Ross Neher, this selection of small to medium-size abstractions by 11 artists locates an underappreciated intersection of personalized formalism and sensuous process where many painters are working these days. Stephen Ellis's percussive grids, Ruth Root's funky Cubism, David Baggenstoss's shimmering veils, James Lecce's confectionery swirls and Carolanna Parlato's intensely colored pours contribute to an experience of immediate visual gratification (Johnson).

DOUG OHLSON: "20 YEARS OF PAINTING, 1982-2002," Times Square Art Gallery, Hunter College, 450 West 41st Street, (212) 772-4991 (through tomorrow). As a painter, Mr. Ohlson has never needed a subject other than color, and here his geometrically abstract but sensuous canvases dazzle with surprising juxtapositions in which one color deeply affects the persona of another. Over the years his style has gone from hard-edge geometric with high-contrast hues in the 1960's to a much more expressive use of lighter, translucent areas with softer edges and closer color values. The progression is interesting to follow, and the color, with a few misses here and there, is an enveloping pleasure (Glueck).

* "PROCACCINI IN AMERICA," Hall & Knight, 21 East 67th Street, (212) 772-2266 (through tomorrow). Who knows when the last time was that a commercial gallery organized an old master retrospective as ambitious as this. It includes a dozen pictures by Giulio Cesare Procaccini (1574-1625), the obscure Lombard Mannerist turned Baroque painter. He was a learned artist of intense and eccentric gifts, melding diverse influences. "The Holy Family With the Infant St. John and an Angel" is perhaps the quintessential Procaccini: a knot of shadowy bodies crowd forward around the brightly illuminated Virgin and Child, with one figure, in the darkness, cut off by the top of the picture. The work is freely, briskly painted, wet into wet; the surface lush, the colors rich and haunting: a painter's painting (Kimmelman).

"SOMETHING WE TALKED ABOUT," Brooke Alexander, 59 Wooster Street, SoHo, (212) 925-4338; and Leo Castelli, 59 East 79th Street, (212) 249-4470 (through tomorrow). Works by John Baldessari, Rita McBride, David Salle and Lawrence Weiner occupy two galleries to play with ideas about doubling. Each artist presents more or less similar works in each gallery, prompting thoughts about absence and presence, the original and the copy, the portable and the site-specific; and so on. It's an interesting idea but the addition of unrelated works confuses the conceptual effectiveness (Johnson).

HEADLINE: FILM REVIEW; 
Turning the Big Screen Into the Small Screen

BYLINE:  By ELVIS MITCHELL 

 BODY:
Filmmakers looking to master the no-budget digital video movie -- which has morphed into a new and often visually tacky subgenre -- need look no further than "Personal Velocity," where Ellen Kuras's cinematography possesses delicacy and freshness.
 Ms. Kuras understands first and foremost that there's no point in trying to pretend that digital video is the same as film. Nor does she light "Velocity" in a way that awkwardly tries to replicate film, a fool's errand. Instead she uses the strengths of digital and wisely chooses to go smaller; she shoots the picture as if it were hand-painted, an intimacy that complements the writer and director Rebecca Miller's script and handling of her actors. 
 The cumulative effect is that of watching misspent lives disintegrate before your eyes. Ms. Miller's canny accomplishment is a triumph, giving the material weight and heart. This is one of the finest pictures of the year because Ms. Miller's knowledge of her characters is mirrored by the secure palette of Ms. Kuras's camera work.
"Velocity," which opens today in New York City and Los Angeles, is taken from Ms. Miller's collection of prose portraits of the same name; it is a triptych, telling the stories of three women. In adopting a piecemeal approach, Ms. Miller uses women of varying humors and temperaments to address an open-ended subtext. Each of these self-contained stories puts the protagonist at a crisis in her life and develops the drama in a free-floating manner. The movie centers on how the women choose to address the problem. (In spirit, the movie mirrors the low-budget adaptation of Grace Paley's urban tales "Enormous Changes at the Last Minute.")
In the first episode Delia (Kyra Sedgwick) is a single mom whose freedom is her body and her uncomplicated sexuality. Ms. Sedgwick is like yards of silk unfurled, flowing and snapping in a glorious midday sun -- the very spectacle makes you smile.
She has finally found a character for her full, rich eyes and long, expressive arms; she plays Delia as a woman who takes life one delicious moment at a time, getting as much pleasure from her kids as she does seeking earthy delight.
When her world begins to fall in on her, one wall at a time, Delia shows the damage slowly, blow by blow. Her pride grows out of her innate ability to enjoy herself; being trapped in an oppressive, abusive relationship deprives her of that gift. She's like a small, abandoned boat taking on water. It won't be long before she goes under.
Ms. Miller shifts tone from story to story with unhurried aplomb; it's as if she takes a deep breath before beginning each new section. The second part stars Parker Posey as Greta, and is played for tense, flamboyantly neurotic comedy. Ms. Miller stages this portion with tightly controlled cameras; characters walk in and out of the unmoving frame, desperate to stake a claim. (It's a page from Ingmar Bergman's notebook that Woody Allen so wisely appropriated.)
Without the loose, rollicking tenor of Delia, Greta is a woman who's all concentration; she seems to exist from the neck up, an exercise of sheer will working to exert some control in the face of her faintly disapproving father (Ron Liebman flexing dismissive eyebrows). Greta's life is in the Manhattan publishing world, where she buzzes through one task after another. Ms. Posey demonstrates a variety of comic skills: she's often like a chatty Fitzgerald heroine, all porcelain perfection, with a modern touch of self-awareness; she knows she's falling apart and is determined to follow through on the disintegration. That doesn't make her plight and her need to be consumed by all the wrong decisions any less hilarious or heartbreaking.
Greta's dilemmas are depicted with such relish and energy, you'll wish her section were longer. The first two stages of "Velocity" are so confidently rendered that the final segment has a lot of pressure on it. Fairuza Balk's performance as Paula is certainly more than a match for the standard that her fellow actresses have set.
This portion is all about the moment of intense self-examination that comes after surviving a catastrophe, and Paula's entire existence becomes a question mark. Running away from a tumultuous relationship, she's pulled into a new one with a young hitchhiker that forces her to come to grips with her future. Paula's melodrama feels diminutive and slightly unformed, despite Ms. Balk's quicksilver, open, emotional quality.
There aren't many actresses who can communicate fear with such economy, and Ms. Balk's large, bright eyes take in all the details of the horrors in her own life and those nearby. She seems like a war veteran trying to leave behind the recent scars of war, and the tentativeness of her story -- it hesitates and hiccups -- doesn't fit with the actress's own strengths. This segment lacks the air of completion that the preceding minidramas contained. 
The remaining slice also makes us most aware of Ms. Miller's decision to use a narrator. The stories have such a closely held interior narrative that this idea makes sense, and the narration isn't used to explain exactly what's going on in the women's heads but rather to outline their dilemmas. Ms. Miller makes a choice that's sure to rile some; the narrator, John Ventimiglia, is a man. It asks an intriguing question: Do women often hear men's voices inside their heads? And is there something about fathers that frames their lives?
Not much is made of this. It's left to the audience to have its own discussions. Ms. Miller's thoughtful, vibrating sensibility will also provoke discussions afterward. Even when the movie is over, the psychological physics of "Personal Velocity" will remain in your head.
"Personal Velocity" is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). It has strong language and sexuality.

PERSONAL VELOCITY

Written and directed by Rebecca Miller, based on her book of short stories; director of photography, Ellen Kuras; edited by Sabine Hoffman; music by Michael Rohatyn; production designer, Judy Becker; produced by Lemore Syvan, Gary Winick and Alexis Alexanian; released by United Artists. Running time: 90 minutes. This film is rated R.

HEADLINE: DRIVING; 
My Gasoline Beats Yours (Doesn't It?)

BYLINE:  By GEORGE P. BLUMBERG 

 BODY:
EVERYONE knows the woman who buys only Mobil, or the man who drives five miles and passes 10 gas stations to get to the BP pump.
 And everyone knows the driver who brags that he will only fill up at the cheapest station in town -- and always knows which one it is. 
 Some of us also know the tomato-tomahto couple who can't agree: one partner is fastidious about gasoline, demanding only a particular brand; the other would rather get it at Wal-Mart and save a couple of dollars for coffee.
So, who is right? Does the driver who insists on a higher-priced brand of gasoline guard his automobile from decay and disruption? Or is he a chump, falling for empty marketing slogans? 
Ah, if the question were only that simple. Yes, there are differences in brands of gasoline, but then again, there aren't. What's safe is a two-part conclusion. All gasoline sold in the United States is basically the same stuff, mingled near the distribution point in the same gigantic tanks, and it is all of good quality. But when the gasoline rivers branch off to be pumped into separate trucks, companies tinker with it, taking that consistently good product (whether regular or premium) and spicing it with their own chemical signatures, the additives that they claim set them apart. The resulting differences are hardly major ones, but if you're an aficionado tuned to your engine's every ping, you may care about them.
Michael Scardino of Brentwood, Tenn., a 52-year-old advertising creative director, said his cars ran better on Chevron and added, "I'd go out of my way to get it." But when the brand is Shell, he said, "I'm never happy with the performance." He also switches periodically between Chevron, Citgo, Exxon and Texaco "to get the additives from one that may be missing in another brand," he said.
Meanwhile, Laura Brengleman, 41, who lives in Greenwich, Conn., and is the editor of the motorcycle magazine RoadBike, puts the cheapest gas she can find in her family car, which has rolled up 150,000 miles so far. "I have no problem buying from a no-name gas outlet," she said, "as long as I see it's a busy station with turnover." (When a station goes through its gasoline supply quickly, there's less potential for water to condense from the air and settle into half-empty tanks.) On the road, Ms. Brengleman said, she might look for Exxon because she counts on its restrooms to be clean.
It sounds as if this brand issue is one for the experts. But they're not much help.
"I can't say one brand is better than another," said Dr. Edward Murphy, a spokesman for the American Petroleum Institute, a trade group that represents oil companies in Washington. "Base gas is a freely traded commodity that must meet certain government specifications. It flows through common pipelines into commingled storage tanks." What he could say, he added, is that "the major brands spend R-and-D money on patented additives, which they add to the basic gas."
Ron Baker, the director of the Petroleum Extension Service of the University of Texas at Austin, is well informed on these additives, which are the true distinguishing elements of gasoline brands. He described them as "detergents and other chemicals" designed to keep gasoline from evaporating, keep engines from corroding, help engines run well in different climates and seasons, and keep engines clean. The goal, he added, is "forming less deposits when the gasoline burns, for better mileage, performance and exhaust emissions." So which brand does Mr. Baker choose? "I buy cheap gas," he said. "All U.S. gas is of good quality."
Gabriel Shenhar, the senior auto test engineer for Consumers Union, the publisher of Consumer Reports, has experience that ought to make him a determined scoffer at brand preference. "We tried to conduct tests a few years ago to measure the differences in acceleration and fuel economy of different gasoline brands," he said. "We bagged the test, because any differences we found were not greater than those you find day to day caused by changing air temperatures or humidity." But in his private life Mr. Shenhar is partial to Sunoco Ultra 94, which he says works best for him in performance and economy.
About 36 percent of adult gasoline users are loyal to one brand or another, said Robert Pasikoff, the president of Brand Keys, a Manhattan brand consulting firm. That leaves 64 percent to be lured into stations by low prices or special promotions.
Perhaps these uncommitted consumers are overwhelmed by the sheer number of brands -- "a couple of hundred," according to Trilby Lundberg, an analyst responsible for the Lundberg Survey, which tracks daily prices and sales at the nation's gas stations.
"Sunoco is big in New York and Pennsylvania, but not in the West at all," Ms. Lundberg said. "The 76 brand is huge all over the West but not on the East Coast." Amoco (now BP at many stations), unknown in Texas, is the top-selling gasoline in the New York metropolitan area. 
"At our Little Rock terminal we store and distribute gasoline for many major brands," said Oakley Bohannon, national accounts director of the Truman Arnold Companies of Texarkana, Tex., a major gasoline distributor. "All the gasoline taps off the same Texas Eastern pipeline, then goes into commingled 150,000-barrel tanks." The distinctive additives go in as tank trucks are filled; the brands acquire their differences just before the gasoline is taken to stations. "If it's a load for Shell stations," Mr. Bohannon said, "the pump injects the Shell additive package with a measured squirt into every 40 gallons of gas."
ALL gasoline has additives. For unbranded gasolines, like those sold at low-cost outlets, the additive is a generic version that meets minimum federal standards, and the ratio is about a third of a gallon of additive to every 1,000 gallons of gasoline. 
Gasoline companies aren't telling what's in their unique additive packages; they are closely held and patented secrets. But whether these details even make a difference to a driver is an open question. "The majors claim they go beyond the federal standard in formulating their additives," Mr. Bohannon said. "I can't argue that, but it's a mystery to me if it's better, and I'm not sure what it practically means. I've sold billions of gallons of unbranded gas over the years, and it has never been a problem."
Major brands tout their own additives while vaguely denigrating one another's. Chevron, whose additive is acknowledged as the most expensive, says it keeps combustion chambers free of deposits while "some of" its competitors' additives will actually increase these deposits. Dave Harvey, the developer of Citgo's additives, says his creation includes a corrosion inhibitor and a de-emulsifier that "others" don't have. Sunoco says its additives perform "above the minimum levels" in cleaning up intake valves and fuel injectors. Shell claims its formula keeps intake valves clean while an unnamed "convenience store gas" damages them.
"The consumer has to take on faith what's in the pump" said Mr. Baker, the University of Texas extension director.
So what gas do his colleagues use? "I took an informal poll of staff at the University of Texas Petroleum Extension Service and asked which brand of gas they think is best," Mr. Baker said. "They all threw up their hands and shrugged their shoulders."
The tomato-tomahto couple may as well just keep arguing.

OCTANE
Premium or Regular? Ask Your Car
GASOLINE brands may be mysterious, but the difference in grades of gasoline -- between regular and whatever kinds of premium a station offers -- is straightforward. Gasoline is graded by octane number, which rates its resistance to premature ignition, or engine knocking. Regular gas has an octane rating of 87, a medium grade is 89, and premium gasolines begin at 91 and go up. Higher-performance cars generally need higher octane. Racecars use a grade of over 100, which you won't find at your local station.
The differences in octane number originate in chemical mixtures created at the refinery, and different grades of gasoline are kept separate throughout the distribution process. The right grade to buy is the one your particular car was engineered for; you need to use only a grade high enough to prevent knock. "Putting premium in a car designed to run on lower octane is a waste of money," said Dennis Simanaitis, the engineering editor of Road and Track magazine.
Using regular in a car designed for premium, however, is a mistake. "If a car is rated to run on premium, it will still run on 87 or 89, but the engine computer will dial back its performance and you won't get optimum performance or gas mileage," Mr. Simanaitis said. In that kind of car, "using premium fuel will eliminate the knock," he added, "and the engine computer will deliver full performance."
So which grade of gasoline is right for your car? Look in your owner's manual.

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Column 5; Leisure/Weekend Desk; Pg. 29

LENGTH: 1552 words

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW; 
A Show Bursting Out

BYLINE:  By HOLLAND COTTER 

 BODY:
SCHEDULING shows at the Metropolitan Museum is like regulating airline takeoffs at Thanksgiving. The queue is long; establishing priorities is a delicate business; the competition for prime runway space is fierce.
 The museum's curators of African art have sidestepped all the fuss in "Genesis: Ideas of Origin in African Sculpture." Rather than wait for one of the deluxe showcase galleries to be free, they've cleared out a piece of their home turf, the Michael C. Rockefeller Wing, and mounted the splendid if compact show there. 
 Even with Daniel Kershaw's ingeniously permeable installation, the space feels small for so large an art. But I always feel this way about African art in museums; to me it looks uncontainable, irrepressible, pressurized to the point of explosion. The impression comes from the physicality of work that is constantly reaching out and pulling in, opening and closing, contrasting light and dark, rough and smooth. It is also a product of conceptual activity that is practical, radical and nonstop. 
The art in the Met's show, from more than a dozen African cultures, does these things:
*It proposes rigorously ethical models for political leadership and a universal etiquette of patience and self-restraint.
*It promotes physical and psychological healing and establishes diplomatic ties with the afterlife.
*For the average person, it shapes a stimulating vision of the here and now by inventing forms that don't exist and reflecting forms that do, so that everyday life feels both exotic and reassuringly familiar.
*Through an exercise of immense wit -- no art is more entertaining -- and moral gravity, it records history, the record of where we came from and where we may be going.
History is the theme of the show, which has been organized by Alisa LaGamma, an associate curator at the museum. Divided into four sections, the first on the creation of the world and mankind, it opens with a heart-melting sight in the form of an eight-inch-tall terra-cotta head of a young woman, made between the 12th and 14th centuries in the city of Ile-Ife in what is now Nigeria.
According to Yoruba myth, Ile-Ife was the birthplace of the first humans, black and white, who were sculptured from clay by the artist-god Obatala, or by the supreme creator Oduduwa, who fashioned the continents. Either would have been proud of modeling this young woman's comely face, scored with undulant lines like flowing water and glowing with serene self-confidence.
To the same degree that early Nigerian naturalism falls comfortably on the Western eye, the Adam and Eve figures carved from wood by a Senufo sculptor in Ivory Coast or Mali present challenges and excitements. Nearly four feet tall with broad shoulders and wedge-shaped heads, their bodies taut with held-in energy, their skin glowing as if filled with sap, they are tremendous and tender things, complementary emblems of the difference-in-sameness balance that keeps the universe in motion.
Once human beings arrived on earth, power politics inevitably followed, and explanations of how government, enlightened or otherwise, came to be is the subject of the show's next section. The story told by the ceremonial masks of the Kuba people of Congo includes an incestuous romance. One mask, encrusted with cowrie shells, represents the first Kuba king. Another personifies his sister, by whom he had children. She is depicted with a strip of beadwork covering her mouth like a seal and her cheeks streaked with painted lines that might be tears.
Luba kingship, by contrast, had more decorous origins. It began with the appearance of a foreign hunter-prince, the young and dashing Mbidi Kiluwe, who established order in an unruly world and whose son, Kalala Ilunga, initiated a dynastic line. To reaffirm this lineage, each new ruler is equipped with a set of ceremonial objects modeled on Kalala Ilunga's, including a staff of office, a bow stand, an abstract map of Luba history known as a memory board and a divination bowl.
The bowl at the Met is attributed to the so-called Buli Master, a 19th-century artist who was the subject of the first special exhibition organized in the Rockefeller wing, in 1980. It is carved in the shape of a woman holding a hollowed-out calabash to be filled with objects used to extract information from the spirit world. With her grave, downcast face and her body curved over the bowl as if to protect it, she makes a stirring figure, not only as a brilliantly realized sculpture but also, as Ms. LaGamma writes in her exhibition catalog, as a "profound commentary on the human spirit's desire to obtain knowledge and influence the course of history."
Family genealogy is also preserved and celebrated through art. For the Fang people of Cameroon, the reverence for lineage focuses on the bones and ashes of forebears. Thought to insure fertility and the safe birth of children, the relics are kept in special containers and guarded by carved ancestor figures with pudgy, infantile bodies and vigilant adult faces.
The Baga people of Guinea express clan or family identity through masks and headdresses based on stylized, hyperbolic animal, bird and insect forms. A butterfly mask has an eight-foot wing span; two very different masks represent serpents, one as tall as a tree and as thin as a spear, the other a thick, sinuously curving column patterned with Harlequin-like black, red and white diamonds. Together they suggest an intense but objective intimacy with the natural world, of the kind hinted at by the social anthropologist Claude Levi-Strauss when he described finding answers to the most complex existential questions in "the brief glance, heavy with patience, serenity and mutual forgiveness that, through some involuntary understanding, one can sometimes exchange with a cat."
This sense of identification, or connectedness, is highly developed in the carved Ci Wara antelope headdresses of the Bamana people of Mali. This sculptural type has long been an emblem for African art and culture internationally. Mali's national airline uses it as a logo. The 40 examples gathered from American collections for the Met show add up to an optical coup de theatre, as a similar ensemble did in "Bamana: The Art of Existence in Mali" at the Museum for African Art last year.
The revelation in that earlier exhibition, re-emphasized at the Met, lay not in how consistent a particular form could remain through many repetitions but in how inventive it could be. Ci Wara is the name of the mythical Bamana hero who introduced agriculture and gave humans a knowledge of plants and animals. It is also the name of the agricultural fraternity that stages masked performances in his honor, and finally of the masks or headdresses themselves, which are composite images of several animals, including antelopes, anteaters and birds.
The show has textbook examples of the sculpture, including male and female pairs. With their squat bodies, beaklike snouts and tapering horns, they share basic features, though the male is distinguished by his windblown mane and the female by the fawn she carries on her back. The variations on these classic types and on the subgenre of horizontally oriented headdresses called n'gonzon koun are astonishing: stripped-down or elaborate, realistic or abstract, changing from place to place, artist to artist. In some cases, the shape is dictated by whether a headdress is created for religious ceremonies or popular entertainment, though often forms and functions are interchangeable.
The Met's installation thrillingly conveys the virtuosity in just this one example of the countless types of sub-Saharan sculpture. What the show cannot do, of course, is fully convey the kinetic dimension of this performance-based art, which is fundamental to how it was imagined and how it appeared to its intended audience.
This is a recurrent issue with museum displays of objects that do not neatly correspond to the Western concepts of art. And while we may have grown tired of revisiting the problem, it remains important, a matter of seeing clearly. Like the bronze temple figures of Hindu gods from South India, displayed in the Met's Asian galleries and assembled en masse in a glorious show at the Arthur M. Sackler Gallery in Washington this fall, the Ci Wara sculptures achieve their ultimate meaning in movement and as part of a dynamic environment. In public processions, the Indian images exchange glances with their devotees; this interaction gives them life. When the Ci Wara headdresses are worn by acrobatic singers and dancers, the sculptures as much as the performers are seen as vivacious.
Ms. LaGamma, thoroughly alert to all of this, has included a fascinating compilation of filmed Ci Wara performances in the exhibition, many of them shot by the art historian and collector Pascal James Imperato. They are given far more prominence than in any Met show I have seen before, and this is good. They may be no substitute for being there when an organic, process-based form of African art is danced to completion, but they are just the right finishing, amplifying touch to an economically executed, grandly conceived show.

"Genesis: Ideas of Origin in African Sculpture" remains at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1000 Fifth Avenue, at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710, through April 13.
