HEADLINE: INSIDE ART 

BYLINE:  By Carol Vogel 

 BODY:
The Morgan On Loan
 Many of the financier J. P. Morgan's favorite medieval artworks -- the ones that he kept in his private study until his death in 1913 and that have since been housed at the Pierpont Morgan Library -- recently went on view in the Medieval Tapestry Hall of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where they will stay for at least two and a half years while the Morgan undergoes a $100 million expansion. 
 "These are objects that will stop people in their tracks," said Peter Barnet, the curator in charge of medieval art at the Met and the Cloisters. "Some of them are among the best Morgan had." Mr. Barnet admits that even the Met's collections don't have examples as complete or as extraordinary. 
Among the best is the Stavelot Triptych from the Abbey of Stavelot in Belgium, made in the 12th century to hold fragments of the True Cross. Incorporating enamel, silver and precious stones, the triptych is considered a masterpiece of medieval goldsmith work, Mr. Barnet said. Its centerpiece is a smaller Byzantine triptych made of cloisonne enamel on gold where the relic of the cross has been placed. "We have wonderful enamels, but almost no museum has a work as complete as this," Mr. Barnet said.
Also on view is the gold and jeweled binding of the Lindau Gospel Book. The front cover, created in the court workshop of the ninth-century Emperor Charles the Bald, grandson of Charlemagne, has finely worked gold, star sapphires, garnets, emeralds, pearls and other stones.
"Many of these pieces were difficult to see at the Morgan because of the way some of the objects were displayed in the study, which is maintained as a period room," Mr. Barnet said. "Here we have three well-lit, free-standing cases."
Other treasures from the Morgan will soon go into storage. On Dec. 4 the McKim building that houses Morgan's original library will close to the public, and the other two buildings will close on May 4. The entire library is to reopen in early 2006.
"We've just completed the design-development phase," said Charles E. Pierce Jr., director of the Morgan. "Despite the economy we feel the time is right for the institution to go forward."
So far the Morgan has raised around $62 million for the project, which is budgeted at $100 million for the building and $25 million for an endowment to support library operations.
The expansion, designed by Renzo Piano, includes a new reading room; more gallery space; a larger, modernized auditorium; improved circulation; and a more welcoming entrance. "The design is completely program driven," Mr. Pierce added.
When the library closes, its staff will move elsewhere in Manhattan to a site not yet determined, Mr. Pierce said. Meanwhile, the Morgan still plans to offer some programs -- lectures, concerts and other educational programs -- in a temporary site that it will announce soon. The library is also organizing six to eight traveling exhibitions.

Lord Thomson's Gift
After the spectacular $76.7 million -- a record for an old master painting at auction -- paid for Rubens's "Massacre of the Innocents" (1609-11) at Sotheby's in London in July, many in the art world wondered if the public would ever have a chance to see this extraordinary painting again. This week the Art Gallery of Ontario in Toronto announced that Lord Thomson of Fleet, the former owner of The Times of London and one of the richest men in Canada, has promised this painting along with nearly 2,000 other works in his collection to the gallery after it completes a $315 million renovation and expansion.
The California architect Frank Gehry has been chosen to design the expansion of the gallery's 1911 building, to be completed in 2007. Plans include adding about 40 percent more gallery space, 75,000 square feet. Lord Thomson is contributing $44 million to the project. Federal and provincial governments are giving $30 million and the rest will come from private donors, gallery officials said.
"This gift is going to make us a very different museum," said Matthew Teitelbaum, its director. "The Rubens, along with related works on paper, will tell the story of the high point of the Baroque. In addition, his collection of European works of art is thought to be one of the finest formed within the last 30 years. It will become an important focus for study." The gift also includes a collection of 19th-century Canadian art.
The gallery has housed 300 works from Lord Thomson's collection since 1997.

A Dallas Skybox
When the Nasher Sculpture Center opens in Dallas in October, it will not only showcase works by artists like Picasso and de Kooning, Moore and Robert Smithson from the real estate developer Raymond D. Nasher's own collection, but also have a site-specific piece commissioned by the installation artist James Turrell. The work, "Tending (Blue)," is one of Mr. Turrell's free-standing "Skyspaces," enclosed spaces that are free-standing structures like rooms open to the sky through rectangular or rounded holes in the roof. Each is large enough for viewers to enter; many have benches so visitors can sit inside them and concentrate on the sky.
"Tending (Blue)," to be placed at one end of the garden, will be a cube measuring 26 by 26 by 26 feet on the outside and 22 by 22 by 22 feet on the inside with a black granite exterior, limestone benches and white plaster walls. It will be able to hold 20 to 25 people. Unlike Mr. Turrell's other "Skyspaces," this one will have both air conditioning and heating so it can be used year round.
"I'm hoping this will be a magnet," Mr. Nasher said. "Turrell is a very exciting artist." Before commissioning the work, he said, he visited many of the artist's installations, including "Roden Crater," Mr. Turrell's project to reshape an extinct volcano near Flagstaff, Ariz. "Everything else in the garden will either be pieces purchased or part of the collection," Mr. Nasher added. "This will be the first Turrell in Dallas."

Off to Buffalo
Louis Grachos, director of Site Santa Fe, a New Mexico contemporary arts center, since 1996, has been named director of the Albright-Knox Art Gallery in Buffalo. Mr. Grachos will succeed Douglas G. Schultz, who is retiring after 30 years at the museum, 19 of them as director. Mr. Grachos is to start on Jan. 21.

HEADLINE: HAVENS; 
Condo Conflict: Fighting Away In Margaritaville

BYLINE:  By JASON TANZ 

 BODY:
STAN RABER works two jobs -- he is the night manager at the Blue Lagoon Motel and an assistant manager at a Circle K convenience store -- to afford his condominium in Truman Annex, a lushly landscaped, 47-acre planned development on the western edge of Key West, Fla. But about three times a week, when he gets home at 7:30 a.m. after working his shift at the Blue Lagoon, he takes a few minutes to walk around the parking lot and write down the license numbers and models of cars he doesn't recognize. Then he arranges that data into a table, cross-indexed by date and parking space. He converts the information into list form and faxes it to the city's code enforcement division. 
 Mr. Raber is determined to rid Truman Annex of an element he is convinced is despoiling his corner of paradise: vacationers who rent a condo from an absent owner and treat the complex's pool as an oversize Jacuzzi and its meticulously groomed grounds as their private playpen. 
 Mr. Raber isn't alone in his anger. The conflict between full-time residents, many of them retirees, and the part-timers who occasionally rent out their homes, has turned this Key West development into a hotbed of controversy over the last couple of years, complete with police investigations, several lawsuits and more than a hundred claims against the city by second-home owners who contend that their freedoms are being trampled.
"It's the most intense issue we've ever dealt with in this city," said Tom Oosterhoudt, a city commissioner. "It's maddening."
All planned developments have, of course, a potential for conflict, as they bring together people who may share little more than a ZIP code. But residential complexes in vacation towns -- in which the residents are typically split between full-timers and second-home owners -- are particularly vulnerable to strife. Each side may have sharply conflicting needs and habits, incomes and ideas of what constitutes a good time.
"You get a tug-of-war of priorities," said Tom Hindman, a lawyer in Wheat Ridge, Colo., who sees these conflicts regularly in his work with homeowners' associations in Vail and Aspen. "The owner who is off site doesn't care about the loud music or the guy who brings the pet with him. So what if somebody had a party out in the pool? They're motivated by the income. But the person who is living there every day is concerned about the quality of life."
Perhaps it's not too surprising that a particularly bitter fight has broken out in Key West, which has long been a study in contrasts. The Victorian showplaces of the moneyed class in Old Town sit just blocks from Mallory Square, where beer-drinking crowds gather each evening to watch the sunset in Margaritaville. 
Paradoxically, short-term rentals, the very issue that has Mr. Raber and some of his neighbors so incensed, is an issue that the City of Key West has tried to regulate. "Transient renting" for less than a month requires a special license, and all the available licenses have been allocated since 1996. Myriad legal challenges to the law are now wending their way through the courts. 
But by all accounts, the battle, which extends throughout Key West, is particularly heated within Truman Annex. Some homeowners argue that because it is a private development, Truman Annex is exempt from the city's rules. Others argue that Truman Annex's own regulations forbid short-term rentals, a claim the pro-rental faction denies. Whatever the case, to hear many full-timers tell it, homeowners are continuing to rent out their units for a tidy profit. 
To all outward appearances, Truman Annex -- named after Harry S. Truman, whose Little White House, now a museum open to the public, is within the complex -- seems a vision of serenity. Beyond the sentry post on Southard Street, T-shirted guards bike through the tree-lined lanes, past the 270 single-family detached homes and upscale two-story condos. The Shipyards, the 183-unit condo development where Mr. Raber lives, has its own gate and board of directors, but it shares the same sense of calm.
In 1999, Truman Annex seemed perfect to Martha and Henry duPont. Tired of feeling inundated by rowdy spring breakers and drunken revelers who show up every October for Fantasy Fest, the duPonts sold their house in the Old Town section of Key West and moved into a large house in the annex. But its gates, it turned out, were no protection against the tourists.
"I had moved into a hornet's nest," Ms. duPont said. The first sign of trouble came before she had even moved in. Her daughter, staying in the house for the summer, called her mother to tell her that "you've got some people living behind you that like to throw some pretty wild parties."
Once Ms. duPont settled in, she noticed unfamiliar faces every week. These guests always said they were relatives or friends of the homeowners, but Ms. duPont was suspicious. Then she learned from a friend that he had rented a house there for a week. Seven months later she hired Lee Rohe, a local lawyer, to bring a suit to end the short-term rentals once and for all.
"There was testimony in the hearing about drunken orgies, sex at the pool," Mr. Rohe said. "One guy almost punched out a homeowner when he tried to quiet them down. Just a lot of crazy stuff."
Truman Annex wasn't always this way, said Angela Dell'Amore, a 67-year-old retired clinical social worker. Ms. Dell'Amore and her husband, John, bought their two-bedroom Shipyards condo in 1991, shortly after the complex opened. Back then, she said, she was surrounded by fellow homeowners, either full-time residents or part-time owners like herself who returned every chance they got. 
In the winter months, a group of 25 residents would meet by the pool for wine and cheese. "There was a real sense of community," she said. 
When the Shipyards opened, there was a limit, tied to the inflation rate, on resale prices, but by the late 1990's, the five-year restrictions were expiring. Homeowners were suddenly able to sell their units at great profit, and many of them did. Real estate agents snapped up five or six at a time and began to rent them. In the next few years, Ms. Dell'Amore said, her neighborhood began to change. 
"We've had people pour wine into the pool until the water turned red," Ms. Dell'Amore said. "Saturdays here are unbelievable. The cleaning people come. You hear rolling luggage everywhere."
Jerry Coleman, a director of one of the annex homeowners' associations, is a lawyer who represents a real estate company and more than a hundred pro-rental homeowners. He contends that some of the complaints about renters' behavior are overblown. "I hear it, but I don't believe it," he said. "This is a small group of busybodies that want to tell people what they can do in their own homes."
B USYBODIES or not, lately they have been very busy indeed. Fed up with what they saw as a blindly pro-rental board of directors, last year some residents organized under the name of Truman Annex Residents Inc., a nonprofit group. Last April, the group packed a City Commission hearing, at which dozens of people spoke out, demanding that the city begin enforcing its ban on unlicensed transient rentals.
Meanwhile, in the Shipyards, Ms. Dell'Amore and Mr. Raber have been patrolling the parking lots and filing reports with the city's code enforcement division -- at the city's request, they say -- every time they suspect that a unit has been rented to a short-term guest. In one six-week period, Ms. Dell'Amore filed 60 complaints.
In May, the city sent in code enforcement officers. John Bollinger, a Shipyards condo owner who has rented his unit, says that he received several phone calls from other angry owners that day: "I got complaints from owners that code enforcement was knocking on doors, asking for documentation why they were there. They said: 'This is like Nazi Germany! We don't want to be harassed in our homes.' " 
Bob Tischenkel, Key West's city attorney, said that the code enforcement division was just doing its job. "Private property owners are always slightly offended," he said. "This is nothing unusual." 
Now the homeowners who have complained about the rentals say it is they who feel harassed. Mr. Raber said that a neighbor challenged him to a fight at a homeowners' association meeting. Bill Estes, another Shipyards owner, said that he put a small cabinet on his porch years ago. As soon as he started agitating against transient rentals, he said, the homeowners' association told him he was violating deed restrictions and demanded that he remove it.
Ms. Dell'Amore said she had started receiving vaguely threatening letters in the mail as well as dozens of unsolicited magazine subscriptions. "It's hard not to feel paranoid," she said. 
Today, the city's enforcement efforts are, for the most part, in abeyance until the various legal maneuvers are concluded. Mr. Coleman, the lawyer and homeowner, and others are challenging the legality of the transient rental ordinance in county court. They have also filed claims against the city, contending that they are being denied rental income and demanding reimbursement.
Meanwhile, Mr. Raber says that once he gets home, he rarely goes outside. "We are relegated to living within our four walls," he said, "because to do anything else makes us uncomfortable and distressed."

HEADLINE: Russian Palladium Producer Investing in Montana Mines 

BYLINE:  By SABRINA TAVERNISE 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Nov. 21 

 BODY:
Norilsk Nickel, the producer of palladium and nickel, said today that it had agreed to acquire a majority stake in the Stillwater Mining Company of Columbus, Mont.
 Norilsk, which is controlled by companies linked to the powerful Russian businessman Vladimir O. Potanin, has agreed to pay $341 million -- $100 million in cash and the rest in the form of about 876,000 ounces of palladium -- or about $7.50 a share for a 51 percent stake in Stillwater, the only American producer of palladium and platinum. 
 Investors, apparently unhappy with the price, bid down Stillwater shares by as much as 15 percent on the news, but the shares later recovered somewhat to close down 38 cents, at $7.03 a share. 
Norilsk said that buying the stake in Stillwater will help it dispose of a large inventory of palladium, a precious metal related to platinum and gold that is used mainly in making automotive catalytic converters. 
Norilsk's sales have been sluggish lately because, after years of erratic deliveries caused in part by Russian government red tape, users of the metal have cushioned themselves by creating their own stockpiles, and now have less need to buy new metal, according to Vasily Nikolaev of Troika Dialog, a Moscow-based investment bank. 
Only one other Russian company has acquired control of a sizable American business since Communism fell: Lukoil, Russia's largest oil producer, bought a chain of Getty Petroleum gas stations in 2000 for $71 million. But many cash-rich Russian companies, in particular the oil producers, have been extending their reach westward in other ways, buying refineries and other assets in Ukraine, Bulgaria and Romania. 
Norilsk will use Stillwater's marketing arm to sell its palladium in North America, by far the most important market for cars and catalytic converters. About 70 percent of the world's palladium production goes into cars, Mr. Nikolaev said.
"Strategically, it's probably a smart move to get this kind of access to U.S. consumers," said Mr. Nikolaev, referring to industrial users of the metal. Still, he said, "the problem is not only lack of trust in Norilsk as a supplier, but also weak demand."
Over the last two years, in part because of the difficulties in getting regular deliveries from Russia, and the stockpiling and searches for substitutes that followed, palladium prices have been quite weak. From a peak of $1,100 an ounce in January 2001, when it was much more expensive than platinum, palladium now sells for about $282 an ounce in the spot market. 
Norilsk's deal for Stillwater begins a new stage in Russia's development as a market economy, said Peter Boone, head of research at Brunswick UBS Warburg in Moscow. As its economy grows and its international credit ratings improve, Russia's companies are getting access to more financing at lower rates, Mr. Boone said.
"The writing is on the wall," he said. "Russians are going to be buying companies abroad."

HEADLINE: U.S. and Britain Urge India To Shed State-Owned Assets 

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: HYDERABAD, India, Nov. 21 

 BODY:
Senior American and British officials touring India today called on the Indian government to scale back its role in the domestic economy, which has lagged behind China in growth.
 Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill said here in southern India today that the country needed stronger legal protections for businesses, which are often vulnerable to sharp swings in regulation or political sentiment. Mr. O'Neill said the Indian economy was attracting only one-tenth the volume of foreign investment now going to China. 
 In Bombay, 600 miles to the west, Britain's chief Treasury secretary, Paul Boateng, said the Indian government should persist in its efforts to sell state-owned enterprises, a process that has been plagued with delays and disputes. Mr. Boateng offered to provide the advice and expertise of the British government, which has considerable recent experience with privatization. He urged India to rein in its chronic budget deficits, which now run to 5 percent of national economic output.
An Indian government minister, reached at home, declined to respond to the remarks. Since throwing off colonial rule, India has been very wary of anything that might smack of foreign interference in its affairs.
Mr. O'Neill and Mr. Boateng are both in India for a meeting of ministers from the Group of 20 developing countries. Attendees are scheduled to attend a dinner in New Delhi Friday night and then spend Saturday in private talks.
The developing countries are expected to call for more foreign aid, something that the Bush administration has promised to try to provide, although not on a scale large enough to satisfy critics.
India's growth rate, while healthy at 6 percent, has not matched China's double-digit rates of the 1990's or its 8 percent rate now. Because China's population is not growing as fast as India's, it has opened an even wider lead in growth of income per person.
A few cities in southern India have boomed by attracting high-technology companies, notably here and Bangalore. But business is stagnating elsewhere, especially in northern and eastern states where local governments still set very detailed regulations.
For India to match its great rival, China, it must emphasize "the fundamentals," Mr. O'Neill said, citing "the rule of law, having contracts that are enforced and fighting corruption."
Mr. O'Neill politely made no mention in his brief remarks to reporters here, nor in the prepared text of the speech he is to deliver on Friday to Indian and American executives in New Delhi, of his personal experience with India's regulatory ways.
In the past, Mr. O'Neill has said that when he was chief executive of Alcoa, he tried to set up a big aluminum smelting operation in India. But the project was ultimately abandoned, he said, in part because of a dispute over whether legally binding contracts could be reached to cover the venture's activities.

HEADLINE: Car Models and Models Vie for Attentionat Seoul Show 

BYLINE:  By DON KIRK 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 21 

 BODY:
The latest Korean car models were on display, but the flesh-and-blood models stole the spotlight as the Seoul Motor Show opened today in a blaze of singing, dancing and hoopla. 
 The dark-suited executives from the country's five carmakers, on hand to extol the technical virtues and glowing sales prospects of the new machines, were no match for the scores of young women in long gowns and miniskirts, in Santa's-helper outfits and sober office wear, hired to lean on hoods and doors, sit behind steering wheels, line up in front of exhibits and pose for snapshot after snapshot. 
 Attractive women draped over the goods have been a staple at trade shows around the world for years, but rarely on the exuberant scale seen here. 
This year's Seoul show features more than 400 models, about half hired by the carmakers and the rest by parts suppliers and other exhibitors. 
Few attendees seemed to question their role in luring visitors to gaze at the gleaming steel evidence of South Korea's rise as an automaker to the world.
No sooner had Nick Reilly and Yu Ki Joon, two top executives of General Motors' recently acquired Korean subsidiary, GM Daewoo Auto and Technology, pulled the cover off the Lacetti, a new Daewoo compact model that went on sale today, than four women in fur-trimmed crimson elf outfits popped out of the front and back seats.
"We hope to manufacture 75,000 of these next year," Mr. Reilly said after posing for photos with Mr. Yu and the elves. "We'll start exporting to Europe and to Australia in about six months. We're still looking at the best time for exporting to the United States, and we're studying China."
At the Hyundai Motor display, the company's president, Kim Dong Jin, predicted that including its Kia subsidiary, which is exhibiting separately at the show, Hyundai will be selling more than five million vehicles a year by 2010, rivaling the Big Three. 
Jerome Stoll, the chief executive of Renault Samsung, was also bubbling with optimistic forecasts for the SM3, a Nissan-derived compact car introduced in September as the company's first new model since Renault took it over two years ago.
"We have some difficulties coping with demand for the car," Mr. Stoll said, struggling to make himself heard as a troupe of singers and dancers behind him performed a song from "Grease." 
He said, the company's only other current car model, the midsize SM5, would turn a profit this year, ahead of schedule.
Even the orphan of the industry, Ssangyong Motor, managed an upbeat mood. The company has been run by its creditors since it nearly went out of business at the height of the Korean economic crisis. Soh Jin Kwan, the president, announced proudly that the company's tiny sales were nonetheless up 48 percent for the year, and that it would soon be profitable again, even though no one seems to want to buy it.
Few seemed to want to talk shop with the executives, either, not amid so much hoopla in the Coex exhibition center. Organizers of the show said that the presence of swarms of models, known as doumi, Korean for "people who serve," was an intrinsic element in the success of any Korean trade show.
"They are very important," said Lee Young Duk of the Korea Automobile Manufacturers' Association. "They are beautiful. People come here to see them."
They play a symbolic role as well, said Mr. Lee, who seemed surprised that a reporter would even ask why they were there. "If a small parts supplier has no money, they might not be able to pay for duomi," he said. "If a company has no money, nobody will go there." 
At the G.M. Daewoo display, Jeo Jung Yeon, smiling as she opened the front door of a Lacetti, spoke of the motor show as a high point of a duomi's year. "This show is the best job," Miss Jeo said. Hired freelance through an agent, she said she made about $120 a day at the show, alternating hours of work and rest from morning to night for 10 days.
Her partner, Lee Min A, was not quite so enthusiastic. "Usually we'll wear the same costume for the whole week," she said, adding that she would rather be in sequined dresses, like the duomi at some other displays. But whatever she wears, "it's hard work, and sometimes people are rude."

HEADLINE: The Sons Also Rise 

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN; E-mail: krugman@nytimes.com

 BODY:
America, we all know, is the land of opportunity. Your success in life depends on your ability and drive, not on who your father was.
 Just ask the Bush brothers. Talk to Elizabeth Cheney, who holds a specially created State Department job, or her husband, chief counsel of the Office of Management and Budget. Interview Eugene Scalia, the top lawyer at the Labor Department, and Janet Rehnquist, inspector general at the Department of Health and Human Services. And don't forget to check in with William Kristol, editor of The Weekly Standard, and the conservative commentator John Podhoretz. 
 What's interesting is how little comment, let alone criticism, this roll call has occasioned. It might be just another case of kid-gloves treatment by the media, but I think it's a symptom of a broader phenomenon: inherited status is making a comeback. 
It has always been good to have a rich or powerful father. Last week my Princeton colleague Alan Krueger wrote a column for The Times surveying statistical studies that debunk the mythology of American social mobility. "If the United States stands out in comparison with other countries," he wrote, "it is in having a more static distribution of income across generations with fewer opportunities for advancement." And Kevin Phillips, in his book "Wealth and Democracy," shows that robber-baron fortunes have been far more persistent than legend would have it. 
But the past is only prologue. According to one study cited by Mr. Krueger, the heritability of status has been increasing in recent decades. And that's just the beginning. Underlying economic, social and political trends will give the children of today's wealthy a huge advantage over those who chose the wrong parents.
For one thing, there's more privilege to pass on. Thirty years ago the C.E.O. of a major company was a bureaucrat -- well paid, but not truly wealthy. He couldn't give either his position or a large fortune to his heirs. Today's imperial C.E.O.'s, by contrast, will leave vast estates behind -- and they are often able to give their children lucrative jobs, too. More broadly, the spectacular increase in American inequality has made the gap between the rich and the middle class wider, and hence more difficult to cross, than it was in the past. 
Meanwhile, one key doorway to upward mobility -- a good education system, available to all -- has been closing. More and more, ambitious parents feel that a public school education is a dead end. It's telling that Jack Grubman, the former Salomon Smith Barney analyst, apparently sold his soul not for personal wealth but for two places in the right nursery school. Alas, most American souls aren't worth enough to get the kids into the 92nd Street Y. 
Also, the heritability of status will be mightily reinforced by the repeal of the estate tax -- a prime example of the odd way in which public policy and public opinion have shifted in favor of measures that benefit the wealthy, even as our society becomes increasingly class-ridden.
It wasn't always thus. The influential dynasties of the 20th century, like the Kennedys, the Rockefellers and, yes, the Sulzbergers, faced a public suspicious of inherited position; they overcame that suspicion by demonstrating a strong sense of noblesse oblige, justifying their existence by standing for high principles. Indeed, the Kennedy legend has a whiff of Bonnie Prince Charlie about it; the rightful heirs were also perceived as defenders of the downtrodden against the powerful.
But today's heirs feel no need to demonstrate concern for those less fortunate. On the contrary, they are often avid defenders of the powerful against the downtrodden. Mr. Scalia's principal personal claim to fame is his crusade against regulations that protect workers from ergonomic hazards, while Ms. Rehnquist has attracted controversy because of her efforts to weaken the punishment of health-care companies found to have committed fraud.
The official ideology of America's elite remains one of meritocracy, just as our political leadership pretends to be populist. But that won't last. Soon enough, our society will rediscover the importance of good breeding, and the vulgarity of talented upstarts. 
For years, opinion leaders have told us that it's all about family values. And it is -- but it will take a while before most people realize that they meant the value of coming from the right family.

HEADLINE: Key Company Assets Moving Offshore 

BYLINE:  By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
American companies have been rapidly shifting some of their most valuable assets to tax havens, where they pay little or no tax on profits, government data show.
 Instead of moving their headquarters offshore, many companies are simply placing patents on drugs, ownership of corporate logos, techniques for manufacturing processes and other intangible assets in tax havens, tax lawyers say. 
 The companies then charge their subsidiaries in higher-tax locales, including the United States, for the use of these intellectual properties. This allows the companies to take profits in the havens and pay far less in taxes. 
From 1983 to 1999 the value of American corporations' assets in Bermuda, the Cayman Islands and 11 other tax havens grew 44 percent more than their assets in Germany, England and other countries with tax rates similar to the United States, Commerce Department data show.
What is more, the havens were given especially lucrative assets, according to an analysis by Martin A. Sullivan, a former Treasury Department economist, published this week in the journal Tax Notes.
The reported profits in tax havens grew far faster than elsewhere. Tax haven profits rose 735 percent, to $92 billion, from 1983 to 1999, while profits in countries that are not tax havens grew only 130 percent, to $114.2 billion.
Bermuda and the other tax havens accounted for 45 percent of the total offshore profits in 1999, but only a fourth of those assets.
Actual taxes paid to the havens ranged from a fraction of 1 percent to 12.5 percent of profits, compared with an effective rate of 35.4 percent in the other countries, the Commerce Department data show.
In all, the 10,000 biggest American companies reported $758 billion in profits worldwide in 1999 and paid taxes to the United States of $154 billion, or 20 percent.
American multinational corporations routinely place ownership of patents, corporate logos and other valuable property in tax havens, said Richard E. Anderson, an international tax lawyer at Arnold & Porter in New York, calling it "international tax planning 101."
"You can't pick up a factory and move it to the Cayman Islands," Mr. Anderson said, "so most of the assets that are going to be relocated as part of a global repositioning are intellectual property. In today's economy that is where most of the profit is. When you buy a pair of sneakers for $250, it's the swoosh symbol, not the rubber" you pay for.
Though a small number of companies have been criticized for trying to move their nominal headquarters to a tax haven, thousands of companies are quietly moving their most valuable assets offshore to escape taxes while keeping their headquarters here, Dr. Sullivan said. The shift allows the companies to both make their domestic operation appear less profitable to the I.R.S. and to take a growing portion of their profits in havens.
A Boston tax lawyer who last summer published a study of assets in tax havens, Avi M. Lev, said that while hard data are not available, "anecdotal evidence suggest that significant intangible assets are beginning to flow offshore."
"The short-term problem is that we are reducing revenues to the United States Treasury from multinational corporations," Mr. Lev said. 
Peter Merrill, chief Washington economist for PricewaterhouseCoopers, said that the surge in tax haven profits could be because valuable assets are being shifted out of the United States. But American companies might also be using new rules adopted during the Clinton administration to shift profits out of foreign countries with higher taxes to tax havens, he said.
As the corporate tax base erodes, the burden of supporting the federal government shifts to individuals. Corporations now generate about a tenth of federal tax revenues, down from about a sixth two decades ago.
For individuals, the portion of their incomes going to taxes rose to 14.8 cents of each dollar in 1999 from 13.1 cents in 1989, according to the Tax Foundation, a group that favors lower taxes.
The tax burden of the 400 highest-income Americans, however, was reduced by more than a fourth by a 1997 tax law. This group, whose average income was $110.5 million in 1998, paid 22 percent of their income in taxes that year, down from 30 percent in 1995, according to an I.R.S. report obtained last year by Professor Joel Slemrod of the University of Michigan.
The Commerce Department figures show that American companies paid 35.4 percent of their offshore profits in taxes in countries that are not tax havens and just 5.8 percent in the 13 tax havens. 
Ingersoll-Rand, Nabors Industries and others that acquired an offshore address in the past year said that high rates of American tax forced them to expatriate. (Federal law gives companies a dollar-for-dollar credit of foreign taxes against the American corporate income tax.)
Before the election, both parties vowed to deny government contracts to companies that acquired an offshore address, a tactic that both Republicans and Democrats denounced as unpatriotic. But after the election, the Republicans reversed course. Republican legislation creating the Homeland Security Department allows such companies to win government contracts if the work is done by an American subsidiary.
The Bush Administration is studying ways to cut corporate taxes further. The Treasury is looking at big ideas, Kenneth Dam, deputy secretary of the Treasury, said at a dinner last week as reported in Tax Notes.
"Corporate tax rate reduction is a big idea," the publication quoted him saying.
Last year, Congress passed a bill allowing companies to quickly write off the cost of new equipment purchased this year and in the next two years. The measure is expected to reduce corporate income taxes by $114 billion over three years, the equivalent of a one-quarter cut in corporate income taxes.

HEADLINE: Jobless Claims Show a Drop; Decline in Indicators Halts 

BYLINE:  Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 

 BODY:
New claims for jobless benefits fell by 25,000 in last week's holiday-shortened workweek to their lowest level since July, the Labor Department reported today. 
 The level of initial claims, which is considered a rough guide to the health of the labor market, slipped to 376,000 in the week ended Nov. 16, from a revised 401,000 in the previous week. That was the lowest since the week ended July 20, when initial claims for jobless benefits totaled 366,000. 
 There was some skepticism, though. "The drop is kind of suspicious, especially given the Veterans Day holiday," said Drew Matus, senior economist at Lehman Brothers. Wall Street economists had forecast new claims at the higher level of 392,000. 
"But the four-week average is moving lower," Mr. Matus said, adding, "It does suggest to us the labor market may have improved slightly."
The drop in new claims pulled the four-week moving average for jobless claims down to 395,750, from 400,250 the previous week. The moving average, considered a more reliable barometer of job market trends because it irons out weekly fluctuations, is at its lowest since August.
In a sign that the pace of hiring may have improved, the report said that the number of people continuing to draw jobless benefits fell to 3.58 million in the week ended Nov. 9, the latest week for which data are available, from 3.64 million the week before. 
In a separate report today, the Conference Board said that the index of leading economic indicators was unchanged in October after a 0.4 percent drop in September. The index, an important forecasting gauge, had fallen for four consecutive months, the board, a New York-based private research group, said. 
"Only consumption has consistently fueled the recovery through the first 10 months of this year," the Conference Board's chief economist, Ken Goldstein, said. "The disappointing employment and output data through October reflect the fragile state of the economy as it enters the holiday season."
The coincident index, which gauges current economic trends, was unchanged in October, as it was in September, and "continues to suggest a recovering yet fragile economy," the board said.

HEADLINE: NASD Says It Plans to Delist Neoforma, Hospital Supplier 

BYLINE:  By MARY WILLIAMS WALSH 

 BODY:
Neoforma, which operates a Web site where hospitals can order supplies, has been told that it will be delisted by the Nasdaq stock market for failing to report its quarterly financial results on time.
 Neoforma said that it would appeal the NASD's decision and that it expected to file its full financial statements for the third quarter in three weeks. The report is late because the company concluded in October that it had to restate its financial results for 2000, 2001 and the first half of this year. 
 Since 2000, Neoforma has been a close business partner of Novation, a company that negotiates contracts for hospitals to buy medical supplies. Novation's stated mission is to help its 2,500 member hospitals save money. But questions have been raised this year about its business practices and the practices of similar groups.
After a series of articles in The New York Times, inquiries into the way Novation and groups like it do business were begun by a Senate panel; the Federal Trade Commission; and the New York attorney general, Eliot Spitzer. In August, Novation pledged to change its operations.
Neoforma has said that the financial restatement involves, among other things, the way it accounted for its original operating agreement with Novation and its corporate parents. Earlier this year, the company dismissed Arthur Andersen, the auditor that had approved its accounting methods. The problems surfaced under Novation's new auditor, Deloitte & Touche. 
Neoforma said yesterday that its request for a hearing before the NASD's listing-qualifications panel would allow its stock to continue trading for now. Shares rose $1.73, to $11.73.
In October, Neoforma said its restatement would "have a significant impact" on its revenue until the second half of 2005. It said that after the restatement, revenue for the third quarter of 2002 would be $1.3 million. In the third quarter last year, Neoforma reported $8 million in revenue.
Neoforma has never been profitable. Last year, it reported that it had lost a total of $541 million since its founding in 1996.
Already, hundreds of nonprofit community and university hospitals have been sustaining Neoforma, jointly contributing about $70 million in subsidies, stock purchases and loans to the company. The hospitals own Novation through its corporate parents, VHA Inc. and University HealthSystem Consortium.
Through Novation, the hospitals now own about 60 percent of Neoforma. Novation is also Neoforma's largest customer by far, accounting for about 88 percent of its revenue last year. In addition, officers and directors of Novation and its corporate parents made the decision to extend $70 million to Neoforma. 
The financial assistance has been a sore point with some of Novation's hospitals, whose officers say they were not consulted.
To the further dismay of the hospitals, a number of executives of Novation and its corporate parents owned stock in Neoforma when the financing was approved. They have since sold most of those holdings. 
Executives of Novation and VHA have said they committed the hospitals' money to Neoforma because they believed that hospitals could save money by buying their supplies electronically.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Nasdaq Hits Highest Level In 5 Months; Dow Is Up 222

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
A surge in technology stocks led the market higher yesterday and pushed the Nasdaq composite index to its highest level in five months.
 The buying, which left the three main market gauges up more than 2 percent, could be signaling a new trend in the market, or could be another in the recent mood swings that have sent stocks higher and then lower since summer. 
 Economists generally agree that the economy is slowing toward a 1 percent annual growth rate in the fourth quarter after a 3 percent pace in the third. That realization did not help stocks. 
But now investors have had time to absorb the surprise half-point cut in interest rates by the Federal Reserve two weeks ago and assurances since then from Fed officials that they have the tools needed to give the economy another lift, if necessary. So the mood may be turning optimistic again.
Yesterday's surge was set off by the report after the market closed Wednesday that Hewlett-Packard had beaten Wall Street estimates for quarterly sales and profit. Shares of Hewlett-Packard rose 12.7 percent, or $2.14, to $18.99, leading the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index higher.
Technology stocks have been the power behind the equity rebound that began Oct. 9, after the overall market had fallen to its lowest level in five and a half years. The two broad technology sectors in the S.& P. 500 index have climbed more than 38 percent since then.
At the same time, expectations for technology earnings in the fourth-quarter have fallen, driven down largely by the companies themselves. But this has turned out to be a positive development because the lower profit thresholds are more likely to be met or beaten, which is good for the stock prices. Hewlett-Packard's earnings of 24 cents a share beat Wall Street forecasts of 22 cents. Those forecasts had come down from 23 cents on Aug. 1, the beginning of Hewlett-Packard's fourth quarter.
"You have driven down tech prices enormously, and some stocks are now priced pretty cheaply," said William E. Rhodes, chief investment strategist of Rhodes Analytics in Boston. This price drop, he added, means that "historically, for some tech stocks, valuations are not that high."
At the close, the Nasdaq was up 48.20 points, or 3.4 percent, to 1,467.55. That surpassed the high reached in the summer rally, which ended Aug. 22 with the Nasdaq at 1,422.95. The Nasdaq has not been this high since June 19. But while the Nasdaq is near a five-month high, it is only 44 points above the low it reached after the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, 2001.
Among the stocks pushing the Nasdaq higher were Intel, up 5.5 percent; Microsoft, up 2.2 percent; and Cisco Systems, up 6 percent. 
The Dow was up 222.14 points, or 2.6 percent, to close at 8,845.15. That is still 208 points below the high on Aug. 22 of 9,053.64. 
The S.& P. 500 index rose 19.61 points yesterday, or 2.2 percent, to 933.76, almost 29 points below the close on Aug. 22 of 962.70.
Because the Dow and S.& P., which have lower weightings of technology stocks, have yet to break above their Aug. 22 levels, announcing a new trend in the market is difficult. But there was an end-of-the-year market rebound last year, with the Nasdaq up 37 percent from its Sept. 21 low. The Dow rose 21.7 percent, and the S.& P. 500 rose 18.9 percent.
The current rally has lasted 31 trading days, already 9 more than the summer rally from July 24 through Aug. 22. The S.& P. index is up 20.2 percent, slightly behind the 20.7 percent rise in the summer. The Dow has beaten its summer performance with a 21.4 percent climb to date, compared with a 17.5 percent rise in July and August.
General Electric also helped push the market higher, despite the fact that the company lowered its profit forecast for this year and next. What appeared to be a positive was that G.E. said that it would have to set aside $1.4 billion in additional reserves against losses at its reinsurance unit, less than the $2 billion that many analysts had expected. G.E. also raised its quarterly dividend by a penny, to 19 cents a share.
Worries about losses at the reinsurance unit because of asbestos claims and those related to the terrorist attacks had been depressing G.E.'s stock.
After the announcement yesterday, shares of G.E. jumped $2.05, or 8.3 percent, to $26.85. It is still almost 22 percent below its Aug. 22 close of $32.70.
There was also some positive economic news yesterday, with the report from the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia that its regional manufacturing index rose to 6.1 in November from minus 13.1 in October. A reading over zero means that a majority of the manufacturing companies surveyed said business had improved.
In addition, initial claims for unemployment benefits dropped to 376,000 last week from 401,000 the week before, the lowest level in four months.
These scraps of brighter economic data, along with the surge in stocks, sent bond prices lower and yields, which move in the opposite direction, higher. The yield on the Treasury's 10-year note jumped to 4.15 percent, from 4.06 percent Wednesday. The price fell 24/32 to 98 25/32 .
Shares of Morgan Stanley jumped $2.89, or 6.6 percent, to $46.40, after it was reported that the brokerage firm planned to cut about 2,000 more jobs, or about 4 percent of its work force, as business for underwriting stocks and trading equities slows.
Morgan Stanley's latest layoffs reflect an industrywide trend. Lehman Brothers laid off about 500 employees a week ago and two Dutch financial firms, ING and ABN Amro, both announced layoffs yesterday.
The other big player in the stock market rally since Oct. 9 has been financial stocks, including banks, insurance companies and brokerage firms. The S.& P. sector including these stocks was up 27 percent through yesterday.
The sector that has performed the poorest is consumer staples, which are often a refuge for investors when the economy is weak. This sector has slipped 0.4 percent.

HEADLINE: New York's Budget Needs More Cuts, Pataki Acknowledges 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA

DATELINE: ALBANY, Nov. 21 

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki's budget director today asked state agencies to cut spending by 5 percent for the rest of this fiscal year, and said cuts next year would be deeper than expected.
 It was the administration's first admission that the state was in worse financial shape than it predicted earlier this year, something that officials in both houses of the Legislature have been saying since the summer. 
 As recently as last month, administration officials insisted that the current budget would take the state through the end of the fiscal year, March 31, without any significant changes.
Cuts in the next year's budget have long been expected, with the state facing a deficit that legislators have estimated at $5 billion to $10 billion. The governor's office has not put a figure on the shortfall. Mr. Pataki will propose a budget for that year in January.
"These are very difficult economic and fiscal times for the city, for our state government and for other state governments," Mr. Pataki said at an unrelated appearance here today, "and we do have to look at a number of different things as we go forward to deal with the decline in revenue."
In a letter to department chiefs, Carole E. Stone, the budget director, told them to report back no later than Nov. 29 with new budget-cutting plans.
"I am asking that you prepare to accelerate implementation of the proposals that are being developed for the 2003-4 executive budget to maximize savings in the current fiscal year, and that you develop more aggressive proposals for next year," she wrote.
For the current year, she wrote, state agencies should aim for "savings totaling a minimum of 5 percent," and those savings "should recur or grow in 2003-4."
Late last year, Mr. Pataki announced a hiring freeze, saying he intended to reduce the state's work force by 5,000 people, or about 2 percent, by early 2003, through attrition and early retirement incentives, as part of an effort to trim expenses by $3 billion. Though it appears that the state might meet the 5,000-job goal, the state has hired several times as many workers in the same period.
In her letter, Ms. Stone said agency heads should "place particular focus on reducing your agency work force." But state officials said it was fairly clear that relying on attrition and buyouts would not reach the target of cutting spending by 5 percent quickly enough.
Last month, as Mr. Pataki, a Republican, was running successfully for re-election, his Democratic opponent, State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, released a report saying that six months into the fiscal year, general fund revenue was down 16 percent from the previous year, compared with the 5 percent predicted at the time the Legislature approved the budget. The governor's office disputed those figures but did not provide its own.
An updated report from Mr. McCall this week put the general fund decline at 8 percent.

HEADLINE: Transit Fare Increases Are Certain, M.T.A. Board Decides 

BYLINE:  By RANDY KENNEDY

 BODY:
The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has ruled out cutting service to maintain the current transit fare, guaranteeing that fares and tolls will rise next year to close a gap of almost $1.1 billion in the agency's budget, officials announced yesterday.
 The only questions now, they said, are whether the basic fare will rise to $1.75 or $2 and whether there will be service cuts or deeper discounts for MetroCard users. 
 Earlier this week, the authority held out the possibility that the fare could be maintained if deep service cuts were imposed. But Peter S. Kalikow, the authority chairman, said at a board meeting yesterday that officials had ruled out that plan because "in the end we would not be able to fulfill our mission and we would go back where we were" when the system suffered from severe neglect in the 1970's and 80's. 
As opponents of an increase stood outside on Madison Avenue with bullhorns chanting "Stop the fare hike! Open those books!" Mr. Kalikow insisted that the authority could find no other way to fix its badly broken budget. "We don't propose fare hikes or service cuts frivolously," he said.
Officials said the first option was raising the base fare to $1.75 and imposing significant cuts in service, such as a 10 percent drop in weekend subway and bus trips and cuts in cleaning.
Under this plan, there would also be a similar fare increase for the Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North Commuter Railroad but only a 25-cent rise in bridge and tunnel tolls. Those increases would come with similar service cuts, such as fewer trains, ticket-window closings and fewer cleaners. A $1 monthly fee for E-ZPass users on the highways would also be levied.
The second plan is to raise the subway and bus fare to $2 with commuter rail and toll increases, but to offer deeper discounts than are now available for MetroCard users and monthly pass users on the commuter rails.
For example, Mr. Kalikow said, a monthly unlimited-ride MetroCard might rise to $70 from $63, meaning that a fare increase would be felt much less by those who could afford to use the monthly or weekly cards.
Transit officials said this plan would increase fare revenues by $850 million over the next two years and, along with other savings, would close the budget gap as long as state and city aid remained level and the economy continued to improve.
They added a third plan, which would give the authority a larger cushion if the economy faltered or state and city subsidies declined, a real possibility as both Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Gov. George E. Pataki seek to repair their own debt-ridden budgets. Yesterday, in fact, Mr. Bloomberg repeated that he wanted to cut the city's contribution of more than $300 million to the authority. "We have to cut everything back," he said, "and while it is a state law as to how much we have to subsidize the M.T.A., we're cutting back other services. It's only appropriate that if you spread the pain evenly, there would be some cuts there, too."
The third option, transit officials said, would increase fares and tolls but offer the same level of discounts available now. The weekly unlimited MetroCard, for example, could rise to $23 and the monthly card to $84. This option, officials said, would balance the transit budget even if the authority lost $400 million in expected income over the next two years and had to spend more on security.
Transit officials sought to explain yesterday how it was that the authority had ended up in such financial straits after having a surplus of almost $200 million just four years ago.
Gary G. Caplan, the authority's budget director, said the problems have been caused by rising pension costs, dropping income from taxes dedicated to mass transit and rising service payments on the authority's debt, which has increased substantially over the past few years to pay for capital improvements. Officials also noted that the authority's labor contracts were being negotiated and that those costs would probably rise.
Mr. Caplan and others also said repeatedly that, with the MetroCard, the average fare has actually decreased since 1995, when it was raised to $1.50. The average fare is now $1.04 because people have taken advantage of card discounts.
Opponents of a fare increase, however, questioned whether the authority's finances were as bad as officials were saying. Even if they were, they asked, should riders be responsible for fixing them? In other cities, riders pay a much smaller part of transit systems' operations with fares, and the government -- to encourage use of mass transit -- provides greater subsidies. (In Boston, for example, fares pay 29 percent of transit operations. In New York, the current fare pays 58 percent of the cost, according to the Federal Transit Administration.)
"If there are fiscal problems," said Roger Toussaint, president of Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union, "it is not the fault of passengers, who are riding and paying at near-record levels. It is not the fault of our members, whose productivity has soared, causing per-rider costs to drop. The long-term problem is Albany's neglect of adequate public funding for mass transit."
Gene Russianoff, the staff lawyer for the Straphangers Campaign, also questioned why the basic bridge and tunnel tolls, which the plans would increase by either 25 cents or 50 cents, were not being increased as sharply as fares. Traditionally, tolls have risen along with fares, and the extra toll money has been used to help keep fares down as part of a longstanding public policy to encourage mass transit use.
"What I'm concerned about is whether a 35-year-old policy of using toll surpluses to keep fares affordable is ending," he said.
Mr. Kalikow said he discussed the fare-increase options with Governor Pataki, who controls the authority board and maintained during his recent re-election campaign that he opposed an increase.
"He heard what we said," Mr. Kalikow said of the governor. "I don't have a decision, but we'll discuss it."
Mr. Kalikow added that anyone else who wanted to offer suggestions could do so on the authority's Web site, www.mta.info.

HEADLINE: Throwaway Societies of Yesteryear; 
Past Decades Were the Golden Ages for Waste, Scientist Says

BYLINE:  By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
The idea that America's output of garbage rises ever skyward -- more trash, year by passing year -- has become one of the great unchallenged assumptions about how the world works. The sun rises, the swallows return to Capistrano and our moldering mountain of refuse grows higher. The disposable society, like the tide, sweeps all before it.
 Daniel C. Walsh believed it, too, until he began poking through the musty records in the New York City Archives about 15 years ago. Dr. Walsh, an adjunct professor at the Earth Institute at Columbia University, stumbled on a long-unread paper trail that he said might be unique among big American cities: 100 years of painstakingly kept records about what New Yorkers threw away. 
 The millions of entries -- recording the weight of each cartload and truck, with periodic detailed examinations of what the carts contained -- began in the late 1800's. And when those entries are laid end to end in a timeline, as Dr. Walsh has done in a paper published last week in Environmental Science and Technology, they shatter a lot of myths. 
The much-lauded greatest generation of the 1920's and 1930's, for example, threw out far more garbage, Dr. Walsh found, than New Yorkers living today in the era of shrink wrap and single-serve. Pounds of trash per person peaked not in the prosperous 1990's, but in 1940.
Most people might expect that the trash of old was also more organic in content, with a higher proportion of materials derived from plants and animals -- a kind of dustbin extension of Grandma's kitchen, full of corncobs, peach pits, butcher paper and other compostable artifacts of a domestic age. 
Wrong again. Organic waste made up a higher proportion of New York City's garbage stream at the century's end, mainly from paper, than in any period before -- four times higher than it was in 1905, and almost twice as high as it was on the eve of World War II.
Even the history of recycling, the record showed, was not quite what it seemed. By many measures, Dr. Walsh found, the golden age of recycling in New York was not the save-the-earth 1970's, but the gilded-age 1890's, when mandatory curbside separation of trash was imposed. Recycling faded before World War I and did not return until the 1990's. 
Well, then how about product packaging? Surely it must be true that there's more of that now. Here Dr. Walsh, a geochemist by training who is also the chief of environmental monitoring in New York City for the State Department of Environmental Conservation, found that the conventional wisdom is only partly true, at best. The increase in packaging has been more than countered by the decrease in packaging weight. Trash per person in New York has barely budged in the last 20 years.
The great trend of the 20th century, Dr. Walsh concluded, has been toward less garbage -- or at least lighter garbage -- because the economics demanded it and technology made it possible. 
"There are very significant forces out there that are working to minimize the mass of the waste stream," he said. "The forces are strong and they're incredibly effective."
There are a few huge factors that explain -- or, some critics might say, skew -- Dr. Walsh's conclusions. A major element in explaining why the garbage today is lighter, and has a higher organic component, comes down to how New Yorkers heat their homes. The use of coal, which produces ash once tossed into landfills, began declining in the 1920's in favor of oil and later natural gas. By the early 1960's, when pounds of trash per person reached their lowest point in the century, that fuel transition had largely been completed. 
Dr. Walsh also conceded that lighter garbage did not necessarily mean fewer items. The city's records reflect weight per person, not volume. Still, the trend is clear that trash, over time, only gets lighter.
The average plastic gallon milk jug, for example, is a third lighter than it was in the 1970's. The oil crisis that struck in the middle of the decade pushed truckers and manufacturers to seek alternatives that were lighter and used less raw material. Remember how much an ordinary American beer bottle weighed during the administration of Gerald Ford? Go to a Chinese restaurant and order a Tsing Tao, brewed in China by bottlers who haven't faced the same pressures to lighten up. 
Garbage experts and historians of sanitation (a bigger club than you might think) say that Dr. Walsh has nailed a process that has largely been overlooked: that the market -- not politics or social policy -- mostly determines what happens inside the nation's garbage cans. But some also say that less waste per person and less waste as a society are not the same.
"I think there was not so much a reduction as a shifting of waste," said Mark A. Izeman, a lawyer at the Natural Resources Defense Council, a New York-based conservation group. The change in fuels toward oil and electricity, for example, might mean less garbage that New Yorkers put on the curb, he said, but more waste and pollution at the power plants where energy was produced. 
Lighter plastics have also meant greater reliance on chemically complex plastics that are harder to recycle. Technology, through the disposal of things like computers and batteries, Mr. Izeman said, has also made the waste stream far more toxic than it was in the past.
The heart of Dr. Walsh's research, however, is the century timeline -- a kind of ticker tape of trash that flickers by, marked by the rise and fall of trends and forces that would seem to have little to do with what people threw away. 
World War I and World War II loom as blips, when trash levels fell because of wartime scrap drives. Trash per person surged in the Roaring 20's and continued rising even during the Great Depression of the 1930's, partly perhaps because of construction debris from the huge public works projects undertaken in those years. Trash levels fell in the mid-1970's as the city's fortunes declined.
There are also images of a city long faded from view. 
Through the 1930's, for example, New Yorkers lived -- or at least ate -- in a greater rhythm with the seasons than they do today. Because refrigeration and transportation were still limited, fresh fruits and vegetables, reflected in the record as food waste, peaked with the harvest in late summer and early fall. Food waste reached its low point in January and February, when fresh produce was for most people not to be had.
But the most profound conclusion that emerged from the records, Dr. Walsh said, was not the historical nuggets, but the underlying engine that produced them. The big economic drivers of the 20th century -- improved transportation and refrigeration, the transformation of consumer convenience, the pressure on businesses to cut costs -- all moved in one direction: toward less waste, not more. He stressed that those findings were a result of independent research at Columbia, not his environmental work for the state.
"Everything relates to two principal factors -- one is reducing costs, making things lighter and easier to transport, and the other is making them more convenient to the consumer," Dr. Walsh said. "And that often means making them lighter, also. I see this pattern throughout the century."
Garbage economics does not always help, though. Sometimes it actually adds to the city's trash burden. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said this year, for example, that weak prices had made much of the city's recycling program untenable. The city suspended the recycling of glass and plastic in June, although Mr. Bloomberg said he hoped to restore the program in the next few years.
Sanitation experts say that Dr. Walsh's study proves Mr. Bloomberg right: markets do matter when it comes to trash. Another implication is that the market itself might bring recycling back into vogue.
"Recycling is going to become more cost effective relative to our other alternatives," said Benjamin Miller, a former City Sanitation Department official and author of "Fat of the Land: Garbage in New York, the Last Two Hundred Years" (Four Walls Eight Windows, 2000). Mr. Miller said he thought that rising costs of landfill disposal in places like Pennsylvania, where much of the city's trash now goes, would eventually tilt the balance back to the point where recycling is the less expensive choice.
Dr. Walsh said he had also become more optimistic that the trend toward reduction would continue.
"Sometimes these forces happen fast, like the replacement of metal and glass with plastic and aluminum; sometimes they're slow, like the replacement of coal, which took 50 years," he said.
Paper, currently the biggest item in the waste stream, will ultimately be replaced, too, in coming decades, Dr. Walsh said, by more economic digital technologies.
"There's no question that it will happen," he said, "because the forces are consistent through the century, and they will be consistent throughout the next."

HEADLINE: New Jersey Narrows Field Of Redevelopers for Arena 

BYLINE:  By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 21 

 BODY:
New Jersey officials winnowed the field of potential redevelopers for the Continental Arena site in the Meadowlands from six to three today, eliminating proposals that centered on Nascar racing and extensive residential development.
 The proposals that cleared this first hurdle in a nearly three-month selection process by the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority emphasize offices and shops built around different cores: a convention center combined with an indoor extreme-sports park, a family entertainment and sports complex that includes a minor-league baseball stadium, or an entertainment complex in an "urban village" setting. 
 All of the proposals for the 106-acre site seek to replace the arena, the current home of the New Jersey Nets and Devils, who are expected to move by 2005 to an arena proposed for downtown Newark.
The three finalists are consortiums with strong interests in the Meadowlands and the region, and extensive development experience in the state, but authority officials said that it was just a coincidence that they had all made it this far. 
Among them is the Westfield Group, which owns the nearby Garden State Plaza. Also chosen was a partnership of Forest City Ratner and Hartz Mountain Industries, the largest private landowner in the Meadowlands. The third finalist, the Mills Corporation, a mall builder with the development rights to a large, environmentally sensitive parcel near the Meadowlands, has indicated it would forgo developing that site if it is chosen as the Meadowlands redeveloper. The company is teamed with Mack-Cali Realty Corporation.
"These proposals contain the components and ideas that best suit the site," said George Zoffinger, the president and chief executive officer of the sports authority.
He and Carl Goldberg, the authority's commissioner and chairman of its redevelopment selection committee, said that one thing became clear in talks with advisory groups of merchants, elected officials and residents of the towns surrounding the Meadowlands: they did not want an automobile racing oval in their midst.
Most said they feared the noise from racing and the traffic that would be drawn to the 80,000- to 100,000-seat grandstands that had been proposed. "Politically it's a heavy lift," said one of the developers, referring to the two proposals that envisioned Nascar events.
David Talley, a spokesman for International Speedway Corporation, a company based in Daytona, Fla., that made one of the racing proposals, said the company would continue to try to introduce the sport to the region. The company has exclusive rights until next August to try to persuade the sports authority to allow it to redevelop the nearby Meadowlands Raceway, a horse racing track, for Nascar events.
Mr. Zoffinger said the three finalists must now provide more detailed information on the financing of their proposals, on their provisions for transportation and on the impact their plans would have on the environment. Those details are expected by Dec. 30, he said, and the authority is expected to announce its choice of developer early next year.
From the beginning, Mr. Goldberg and other officials involved in the selection process have said that they expected the successful bidder to contribute substantially to financing the construction and reconfiguration of roads around the site, and to creating the first-ever rail or light-rail connections to the Meadowlands site. 
The initial proposals were thin on such details, but Mr. Goldberg said the finalists are likely to flesh out "their willingness to invest private dollars" for a rail link and road work, which some have estimated could cost as much as $700 million.
The Westfield Corporation plan, with an estimated cost of nearly $1 billion, calls for converting the arena into an entertainment and theater complex with exhibition space set amid an "urban village" of low-rise shops and restaurants, and offices and hotels. A spokesman for the company said today that it was "pleased and delighted" to make the cut.
Emanuel Stern, president of Hartz Mountain Industries, said he, too, was enthusiastic about being a finalist. The $815 million "ExpoPark" proposal by Hartz and Forest City Ratner includes a medium-size convention center, an extreme-sports complex, four office buildings, hotels, shops and a multiscreen cinema.
A spokesman for the Mills Corporation and Mack-Cali group could not be reached. Their $1.2 billion "Meadowlands Xanadu" would include a hotel conference center and possibly a convention center, twice as much retail space as the other finalists, an extreme sports center, a Canyon Ranch spa and minor-league ballpark.
A group of Newark residents filed a lawsuit today in Essex County Superior Court that could affect the proposed arena for the Nets and Devils. The suit contends that city officials ignored public hearing requirements last month in agreeing to finance the arena with $165 million in windfall lease proceeds from a newly negotiated deal for the operation of Newark Liberty International Airport.

HEADLINE: Ordering Hunt for Bomb Plotters, Sharon Resists More Drastic Steps 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Nov. 21 

 BODY:
Prime Minister Ariel Sharon ordered Israeli forces today to return to Bethlehem to hunt down those responsible for a suicide bombing on a Jerusalem bus this morning that killed 11 people, including at least four children, and wounded dozens, Israeli officials said.
 For the moment Mr. Sharon resisted pressure from his political right for more drastic military action, although Israelis reeled from images of grieving parents and scattered school books, and a shredded teddy bear carried from the wreckage by an emergency worker. 
 The bombing and the Israeli and Palestinian responses to it provided a painful glimpse into the turmoil in the politics on both sides more than two years into the current conflict. 
In the foreground was the crippled bus, not far from the boundary with Bethlehem, the 23-year-old bomber's hometown; in the background were the sweeping ambitions of the Bush administration to reshape the Middle East with a possible war on Iraq. 
Israeli officials said Mr. Sharon, who met into the night with his security advisers, had been governed in his response by the American military intentions. "We are not going to allow any kind of escalation," said Raanan Gissin, Mr. Sharon's spokesman. He accused Palestinian terrorists of stepping up their own attacks in hopes of provoking such a response and opening a second front ahead of an Iraq war.
Through a spokesman, the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat condemned the bombing as terrorism. Hamas and Islamic Jihad, two militant Islamic groups, issued dueling claims of responsibility for the attack.
Mr. Sharon calculates that it is in Israel's interest to do what it can to avoid hindering the American effort to gain international support for a possible assault on Iraq. Israeli officials hope that an American victory will ultimately force Israel's adversaries in the region to sever links to terrorism and Palestinian militants.
Mr. Sharon also has more immediate concerns. In a week he faces a primary contest to retain the leadership of the Likud Party against Benjamin Netanyahu. Mr. Netanyahu, the former prime minister who recently became foreign minister, has shifted his emphasis from criticizing Mr. Sharon for failing to stop Israel's economic slide to criticizing him for failing to safeguard its security.
Recalling his own tenure as prime minister in the 1990's, Mr. Netanyahu has been declaring in advertisements: "Four suicide bombings in three years." In a deft twist of the knife, the advertisements are appearing on the sides of buses.
Dozens of suicide bombers have struck since Mr. Sharon was elected in February 2001 on a platform of peace and security.
But so far, Mr. Netanyahu's attacks from the right have not done much damage to Mr. Sharon within Likud. They appear to have placed him closer to the center of Israeli politics, the position that has helped sustain his popularity.
Mr. Sharon's response to today's bombing, if it remains restrained, may have the same effect, while also underscoring the cooperative relationship he has built with President Bush.
At the same time, the bombing could not have been more precisely timed or targeted to undermine Israel's left-of-center alternative to Mr. Sharon. Just two days ago, the Labor Party elected as its new leader Amram Mitzna, who will compete in general elections on Jan. 28 as Labor's candidate for prime minister against the winner of the Likud primary.
Mr. Mitzna is a former general who advocates immediate negotiations with the Palestinians, without conditions, and a unilateral Israeli withdrawal of soldiers and settlers from the Gaza Strip. Among other conditions before negotiations resume, Mr. Sharon insists that Mr. Arafat be replaced as Palestinian leader and that Palestinians halt all violence.
At issue is a fundamental difference of belief over the source of the conflict. Where Mr. Sharon sees a relentless, generations-old campaign of Arab terror to destroy the Jewish state, Mr. Mitzna sees some Israeli culpability, stemming from Israel's occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip after the Arab-Israeli war of 1967.
The wreckage of the No. 20 bus is a problem for the latter theory of the conflict and a possible blow to the idea that an Israeli withdrawal to pre-1967 borders might end the violence. The bombing took place on land that was Israel's before the 1967 war, and its victims included schoolchildren rather than only settlers and soldiers.
In fact, a debate is under way among Palestinians over whether it is legitimate to attack Israelis outside what is known in shorthand as '67 land.
Mr. Arafat today harshly criticized violence against Israeli civilians within the 1967 borders. 
"Resisting Israeli occupation and settlements doesn't mean targeting the lives of the Israeli civilians who have no relation at all with occupation and settlement activity," he said through his spokesman. "They are normal people who are living their daily lives, and targeting them is a condemned act ethically and politically."
The effect of such bombings, he said, is to make even "legitimate resistance" look like "blind terrorism."
But while Mr. Arafat has recognized Israel's right to exist, at least within its pre-1967 borders, Hamas and Islamic Jihad have not. In practice, these groups make no distinction among Israelis and have repeatedly shown a determination to kill them without regard to age, occupation or geography.
At the urging of the European Union and Egypt, Mr. Arafat's Fatah faction has been negotiating with Hamas to suspend suicide bombings in pre-1967 Israel, at least during the Israeli election campaign, when such attacks are likely to aid the right wing.
But in a commentary on a Hamas Web site today, Dr. Abdel Aziz Rantisi, a political leader of Hamas, rejected that distinction as well. "I'm shocked at what I hear people keep saying, that the Likud is violent and the Labor is peaceful," he wrote. They are both violent, he said.
In hopes of halting the violence on both sides, the so-called Quartet -- the United States, the United Nations, the European Union and Russia -- is pressing the antagonists to adopt a "road map" toward peace and a Palestinian state in 2005.
Terje Roed-Larsen, the United Nations special envoy here, said Palestinians had diverse views about the violence. He argued that only the prospect of political progress could strengthen those in favor of peace, saying that so far "scores of cease-fire declarations" had yielded only more violence.
"Unless there is a political underpinning, they cannot take hold," he said, "and this is precisely what the work on the Quartet road map takes into account."
The road map is evolving. The Quartet recently added some requirements on both sides, including some that would be hard for Mr. Sharon: Israel would have to express a commitment to an "independent, viable, sovereign" Palestinian state and halt settlement expansion that would interfere with making Palestinian territory contiguous.
But that schedule means that if Mr. Sharon wins the Likud primary, he will be faced with the road map at least a month before elections. 
"Israel would not want to be put in a position where it would have to make specific decisions with regard to that before the situation with Iraq is cleared up," said Zalman Shoval, a Likud politician and Sharon adviser.
Depending on its final shape and timetable, the road map could force Mr. Sharon to make the decision he has so far evaded: choosing among his rightist political base, his averred willingness to make "painful concessions" for peace and his relationship with Mr. Bush.
It could also force Mr. Arafat to make an often-avoided choice between merely condemning killing like today's and trying to stop it. --------------------
