HEADLINE: The Empire Builders 

BYLINE:  By David Nasaw; David Nasaw is a professor of history at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York and the author of "The Chief: The Life of William Randolph Hearst."

 BODY:
 FIRST GREAT TRIUMPH
How Five Americans Made
Their Country a World Power.
By Warren Zimmermann.
Illustrated. 562 pp. New York:
Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $30.
 "AMERICANS like to pretend that they have no imperial past," Warren Zimmermann tells us in "First Great Triumph: How Five Americans Made Their Country a World Power." But they do. The United States had been expanding its borders from the moment of its birth, though its reach had been confined to the North American continent until 1898, when American soldiers and sailors joined Cuban and Filipino rebels in a successful war against Spain. When the war was won, the United States acquired a "protectorate" in Cuba and annexed Hawaii, the Philippine Islands, Guam, Puerto Rico and Hawaii. "In 15 weeks," Zimmermann notes, "the United States had gained island possessions on both the Atlantic and Pacific sides of its continental mass. It had put under its protection and control more than 10 million people: whites, blacks, Hispanics, Indians, Polynesians, Chinese, Japanese and the polyethnic peoples of the Philippine archipelago." 
John Hay, at the time the American ambassador to Britain, writing to his friend Theodore Roosevelt in Cuba, referred to the war against Spain as "a splendid little war, begun with the highest motives, carried on with magnificent intelligence and spirit, favored by that Fortune which loves the brave." He hoped that the war's aftermath would be concluded "with that fine good nature, which is, after all, the distinguishing trait of the American character." More than a century later, we are still asking ourselves just how splendid that little war and its consequences really were. 
Zimmermann, a career diplomat and a former United States ambassador to Yugoslavia, begins his brilliantly readable book about the war and its aftermath with biographical sketches of the five men -- Alfred T. Mahan, Theodore Roosevelt, Henry Cabot Lodge, John Hay and Elihu Root -- who played a leading role in making "their country a world power."
Alfred Mahan, the least known of the group, articulated through his lectures at the Naval War College and his writing the rationale for American overseas expansion, and provided two presidents and their advisers with the military strategy required to achieve it. Theodore Roosevelt, one of Mahan's most enthusiastic readers, was the nation's fiercest proponent of expansionism -- as writer and politician, assistant secretary of the navy, saber-rattling Rough Rider colonel in Cuba, vice president under President William McKinley and president from 1901 to 1909. Henry Cabot Lodge of Massachusetts, Roosevelt's friend and political sponsor, forcefully advocated and carried the case for a larger navy and American expansionism in the Senate. John Hay as secretary of state and Elihu Root as secretary of war under McKinley and then Roosevelt were entrusted with administering the overseas islands acquired after the war with Spain and formulating and advocating a foreign policy consistent with America's new global status. 
What may be most remarkable about these remarkable men, at least from our perspective, is that all of them were "intellectuals and thought of themselves as such." Roosevelt was the author of 38 books, Lodge 27; Hay was the co-author of a biography of Abraham Lincoln, and the author of volumes of poetry and a best-selling novel, "The Breadwinners"; Mahan's books and articles on naval and military history won him election to the presidency of the American Historical Association in 1902; Root, a highly successful corporate lawyer before entering government service, became an expert in international law afterward. 
Zimmermann wisely resists making heroes -- or villains -- of his central characters, though he does show a partiality to Hay and Root, the least arrogant and the most humane of the five in their treatment of America's new overseas possessions and peoples. Both also had sparkling senses of humor, which Zimmermann delights in displaying. When the 325-pound William Howard Taft, who as colonial governor in the Philippines reported to the secretary of war, informed Root that he had recovered from illness and "had just taken a long horseback trip into the mountains . . . Root, always fast with a quip, cabled back: 'Fine. How's the horse?' "
Roosevelt, who plays the leading role in the story, is portrayed the least sympathetically. Though Zimmermann admires his "enormous capacity for work," his "extraordinary mental and physical toughness" and his use of diplomacy as president, he has disdain for Roosevelt's "near-hysterical warmongering over Cuba in the 1890's," his "idiotic assertions that America needed a war" to establish its greatness in 1898 and his relentless campaigning for the Medal of Honor after a total of two weeks' combat experience in Cuba. That President Bill Clinton in 2001 posthumously awarded the medal to Roosevelt, when Roosevelt's own contemporaries felt obligated to deny it to him, is noted without comment. 
After offering five rich biographical sketches, Zimmermann merges the stories of his characters into a historical narrative of the decade of American expansionism that commenced with the war against Spain and ran through the presidency of Theodore Roosevelt. Human rights considerations, he tells us, were put forward by President McKinley in 1898 as the major reason for intervening in Cuba and have been a stated foreign policy priority since then. Still, Zimmermann argues, human rights had precious little to do with American policy toward Hawaii or Guam or Puerto Rico or the Philippine Islands or the Panama Canal Zone. These territories were added to the American empire because of strategic and commercial considerations. The case of Hawaii was perhaps the most egregious. Here, the human rights of the local population were entirely ignored. A functioning government was overthrown and the political rights of the indigenous peoples were trampled to protect American business interests, enhance the power of the local American minority and secure for the Navy a coveted Pacific port. 
Though the advocates of American imperialism, or what Henry Cabot Lodge called the "large policy," won every argument in the end, they did not always have an easy time of it. The treaty ending the war with Spain and ceding the Philippine Islands to the United States was approved by the bare two-thirds vote of the Senate required by the Constitution.
Outside Washington, the anti-imperialist forces were led by a distinguished group that included Andrew Carnegie, Mark Twain and Samuel Gompers, as well as the president of Harvard University, Charles W. Eliot, the Harvard professors William James and Charles Eliot Norton and the publisher, writer, and former United States Senator Carl Schurz. The anti-imperialists argued forcefully that the United States would surrender its birthright by denying self-government to people who desired it. "If we turn this war, which was heralded to the world as a war of humanity, in any sense into a war of conquest, we shall forever forfeit the confidence of mankind," Schurz wrote President McKinley in the spring of 1898. But neither McKinley nor his successor, Theodore Roosevelt, was listening. The course of empire, the fulfillment of America's manifest destiny, had been set, and there was no turning back. America had come of age as a global power, and as such required new markets for goods and investment, naval bases and coaling stations in the Pacific and hegemony in the Caribbean. 
Zimmermann's biographical approach makes for an engaging narrative, though it occasionally obscures the larger structural imperatives, primarily economic, that underlay American expansionism. What Zimmermann never loses sight of, however, are the racial dimensions of his story. "Imperialism is inherently racist," he reminds us. He demonstrates time and again how the American imperialists applied racial arguments to explain why colonial subjects were not worthy of self-government. The hallowed principles of democracy and self-determination, Senator Albert Beveridge of Indiana explained on the floor of the Senate in 1900, did not apply to Filipinos because they were "not of a self-governing race. . . . Savage blood, Oriental blood, Malay blood, Spanish example -- are these the elements of self-government?" 
Reflection on our imperial past and the history of our relations with the rest of the world may well be in order at this moment in our national history. Warren Zimmermann has provided us with an excellent place to begin.

HEADLINE: Benji and Marcella Get Paid 

BYLINE:  By Suzanne Ruta; Suzanne Ruta is the author of "Stalin in the Bronx: And Other Stories."

 BODY:
 A GIRL FROM ZANZIBAR
By Roger King.
307 pp. New York:
Books & Company/Helen Marx Books.
Paper, $14.95.
 WHY isn't that Iraqi doctor practicing medicine? Why is he running a popular cafe in London's Bayswater district? He must be a political refugee, like most of the characters in this timely, entertaining novel about postcolonial migrants trying to survive in Margaret Thatcher's Britain.
The slight time warp adds extra ironies. In mid-1980's London, privatization is still a shocking new tactic. Applied to public housing, it brings windfalls for a few and homelessness for many. AIDS has struck but not yet been identified. The British and the Americans connive with Pakistan's attempts to obtain weapons of mass destruction, the deal financed by a shady international banking network and brokered by a steely Pakistani mercenary whom the Americans invite to train the Nicaraguan contras. He turns them down: he has bigger fish to fry.
These alarming events are filtered through the mind of the title character in Roger King's fourth novel, "A Girl From Zanzibar" -- a naive, ambitious and beautiful young illegal immigrant. Marcella D'Souza is a wonderful invention, a latter-day Candide, an East African on a picaresque voyage of discovery. Her creator specializes in close-up, intimate views of the global economy: the meetings in overheated rooms where the haves decide the fates of the have-nots. He's been in those rooms. As an agricultural economist, he worked for United Nations agencies in Asia and Africa. These days, he lives and teaches in western Massachusetts.
America is not Marcella's land of opportunity; it's where she comes to lie low after her dramatic rise and fall in London. By the time the novel opens, in the late 1990's, she's pushing 40, unmarried, childless, lonely and newly hired to teach multicultural studies at a small college in Vermont. She wonders about her American students. "How can it be that these privileged children of such a big, rich and confident nation are so fragile and lost?" The curriculum is mystifying too. The term "multicultural studies" makes no sense to her, so she promptly revises the course description, arguing that "cultures are just the outcomes of people who moved from somewhere else and would move on" and "nothing is separate, permanent, fixed or owned."
Marcella's life, as she looks back on it, is a case in point. Born from the ruins of three major empires -- the Portuguese, the Arab, the British -- she is, as a friend puts it, a "Goan Indian Portugese Arab African of Catholic Moslem parentage." "You're from everywhere," this friend (an earnest British aid worker who serves as the novel's deus ex machina) tells her. She corrects him: "I'm from nowhere."
Marcella divides this account of her life into sections: "Life Before," "In My Life," "After Life." She doesn't tell her story in chronological order but meanders artfully from then to now and back again, trying to redeem her past, salvage a future. The layering adds depth to a vivid, precise and fast-paced narrative, told with graceful, at times almost arch, concision.
"Life Before" is the nowhere of Marcella's native Zanzibar, waiting for her passport to be granted, arguing with her forceful Aunt Stella, a pillar of the local Goan community. Aunt Stella (or Mrs. F, as she's known), a Dickensian eccentric for sure, insists that Goans are "really Europeans in disguise." "We have European names, some of us have European blood. We've been European for 400 years. We eat beef. We drink alcohol. We ballroom dance. We're European." Naughty Marcella disagrees: "Just because our ancestors were the first to jump into bed with the Portuguese when they arrived in India, doesn't make us European."
This fine comic passage has a grim subtext, since, when independence came to East Africa, Indians and Arabs by the thousands were expelled or killed. Marcella's own father is said to have perished in the massacre that preceded the union of independent Zanzibar with Tanganyika to form Tanzania. Twenty years later, as she prepares to leave the country, violence is still in the air: "The degree of delicacy and tentativeness we brought to our social encounters was that of people tiptoeing among light-sleeping lions."
Marcella makes her getaway at last with the help of a Tanzanian bureaucrat and that well-meaning British aid worker. And the result is a migration from the sorry stagnation of Zanzibar under state socialism to the feeding frenzy of London under rampant capitalism. In Zanzibar, Marcella -- who, like her ancestors, has a head for business -- ran a prosperous ice cream stand. In London, she quickly makes a killing in real estate.
She also finds the love of her life, Benji, an Indian from Singapore who recognizes her at once as a kindred spirit. Not only is their skin the same color, they are, as he puts it, "both godless business Indians with Portuguese names, once displaced and twice removed." Benji is a wonderfully conceived character, the classic middleman, always optimistic, always on the run. ("Debt," he explains, "just proves people trust you.") The only book he owns is his Filofax. He does business out of his car and sleeps in half-built apartments. He has contacts everywhere. But ambition and ego lead him astray.
In the end -- the point is belabored a bit -- all the horrors of Zanzibar, from murder to corruption to terrorism, converge on London too. As we have known from the beginning of the novel, Marcella will go from a life of success to a prison cell, and she'll do it in a single day. Her friends and business associates, even Benji, vanish. She serves an eight-year sentence for a crime she did not commit.
Marcella is the author's mouthpiece, his stage manager, theorizing, summing up the action, signaling transitions, and at times these extra roles blur her outline. But the minor characters are just themselves, seen whole with tragic clarity. Kamara, a political refugee from Sierra Leone, a committed socialist, gradually becomes embroiled in the petty corruption of the government office that employs him. Monique, a beauty from Mauritius, drifts into a soul-destroying marriage with a a kind of modern slave trader. Even that Iraqi doctor, glimpsed now and then unloading a tray of pastries from his car, suggests a painfully reconstructed life.
There is no safe haven, this brilliantly prescient novel suggests, and nothing to hold onto. For better or worse, we are all migrants now.

HEADLINE: Streetscapes/The Queensboro Bridge; 
Spanning the East River, With a Sense of Drama

BYLINE:  By CHRISTOPHER GRAY 

 BODY:
THE Queensboro Bridge, begun in 1901, was one of New York City's most dramatic construction projects. Its vast steel frame is gradually cantilevered out from huge masonry piers across the East River, connecting Manhattan and Queens over Roosevelt -- then known as Blackwell's -- Island. 
 A project to clean and repair the bridge's six colossal stone piers, which were part of its lost network of pedestrian accommodations, is to begin next year. 
 The original plan used a bare-bones design, but after work started, a new commissioner of bridges, the engineer Gustav Lindenthal, hired the architect Henry Hornbostel in 1902 to create structural elements that would be more appropriate for a great public work. Usually, the magazine Architecture observed in 1903, "the engineer makes the design, hands it to the architect to add a lantern or two, makes it fancy, and the artistic conscience of the interested community is at rest." 
But in this case Hornbostel reworked the original, giving it elliptical entrance portals, Art Nouveau-influenced crowning finials and related ornamentation, as well as dome-topped masonry towers. Unlike the city's earlier suspension spans, the Brooklyn and Williamsburg Bridges, the new Blackwell's Island Bridge, as it was first called, was erected by cantilevering steel sections out from support towers on land. 
When Rudolph Knorr, a Cornish-born workman, put in the last rivet at 3:33 p.m. on March 19, 1908, a bottle of champagne was broken over the final beam. 
That September, Queens businessmen petitioned to have the name changed officially to the Queensboro Bridge. The New York Times wrote that influential property owners in Manhattan and Queens objected to the name Blackwell's Island Bridge because certain city buildings on Blackwell's Island made that name "unpleasantly suggestive of a penal institution and a poorhouse."
One businessman, E. J. Rickert, said: "It is distinctly a Queens Borough bridge, and is should have been so designated in the first place." The article did not discuss why the shorter form, Queensboro, was chosen.
But various Irish-American societies opposed the choice of Queensboro, which they thought sounded too British. Bernard McLaughlin, an original promoter of the bridge, said, "There is a deplorable fashion in this country of giving English names to American institutions." He added that the borough of Queens, not the bridge, needed a name change. He suggested "Montauk or some other good American name." 
According to Jeffrey Kroessler, president of the Queensborough Preservation League and author of "New York Year by Year: a Chronology of the Great Metropolis" (N.Y.U. Press, 2002), there is no evidence that Queens, named in 1683 when the province of New York was divided into 10 counties, was named for a particular queen. Some have argued, however, that the borough was named in honor of Catherine of Braganza, who was born in Portugal and married King Charles II of England in 1662.
The Queensboro name -- which had been in occasional use since 1899, before the bridge went up -- won out, and on March 30, 1909, the new $12 million span opened. There were 235 applications from people who sought to be the first to jump from the bridge -- 168 from professional bridge jumpers, 34 from inventors with devices to test, 9 would-be suicides and 24 unemployed men who thought the gesture would improve their chances of work.
They were all disappointed, because the hundreds watching from the roofs and windows of the tenements surrounding the bridge in Manhattan saw it open to a stampede of runners from athletic clubs, of whom the first was Alfred Lehnhardt, 18, of Manhattan and the Olivet Athletic Club. Among the first vehicles across was a farm wagon returning to Queens; a few hours earlier, it had carried produce into Manhattan on the 34th Street ferry. Far below, convicts in the penitentiary on Blackwell's Island pressed their faces to the barred windows of their cells. They had watched the 3,724 1/2-foot-long bridge grow, day by day. 
The bridge design provided for two decks, the upper with two outside footwalks and an interior double rail line to connect with the Second Avenue elevated, the lower with a vehicle roadway and four trolley tracks, including a special shuttle line that, in Manhattan, made a loop under the bridge's plaza on Second Avenue.
Hornbostel was proud of the spiky metalwork on top of the "gaily-capped" steel towers, as he described them in the magazine Architecture in 1909. Their fantastic, slightly sinister wavy shapes in riveted steel evoke Jules Verne's submarine the Nautilus in his book "20,000 Leagues Under the Sea." Traffic on each side of the bridge was disgorged without benefit of any formal plaza, although one of the 18-foot-high bronze lanterns designed by Hornbostel at the Manhattan end has somehow survived the continuous widenings made for increased auto traffic.
In July 1910 a letter in The Times signed "A Constant Reader" complained about a lack of benches for the "hundreds of children with their parents trying for air" on the stifling summer nights, an indication that the bridge was not solely used for vehicles. 
Indeed the two dome-topped anchorages housed elevators and stairs for pedestrians who needed access closer to the shorelines in Queens and Manhattan. A 1916 tally listed 705,000 pedestrians per year, as against 20 million rail passengers and 3.5 million vehicles. In 2000 the yearly tally was 289,000 pedestrians and cyclists, and 66 million vehicles. 
IN 1912 one prisoner tried to add to the pedestrian statistics. David D. Lewis, a clergyman, was at the Blackwell's Island penitentiary serving a one-year term for fraud. Slipping away from a work detail, he used a maintenance cable to clamber up to the bridge deck while under fire from prison guards below. 
But he was captured by two policemen on bicycles. The Times reported that friends of prisoners often dropped food and clothes from the bridge.
Because Manhattan-bound traffic arrived at Second Avenue without the benefit of a grand colonnade like that at the Williamsburg Bridge, a change was proposed in 1913: the demolition of the entire block between 59th and 60th Streets from Second to Third Avenue, and its replacement by a formal garden with temple-like structures camouflaging the elevated lines. But the plan was never realized. 
In 1931, Edward A. MacDougall, a prominent Queens real estate figure, called for another bridge crossing at 86th Street, saying that the saturation level for the Queensboro would be reached in 1937. But some room was made for increased vehicle traffic by adding a series of new approaches, north and south, and ending trolley and elevated service across the bridge. 
In 1960, eight elegant, 70-foot-high flagpoles, part of Hornbostel's design, were removed from the bridge's towers after years of inadequate maintenance. When flags flew from them, it must have been an inspiring sight, but The Times reported that the practice was discontinued after World War II -- it took several hours a day to raise and lower them. 
Now the Department of Transportation is planning a $3 million rehabilitation of the six massive piers in Manhattan and Queens. The project, designed by Walter B. Melvin Architects and Parsons Transportation Group, is to begin next year. In addition to cleaning and repairing the exterior stonework, the interior stairways will be rehabilitated; the elevators were removed long ago. 
A recent visitor walking up the stairs of the white-glazed-brick shaftway at 60th Street in Manhattan alarmed the pigeons who nest there, as well as a couple of friendly homeless men who live peacefully on a mezzanine near the top level, with the traffic roaring past. 
The open iron stairway makes for a giddy ascent, about seven floors high and protected only by light wire caging on one side. But the modern walker in the city will not soon experience it -- the work is being undertaken for the convenience of bridge workers, and the rehabilitated stairways will not be open to the public. 
The narrow bicycle/pedestrian lane on the north side of the bridge's lower deck is not nearly so elegant as the original pair of upper deck pedestrian walks. But even with the deafening traffic, it offers sweeping views to the north and south, with the swirling whorls of the East River far below, and the huge iron matrix of the bridge above.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Left, Queensboro Bridge being built, in 1907; right, bridge in 1909; and below, the bridge today. Flagpoles atop bridge's towers, seen at right, were removed in 1960. (Left, Museum of the City of New York; above, Office for Metropolitan History; below left, Don Hogan Charles/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT; 
Bali Tightens Security To Win Back Tourists

BYLINE:  By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: Kuta, Indonesia 

 BODY:
The sweeping stretches of Bali's beaches sparkle in the sun, and in some places a few hardy tourists mingle with the local fishermen. But mostly, the popular playgrounds of young surfers and backpackers -- outdoor cafes, boutiques and nightclubs -- are virtually empty. 
 The hotels favored by a well-to-do clientele from Europe, the United States and Japan have become the exclusive clubs of some resilient regulars or a few determined honeymooners. In Ubud, the art community in the hills, the jewelry, furniture and clothing stores languish without customers. 
The emotional and economic toll of the Oct. 12 terrorist attack on a disco that killed more than 180 people, most of them tourists, has been tremendous. The mood on the island, known as an enclave of Hindu tranquillity, is strained by the prospects of a bleak economic future. 
 In the last 15 years, the surge in new hotels and shopping malls turned Bali into one of Indonesia's wealthiest areas, but it also made it overwhelmingly dependent on tourism. There are about 800 hotels, and a month after the blast, the occupancy rates in many places were in the single digits, with some managing 15 percent, according to the Bali tourism board, a government agency. Before the blast, occupancy had been about 70 percent. 
 To get tourism back, the major hotels have made some hard-headed decisions. The first, according to Brad Kirk, the general manager of the Bali Hyatt and the spokesman for the Casa Grande, an association of 44 four- and five-star hotels, was not to push for bookings right away. 
 "With the exception of the local market, we are telling our members: zero advertising and zero sales trips until January," Mr. Kirk said. "We think it looks heartless and mercenary to go into the marketplace now." 
 But more important, he said, the hotels wanted to develop what he called credible information about security on Bali. This information -- stressing new security measures at the major hotels -- has been circulated to all Indonesian embassies, foreign embassies in Jakarta and major tour operators, he said. 
 Immediately after the attack, hotels in the group beefed up security. Now, guards stop all vehicles entering the grounds of the 44 hotels, inspect the trunks and interiors of the vehicles and check the undercarriages. All of the five-star and most of the four-star hotels -- including the three Aman resorts, two Sheraton hotels, the two Hyatts, the two Four Seasons, the Ritz-Carlton and the Oberoi -- have gates, Mr. Kirk said. The association's hotels and others have uniformed, armed soldiers and police officers patrolling their properties. 
 At the Hyatt, four armed police officers and four armed soldiers patrol the 36 acres of gardens around the clock. In addition, four undercover military intelligence officers are on 24-hour duty, Mr. Kirk said. Some of the staff from underused divisions have been trained in security and now work as uniformed officers. 
 At the top and middle of the market, Mr. Kirk said, it was unlikely that hotels would cut rates. The problem for Bali, he said, was not the price of rooms but the perception of security. If the next two months are calm, the hoteliers will bring travel agents to Bali to show them that safety was being addressed, he said. 
 Midrange properties, which are particularly popular with Australian tourists, are also struggling. But they were heartened somewhat when the Australian government lifted a specific travel warning on Bali, though it kept a general warning about Indonesia. This followed the Japanese government's easing of its travel warning for Bali on Oct. 26. Other Asian countries, including Singapore, Hong Kong and South Korea, have not issued travel warnings. 
 The Japanese Tour Operators Association, whose members visited Bali after the attack to see the new security measures, have begun promoting it again. This was an important boost because the Japanese -- with about 300,000 arrivals last year -- are the largest group of visitors. One of the demands of the Japanese -- more visible security at the Denpasar airport -- was taken care of by the Balinese government soon after the blast. Armed soldiers and police are now on the tarmac and in the terminal.
 The travel industry here is upset that the United States -- as well as Britain and Australia -- issued a stern travel warning for Indonesia after the attack. The State Department's public announcement says bluntly, "It is clear that U.S. citizens and U.S. interests in Indonesia are at risk." 
 But Bali is now safer than big resorts anywhere, hoteliers contend, arguing that terrorists don't strike the same place twice. American families who live in Jakarta continue to come here for weekends -- as do members of the American Embassy in Jakarta. 
 A big test will be the Christmas season. At the Oberoi, a resort of luxury villas among frangipani and bougainvillea on Legian Beach that has had few guests this month, reservations are coming in for Christmas, according to the general manager, Kamal K. Kaul. So far, there have been no cancellations for Christmas and New Year's.
 Meanwhile, the staff at the main hotels are being asked to take vacations, and those who remain on duty are doing maintenance or receiving extra training.
 Despite the downturn, hoteliers say Bali is resilient. "People love the Balinese," Mr. Kaul said. "I don't think Bali will be abandoned by those who have had a great time here."

HEADLINE: Agents' Survival Strategies 

BYLINE:  By BARRY ESTABROOK; BARRY ESTABROOK is a writer and editor who lives in Vermont.

 BODY:
WHEN reviewing her year-end accounts last January, Amy Powell, co-owner of All Ways Travel, realized that the agency she had operated profitably for 10 years from a Main Street storefront in Valdese, N.C., was in such dire financial straits that going out of business seemed to be inevitable. 
 Revenue was off by more than 20 percent from 2000 levels. Ms. Powell's credit line and overdraft protection were stretched to the limit. A major payment to the agency's bonding company was due in a few weeks or she would have to forfeit her accreditation to sell airline tickets. 
All Ways Travel was being assaulted from all sides. Internet travel service providers such as Expedia, Travelocity.com and Orbitz had eaten into Ms. Powell's business as clients, who used to walk into her plant-filled office to pick up tickets, got them by logging on. Facing a sour economy, her corporate customers spent less time on the road. Commissions from selling airline tickets, which once accounted for 60 percent of her revenue, had dwindled as airlines cut payments to travel agents. (Last March major airlines eliminated virtually all travel agents' commissions for tickets sold in the United States and Canada, although travel agents can still earn commissions by placing a sizable amount of business with a single airline.) The abrupt decline in travel after Sept. 11 administered what looked like the coup de grace. 
 "But bankruptcy wasn't an option for us," said Ms. Powell. "The company was supporting three families: mine, my partner's and the woman who works for us."
 So, with creditors looking over her shoulder, Ms. Powell began reshaping her business. Salaries were cut; hers by 75 percent. Expenses were trimmed. She made a concerted effort to encourage business clients to book their leisure travel through All Ways. And she began to increase service fees to customers.
 "If I'm going to do something for you, I'm not going to do it for free," said Ms. Powell. "Service fees are now in place for everything we do that doesn't yield a commission, whether it is selling an airline ticket, booking a rental car, or making a dinner reservation. We have to nickel-and-dime everyone to death."
 Virtually all members of the American Society of Travel Agents are now charging fees to clients for booking airline tickets, unheard of before 1995, according to William A. Maloney, executive vice president of the society. He said that the average charge was $20 to $25.
 To a greater or lesser extent, every travel agent in the country is facing the same challenges as Ms. Powell, and the industry is struggling to reinvent itself and redefine its role.
 "There is a sea change going on," said Mr. Maloney. "Travel agents for a long time had a monopoly on two things. One was information. They had the airlines' computers. The second thing was documents. If you wanted a ticket, you went to a travel agency. Now they have lost those monopolies. Information is plentiful, and tickets are irrelevant."
 The Airlines Reporting Corporation, which processes the sales of all airline tickets not bought directly through airlines, reported that sales were down by 13 percent for the first nine months of this year compared with the same period in 2001. 
 Another measure of the bad times in the industry is that membership in the American Society of Travel Agents has dropped to 20,000 from 27,000 three years ago, according to Mr. Maloney.
 One casualty was Bristol County Travel Agency in Bristol, R.I., operated for 35 years by Frederico Pacheco. When times were good, the agency had four employees and did about $2 million in business a year, which brought in commissions of $200,000, said Mr. Pacheco, who was a founding member of the Association of Professional Travel Agents.
 "I used to love the travel business. But the airlines cut the commission from 10 percent to 8 percent to 5 percent and then to zero," said Mr. Pacheco. "We tried to charge fees to our customers, but that didn't make up the difference." On April 1, realizing that he was dipping into his savings to keep the agency afloat and seeing no hope of an improved business climate in the future, Mr. Pacheco, who is 67 years old, closed his doors. 
 "The whole product is going through a transition," said Richard Eastman, a travel technology consultant in Newport Beach, Calif. "We are in a state of managing the unknowable, and it will probably take another five to 10 years before a new travel paradigm matures."
 Further change is also predicted by Jon Ash, managing director of the consulting firm Global Aviation Associates, who recently concluded a study for Orbitz, the online travel agency established jointly by United, American, Delta, Northwest and Continental airlines. Mr. Ash concluded that the number of travel agencies in the country, now approximately 24,000, which represents a drop from a high of 32,000 in the mid-1990's, could fall to 15,000 or 20,000 before the current shakeout was over.
 "The structural changes that are taking place in the industry are such that unless you are providing added value for which you can charge the client, you will go by the boards," said Mr. Ash.
 The drive to add value has led to a proliferation of agents who bill themselves as specialists in geographic areas or experts on specific leisure pursuits such as cruises, spa vacations, adventure travel, vegetarian travel and gay and lesbian travel.
 Established specialist agents have not been hit as hard as generalists by commission cuts and by the overall drop in travel. "Business is surprisingly good," said Mollie Fitzgerald, co-owner of Frontiers International Travel. The 34-year-old company, which has 83 employees in offices in Wexford, Pa., and London, derives 80 percent of its business from high-end clients who travel to fish or to shoot game birds. 
 "We feel fortunate that we are associated with specialty interests," said Ms. Fitzgerald. "People who are skittish about travel might defer the family holiday to Europe, but a guy isn't going to miss his annual fishing week in Iceland for love or money. People who are passionate about a sport or pursuit are much more likely to travel in this environment. We feel fortunate that we are not just selling airline tickets."
 Frontiers generates most of its revenue from commissions paid by the lodges and tour operators it represents. It charges customers a service fee of $35 for booking airline tickets on which no commission is paid.
 Some specialist agencies look upon the term "travel agent" as close to a dirty word and refuse to label themselves as such. "The public recognized that travel agents are doing something that can be duplicated on the Internet," said Richard Turen, managing director of Churchill and Turen, Ltd. "We are not a travel agency. We are vacation planning consultants."
 The company, which is based in Naperville, Ill., specializes in culinary vacations and tours. "It's been a very strong summer," said Mr. Turen. "I'm almost uncomfortable saying that we are busy."
 Business is also holding up at Virtuoso, a network of 265 agencies that focus on luxury travel for upscale clients. Matthew D. Upchurch, Virtuoso's chief executive officer, said that he expected that revenue generated by his member agencies this year would be 2 to 5 percent above last year's level.
 "Unfortunately, a lot of traditional travel agents are now trying to extricate themselves from being human vending machines for the airlines," he said. "We're really not so much in the travel business as we are in the life experience business."
 Mr. Upchurch said that most Virtuoso agencies charge their clients fees, but they are often "plan to go" fees that are written off against any commissions the agency receives from tour and cruise operators whose services the client books. Such commissions range from 8 to 15 percent of the cost of the package.
 Some segments of the traditional travel agency business remain strong. "Travel agents still represent 95 percent of the sales of all the cruise lines, 95 percent of the package tours from tour operators and over half of all the car rental days and hotel rooms in the United States, Mr. Maloney of the American Society of Travel Agents said.
 "Airlines would like you to believe that there are only two or three applicable fares between any pair of cities," Mr. Maloney said. "Nothing could be farther from the truth. Consumers need a guide through this jungle." 
 "In the short term you are going to have this chaos," he said. "But the underlying demand for travel during the next 10 years is phenomenal."
 Travel agents who have adapted to the new world are gradually becoming more optimistic. 
 On a Friday afternoon in mid-September, a small celebration took place at All Ways Travel. When she looked at her bank statement for August, Amy Powell saw that for the first time since she reorganized, there was a positive balance in the checking account. "I was dancing in the office," said Ms. Powell. "We could pay off our overdraft. Pay down our credit line. We even gave ourselves a small raise. You know, it's coming around."

HEADLINE: The Commuter Tax: Beyond the Knee-Jerk 

BYLINE:  By VIVIAN S. TOY

 BODY:
ADLINE WILSON takes two buses and then two subways every morning to get from her home in Uniondale to her job as a hospital clerk on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.
 "You do it enough and you don't even think about it anymore," she said while rushing to catch a connection at the Hempstead bus terminal one recent evening. Her commute is two hours each way. 
 Mayor Michael M. Bloomberg's plan to impose a new income tax on commuters, on the other hand, definitely has given her something to think and complain about.
"It'll be a big bite out of my paycheck and I can't afford it," said Mrs. Wilson, who earns only about $30,000 a year and takes the bus because the train is more expensive. "It won't hurt the people on Wall Street. It's the little people like me who are going to feel it the most." 
Governor Pataki and the State Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, oppose the commuter tax plan, dooming it in its current form. Just in case, Long Island legislators have started collecting signatures from riders on the Long Island Rail Road as part of a campaign to make sure the State Legislature does not impose the mayor's plan on the 265,000 Long Islanders who work in New York City.
But officials and policy analysts have speculated that the Bloomberg proposal is a bargaining ploy intended to get state officials to approve a smaller, more defensible, commuter tax.
Mr. Bloomberg's proposal would extend the city's income tax to commuters, producing a tax that is roughly six times higher than the commuter tax that state officials eliminated with great fanfare three years ago. Under the proposed tax, a Long Islander who makes about $100,000 a year in New York City would pay about $2,100 a year, or about $9 a day -- a considerable sum when added to the cost of commuting.
While Mayor Bloomberg and his supporters argue that the debate should focus on how much in city services a commuter consumes, Long Island officials counter that commuters pour millions, if not billions, of dollars into the city's economy each year and that those contributions should not be ignored.
Fiscal experts are just as divided on the subject. Some say the proposed income tax would drive jobs out of the city and ultimately might hurt not just the city's economy, but that of the entire region. Others reason that some form of a commuter tax is justifiable, but say Mr. Bloomberg's plan to tax commuters and residents at the same rate is not.
While Mr. Bloomberg insists that "nothing could be fairer" than having commuters pay for their services, city officials have not produced any figures to show how much commuters actually cost the city in added services. But a study done by an economics professor at Hunter College, Howard Chernick, concludes that commuters cost the city between $1.2 billion and $1.9 billion a year in additional city services, or between $1,480 and $2,343 per commuter.
That would suggest that Mayor Bloomberg's proposal is not that unreasonable. But Dr. Chernick maintained that while his study shows that commuters do in fact cost the city money, they should not be expected to pay the same rate as residents since they do not consume the same level of services. He endorsed the reinstatement of the old commuter tax of 0.45 percent, which cost the commuter with a $100,000 salary about $400 a year. When revenues from a commuter tax like the previous one of 0.45 percent are added to the sales taxes paid by commuters for meals, shopping and services bought in the city, and the business taxes that employers already pay for each job, he said, the tax revenue estimate from each commuter job adds up to $2,253 -- a number that falls right within his commuter cost estimate. 
"It's justified on the grounds of equity and efficiency," Dr. Chernick said of the 0.45 percent commuter tax. "It's equitable because it taxes workers who tend to be higher-income people, and it's efficient because not having the tax gives commuters a free ride and makes it easier for people to take jobs in the city and move to the suburbs."
Pearl M. Kamer, the chief economist for the Long Island Association, said Mr. Bloomberg's proposed tax would hurt individual taxpayers and therefore "would be a significant drag on the Long Island economy because it would affect consumer spending."
Dr. Kamer said the proposed income tax "would negate the LIPA rebate and a whole lot of other things because it would erode the disposable income of Long Islanders." She was referring to the rebate and cut in electrical rates that Long Islanders received in 1998 when the Long Island Power Authority was created to replace the Long Island Lighting Company.
In the short run, she said, Long Island might benefit from the tax as some commuters might choose to leave their jobs in the city for ones on the Island and some businesses might move to the suburbs. But she said the tax ultimately could hurt the whole region. 
"The health of New York City's economy is essential to Long Island's economic health," she said. "But by the same token, New York City is dependent on the skills of Long Island residents and other suburbanites, and if the city loses those skills, it could lose that base. That base might shift to the suburbs, but we also run the risk that it might leave for other regions entirely."
James A. Parrott, the chief economist at the Fiscal Policy Institute, a labor-backed research group, said, however, that as upset as many commuters may be by a tax, workers and their jobs were unlikely to head for the suburbs. The institute studied the economic relationship of suburb to city and found that between 1991 and 1998, Long Island had become more dependent on the city for jobs.
In Nassau County, commuter wages of $8.6 billion in 1991 accounted for 49 percent of total wages earned by county residents. By 1998, the figure had grown to $12.7 billion, or 56 percent. Suffolk County's reliance was lower, but also grew from $3.1 billion or 22 percent of total wages to $4.6 billion or 23 percent.
"The importance of commuter wages to the suburban economy grew substantially in the 1990's," he said, noting that the shift was due in part to Long Island's loss of some 50,000 jobs in the aerospace and defense industries in the late 1980's and early 1990's.
Mr. Parrott also pointed out that commuters tend to work at higher-paying jobs, particularly in the financial sector, which accounts for a remarkable 76 percent rise in total commuter wages between 1991 and 1998, going from $35.9 billion to $63.1 billion. Total wages for city residents, by contrast, increased by only 40 percent.
"A commuter tax is not going to result in droves of people quitting their city jobs," he said. "In this economy, in recession with no upturn in sight? You've got to be kidding."
But even if the jobs and the commuters stay where they are, the Nassau County executive, Thomas R. Suozzi, has argued against the commuter tax on the grounds that the city should not pit city against suburb. Both the city and Nassau County have been hurt by the slowing economy and by the need to shoulder increased Medicaid burdens, and Mr. Suozzi's spokesman, Bruce Nyman, argued that together they should push for a change in the Medicaid funding system.
"The answer isn't a commuter tax or a Long Island tax," Mr. Nyman said. "There needs to be a statewide answer for the problems of the city, Nassau County, Westchester and all the other local municipalities."
Unlike New Jersey officials who have called for new taxes on commuters to their state, Mr. Suozzi opposes any retaliatory tax on the tens of thousands of city residents who commute to Long Island. "What's next then, setting up moats and gates?" Mr. Nyman said. "We need to work together."
E. J. McMahon, a senior fellow at the Manhattan Institute, a conservative policy research center, agreed that commuters should not be subject to any commuter tax, mainly because the city already heavily taxes employers in the form of business income taxes and commercial rent tax. "All those taxes are designed to tap into the stream of wealth generated by workers," he said. "So businesses already are paying many times over for the services their people are consuming."
Mr. McMahon also said that commuters use very few city services, mainly just those of the police and fire departments. Large portions of the city budget are dedicated to the school system and welfare programs, which do not benefit commuters at all, he added.
But Dr. Chernick said commuters benefit indirectly from maintaining the city's quality of life, including services to the poor. "Things like traffic, environmental protection and sanitation, these are all services that make the city an orderly place and that's consumed by everybody who comes here," he said.
Mr. McMahon also contended that commuters already pay for their share of city services through their huge contribution to the city's economy and the sales taxes generated from their spending. He estimated that commuters easily pour several billion dollars into the city each year and calculated that even with a daily expenditure of about $5 a day, the city's 800,000 commuters would easily spend more than $1 billion. "And that's not taking into account the special occasions, dinner and theater or season tickets to the Rangers," he said. "Commuters do a lot of these things because they're already here, and a lot of that would vanish if they were back in Mineola or White Plains."
Edward Shannon, who commutes to Lower Manhattan from Garden City for his job as a money broker, said he sees the city at large "as kind of like an extended office for me." He has breakfast meetings around town, rides the subway to get around and buys all kinds of supplies for home and office while he's there.
A few years ago, he might have taken a tougher position against the commuter tax, he said, but watching the city suffer through Sept. 11 and its aftermath has changed his perspective somewhat.
"Do I want to pay a commuter tax? Absolutely not," he said. "But I understand the mayor's got to get the money from somewhere and if he a needs a few dollars, I don't have a problem with it."

HEADLINE: IN BUSINESS; 
The Commuter Tax Debate

BYLINE:  By VIVIAN S. TOY 

 BODY:
AS soon as Janet Morgan heard about Mayor Michael M. Bloomberg's plan to impose a new income tax of up to 2.7 percent on commuters, she did the math to figure out what it would cost her. The results weren't pretty.
 The figures "are kind of crazy," said Ms. Morgan, who commutes to New York City from Dobbs Ferry where she lives as a single mother with three children, who will all be in private school next year. "What I might pay in New York City income tax is what it costs to send my son to Catholic school," she said. Finding money to pay the commuter tax and the proposed 28.6 percent property tax increase for Westchester "will be very difficult for me," she said. 
 Elected officials from Westchester and other suburban communities have zealously joined the debate on behalf of Ms. Morgan and the more than 103,000 other Westchester residents who make the trek to New York City for the sake of a job. Westchester County Executive Andrew J. Spano said Mr. Bloomberg's plan was misguided and warned, "We don't want to start a border war." New Jersey legislators have gone even further and threatened to devise retaliatory taxes on commuters to New Jersey. 
While Mayor Bloomberg and his supporters argue that the debate should focus on how much in city services a commuter consumes, Westchester officials counter that commuters pour millions, if not billions, of dollars into the city's economy each year and that those contributions should not be ignored.
Fiscal experts are just as divided on the subject. Some say that the proposed income tax would drive jobs out of the city and ultimately might hurt not just the city's economy, but that of the entire region. Others reason that some form of a commuter tax is justifiable, but say that Mr. Bloomberg's plan to tax commuters and residents at the same rate is not. Officials and policy analysts have speculated that the proposal is a bargaining ploy, designed to get state officials to approve a smaller, more defensible, commuter tax.
The mayor's proposal would extend the city's income tax to commuters, a tax that would be roughly six times higher than the commuter tax that state officials eliminated with great fanfare three years ago. Under the proposed tax, an average commuter, who makes about $100,000 a year, would pay about $2,100 a year, or about $9 a day.
While Mr. Bloomberg insists that "nothing could be fairer" than having commuters pay for city services, city officials have not produced any figures to show how much commuters actually cost the city in added services. But a 2001 study by an economics professor at Hunter College, Dr. Howard Chernick, concludes that commuters cost the city between $1.2 billion and $1.9 billion a year in additional services, or between $1,480 and $2,343 per commuter. 
That would suggest that Mr. Bloomberg's proposal is not that unreasonable. But Dr. Chernick maintained that while his study shows that commuters do in fact cost the city money, they should not be expected to pay the same rate as residents since they do not consume the same level of services. He endorsed the reinstatement of the old commuter tax of .45 percent, which cost the average commuter with a $100,000 salary about $400 a year. When revenues from a commuter tax like the previous one of .45 percent are added to the business taxes that employers already pay for each job, he said, the tax revenue estimate from each commuter job adds up to $2,253 -- a number that falls within his commuter cost estimate. 
Marsha Gordon, the president of the Westchester Chamber of Commerce, said, however, that Westchester does not tax the 50,000 people who commute from the city to Westchester. "So to tax Westchester residents who commute into the city is unfair," she said. "It does not help the causes of either quality of life or inter-regional cooperation."
Mr. Spano agreed and said that if the proposed tax thinned the ranks of commuters to the city and resulted in companies looking elsewhere to relocate, he would not want to see Westchester gain at the city's expense. "Getting business from the city is never good under any circumstance," he said. "We're partners." 
James A. Parrott, the chief economist at the Fiscal Policy Institute, a labor-backed research group, said that as upset as many commuters may be by a commuter tax, workers and their jobs were unlikely to head for the suburbs. The institute studied the economic relationship of suburb to city and found that between 1991 and 1998, the last year of the tax, Westchester had become much more dependent on the city for jobs.
Commuter wages in Westchester grew to $11.1 billion in 1998, or 65 percent of total wages earned by county residents, from $5.8 billion in 1991, or roughly 45 percent of total wages. "The importance of commuter wages to the suburban economy grew substantially in the 1990's," he said, noting that the shift in Westchester was due in part to downsizing in the mid-1990's, which led to high office vacancy rates in the county.
Mr. Parrott also said that commuters tend to work at higher paying jobs, particularly in the financial sector, which accounts for a remarkable 76 percent increase in total commuter wages between 1991 and 1998, going to $63.1 billion from $35.9 billion. Total wages for city residents, by contrast, increased by only 40 percent.
"A commuter tax is not going to result in droves of people quitting their city jobs," he said. "In this economy, with no upturn in sight? You've got to be kidding."
BUT even if the jobs and the commuters stay where they are, Mr. Spano argued against the commuter tax, saying it would wrongly pit city against suburb. Both the city and Westchester have been hurt by the slowing economy and by the need to shoulder increased Medicaid burdens and other state-mandated programs. "The state is putting too much of a load on the city and counties," he said. "It's an Albany tax problem, not a Bloomberg tax problem and not a Spano tax problem."
E. J. McMahon, a senior fellow at the Manhattan Institute, a conservative policy group, agreed that commuters should not be subject to any income tax, mainly because the city already heavily taxes businesses in the form of business income taxes and commercial rent tax. "All those taxes are designed to tap into the stream of wealth generated by workers," he said. "So businesses already are paying many times over for the services its people are consuming."
He also said that commuters use very few city services, mainly just those of the police and fire departments. Large portions of the city budget are dedicated to the school system and welfare programs, which do not benefit commuters, he said.
But Dr. Chernick reasoned that maintaining the city's quality of life through services to the poor and through the general administration of the city benefits commuters indirectly. "Things like traffic, environmental protection and sanitation, these are all services that make the city an orderly place and that's consumed by everybody who comes here," he said.
Mr. McMahon also contended that commuters already pay for their share of city services through their huge contribution to the city's economy and the sales tax generated from their spending. He estimated that even with a daily expenditure of about $5 a day, the city's 800,000 commuters would easily spend more than $1 billion. "And that's not taking into account the special occasions, dinner and theater or season tickets to the Rangers," he said. "Commuters do a lot of these things because they're already here and a lot of that would vanish if they were back in Mineola or White Plains."
Still, there are some commuters like Eric Sweeting, from Hastings-on-Hudson, who believe that the new tax actually makes sense.
"I think it's fair," said Mr. Sweeting, who works for a social service agency in the city. "When they repealed the commuter tax, I thought it was irresponsible. If suburban commuters make their living in the city and bring their paychecks back out, it's just not unreasonable to ask them to pay."
He for one doesn't buy into the prediction that the tax will drive people out of the city. "That's the first thing that rolls off people's tongues, but the fear is exaggerated," he said. "There's not a municipality in America that doesn't face a tax increase."

HEADLINE: Top Picks: Mazda, VW, Honda, Nissan 

 BODY:
 After evaluating nine midsize sedans, contributors to these pages picked their favorites, least favorites and what they found most surprising. Here is what they said:

James G. Cobb, editor of the Automobiles pages for The New York Times:

PICK -- I drove the Mazda6 500 miles to Ohio, then made a 10-hour dash to upstate New York. After all that time at the wheel I had no complaints, which is rarely the case, though I'd have preferred the optional V-6 to the just-adequate 4 in the test car. I like the Mazda's style, its suspension and even its seats, controls and stereo. It's a good car, and with more power it could be a great one.

PAN -- The Optima looks good on paper, and it dazzles you with a lot of features for its price. But when you drive it back to back with the competition, you quickly realize that the Kia's chassis, transmission and overall refinement don't yet measure up.

SURPRISE -- Under its homely skin, the Impala has great bones, with an eager engine, a capable suspension and decent handling. The Chevy felt bigger, plusher and more substantial than some of the other cars. To my surprise, I preferred it to the mushy Camry.

Cheryl Jensen, a Cleveland freelance writer who often writes for these pages:

PICK -- The Mazda6 is not just entertaining to drive, it has room for a four-member family and more trunk space than the Accord, my third choice. It is more nimble than the Passat, my second choice, probably because it is more than 200 pounds lighter, and the body motions are more tightly controlled.

PAN -- The Taurus is proof that Ford is putting its resources into sport utilities.

SURPRISE -- The Mazda6 steers and handles better than the Passat. It's the most fun I'd had in a Mazda since the Miata.

Michelle Krebs, a Detroit area auto writer whose car reviews have appeared in these pages since 1994:

PICK -- I'm tired of boring interiors. The Mazda6 has a beautiful cabin inside its attractive skin. The car has spirit, too. Mazda engineers have magically made a front-drive family car feel like a rear-drive sport sedan.

PAN -- The company saved by the Taurus has invested no money to keep the car fresh. Ford executives say Americans want S.U.V.'s, not cars, but if they built a great midsize family sedan, people might buy it.

MOST SUPRISING -- The Impala performed better than I expected. Too bad it is so ugly.

Bob Knoll, who retired in 1997 after 32 years as Consumer Reports' auto testing director and is now a Connecticut freelancer:

PICK -- Although the Passat was my top-scoring car by a close margin, largely because of its well-balanced chassis, the car I would buy is the Altima. In my judgment, it is the best-rounded, because it combines contemporary styling inside and out with a roomy and useful body. The rather large four-cylinder engine responds well, works well with the automatic transmission and delivers fuel economy on par with the other four-cylinders'. The Altima handles crisply, responds well and is fun to drive. To top it off, it was the least expensive car in the test.

PAN -- One looks at the Optima and sees a V-6 engine, leather seats and bells and whistles. One does not see the clumsy, heavy handling or the mediocre ride. The Kia's V-6 should outpower the 4's in this group, but it feels weak, and the transmission has trouble matching the engine's requirements. This car needs a lot of development to catch the others, and it needs to lose 300 pounds.

SURPRISE -- The Camry's ride and handling were disappointing on secondary roads --roads that the three domestic sedans handled with aplomb. The Camry feels too much like an older American car, especially compared with the crisp-handling Passat, Mazda6, Altima and Accord.

Dan Lienert, a New York City freelance writer who graduated from Harvard University this year:

PICK -- The Accord isn't as cheap as the Camry and it doesn't look as nice as the Passat, but thanks to a great ride, the most sophisticated interior and a sleek body design, the Accord seems the most comfortable with itself. After all these years, it should.

PAN -- The Intrepid swims in vague steering and throttle responses and gets relatively poor gas mileage. It looks bloated from behind. Its cabin lacks storage compartments, and there's no escaping the plastic interior.

SURPRISE -- The elder statesman from Detroit, the Taurus, has fossilized, but the Accord looks fresher than ever -- fresher, indeed, than anything else out there.

Keith Martin, editor and publisher of Sports Car Market magazine in Portland, Ore., who writes about sports and collector cars for The Times:

PICK -- The Mazda6 was unremarkable, even somewhat underpowered, on the freeway. But when driven aggressively, its drivetrain, suspension and ergonomics came together to make it easily the best all-round car in the group.

PAN -- With Olds fading out, perhaps the Camry can stand in as a squishy-handling replacement. You used to expect Toyotas to feel crisp, but the Camry has turned into a wallowing, pseudo-American sedan.

SURPRISE -- I didn't like the Passat unless I was thrashing it to within an inch of its mechanical life. At that point, its Teutonic solidity and composure put it at a different performance level than the other cars.

Mark Phelan, a Michigan writer (who recently joined The Detroit Free Press):

PICK -- The Passat's small engine struggled to power a car of its size, but other virtues overcame that shortcoming. The Passat has a gorgeous interior, styling that has aged well, crisp steering and excellent handling. The cabin is a little cramped, but the VW we tested was a lot of car for $23,725.

PAN -- The first-generation Taurus redefined the American sedan and saved the Ford Motor Company. It is a shame that Ford has allowed the Taurus to age so gracelessly.

SURPRISE -- Who'd have thought that the Intrepid, a car destined for replacement within a year, would hold up so well in such tough competition? The styling is still fresh, though I could do without the test car's rear spoiler. The V-6 has plenty of power, and the handling was amazingly fluid for such a large car. On the other hand, the interior was among the worst, with big gaps, poor materials and prehistoric switches.

HEADLINE: Itching to Rebuild the Tax Law 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
TAX experts from universities and research institutes have trooped into Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill's spacious office for months now. Some come to feed his passion for overhauling the tax code, others to temper it. Some come bearing specific plans for achieving his ambitious goal, others with advice based on long experience in the political trenches, where the idea of making the tax code simpler, fairer and more economically efficient is as perilous as it is alluring.
 In the next month or two, Mr. O'Neill is expected to distill the thinking of outside economists and his staff, along with the strong personal views on the tax code's flaws that he developed as chief executive of Alcoa, into prototypes for entirely remaking the tax system and for substantially simplifying it. Those options, in turn, will guide President Bush as he decides whether and how to take on what would be one of the most ambitious projects of his presidency and a possible centerpiece of his 2004 re-election campaign platform. 
 If the administration moves ahead -- all indications suggest that it will proceed cautiously -- it will be opening the door to a furious ideological battle, inflamed by interest groups. 
The ensuing debate would focus on fundamental issues like whether the wealthy should pay taxes at higher rates than lower-income people. It would challenge the practice of using the tax code to encourage certain types of behavior and to discourage others. It would test the administration's commitment to help big business at a time when corporate scandals have made it politically tricky to do so.
It would also threaten -- or promise -- to undo the tangled mass of tax breaks won by lobbyists over the decades for particular industries, companies and individuals. And it would present immense practical obstacles, not least finding a way to shift from one system to another without unduly disrupting a $10 trillion-a-year economy.
"This is the ultimate Washington insiders-versus-America issue," said Stephen Moore, president of the Club for Growth, a conservative political action committee that supports changing the tax system. "Washington derives so much of its power from the tax code -- not just congressmen on the Ways and Means Committee, but lobbyists and lawyers. You're taking on the whole Washington establishment, from real estate to municipal bond traders to accounting firms, charitable groups and so on down the line. It becomes a battle royal."
The tax agenda is already crowded. Mr. Bush is pushing hard for Congress to make permanent the 10-year, $1.35 trillion tax cut enacted last year. He may also propose new tax cuts early next year intended to lift the economy in the short run, steps like reducing the taxes paid on stock dividends, giving companies tax breaks on investment in equipment and accelerating the personal income tax cuts passed last year.
BUT Lawrence B. Lindsey, Mr. Bush's chief economic policy adviser, said in a speech this month that before they are put forward, even those measures will be assessed to see if they would be consistent with the goal of rethinking the tax code. 
The last tax overhaul took place in 1986. After two years of debate and intense behind-the-scenes deal making, the Reagan administration and Congress settled on a bipartisan package that cut rates and simplified the code a bit in return for eliminating some tax breaks. 
But that effort was modest compared with what will be on the table this time.
Since the mid-1980's, the closest thing to a national discussion of a new tax system came in 1996, when Steve Forbes made a single-rate flat tax the centerpiece of his candidacy for the Republican presidential nomination. When his campaign fizzled, the issue all but disappeared.
The administration has not yet decided how to present the issue to voters this time around. After promising this fall to deliver his ideas to Mr. Bush after the election, Mr. O'Neill has gone silent on the topic, and Treasury officials said there was no timetable for completing the study. White House officials have been studying various proposals on their own.
Proponents of change, most but not all of whom are on the right, say the present tax code hurts the economy. They say it imposes huge costs on individuals and businesses as they fill out forms, keep their books and deal with legal and financial issues; discourages savings and investment; and encourages companies and individuals to shelter income in sometimes questionable or illegal ways.
"Our tax code is an abomination, and it hurts our competitiveness," Mr. O'Neill said in a speech to a business group this summer. "This nation deserves a better tax code, and I believe we can achieve it." 
Behind most of the proposals is a basic philosophy: shifting from a system of taxing income to one that taxes consumption -- another way of saying that savings and investment should be exempt from taxes. In theory, promoting more savings and investment by eliminating taxation of capital gains and dividends, for example, would make the economy more productive in the long run. It would increase the pool of capital available for research, new technologies, more efficient factories and better educated and trained workers.
The changes would also address longstanding complaints among businesses and individuals that the tax code is too complex and the Internal Revenue Service too intrusive and intimidating.
Mr. O'Neill talks mainly about the corporate income tax, which raises about 10 percent of the $2 trillion in federal revenue each year. He has long derided it as a barrier to international competitiveness and rational business decision making.
Much more political attention would no doubt be paid to individual income taxes, which raise about $1 trillion a year at the federal level.
Most of the possible changes assume that the goal is neither to reduce the government's overall tax receipts nor to increase them. One approach would tax households at a flat single rate, estimated to be as low as 18 percent and as high as 33 percent. Another would replace the income tax with a national sales tax, probably at least 23 percent; a variant would be a European-style value-added tax levied at every point in the distribution chain. Another strategy would retain progressive multiple rates for individuals but replace the corporate income tax with a value-added tax.
Critics of change fall into two camps. Some object to specific proposals that would harm their interests. The idea of eliminating the mortgage interest deduction, for example, has drawn fire from the housing industry and homeowners. Getting rid of the child credit would no doubt provoke a backlash from families and from social conservatives who have championed its expansion.
More generally, many liberals say that recent tax-overhaul proposals are thinly disguised efforts to benefit the wealthy at the expense of the poor and the middle class. They note that nearly all the proposals move away from the progressive tax system, which taxes higher incomes at higher rates, and toward systems that ultimately cut taxes for wealthy people more than for anyone else. Not only would income tax rates come down for big earners, but most proposals would also eliminate other taxes paid largely by the wealthy, like the capital gains tax, long a target of Republicans.
Conservatives "believe, or have been influenced to believe, that light taxes on the wealthy, or no taxes on the wealthy, are the key to prosperity," said Robert S. McIntyre, director of Citizens for Tax Justice, a liberal research organization.
Some Democrats, like Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, a likely presidential candidate in 2004, think that the issue, properly framed, could be a winner for their party. But even if the left-right differences over the need for a new system could be resolved, advocates of fundamental change differ sharply over what it should look like.
Advocates of a national sales tax say that only their proposal would eliminate the need for the Internal Revenue Service. Flat-tax advocates say their proposal is much more workable and can be made fairer to low-income people than can a sales tax.
With Republicans now in control of both the House and the Senate, and Mr. Bush, a proponent of change, in the White House, the stars are better aligned to put the issue at center stage. But even the most enthusiastic advocates of change say it will not be easy, especially if industries that perceive themselves as losers mount aggressive lobbying efforts.
"It's going to take an enormous investment of political capital on the part of the president to build grass-roots support," said Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who was chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee for six years before retiring from Congress two years ago.
WITH Mr. Bush confronting the likelihood of a war with Iraq, the continued threat of terrorist attacks and a soft economy, tax reform is not his highest priority. Lobbyists and economists in Washington assume that he will raise the issue in his State of the Union address in January, then spend a year or two promoting the principle without backing a specific proposal or pushing for legislative action.
"I don't see this as an immediate issue," said R. Glenn Hubbard, chairman of the White House Council of Economic Advisers, who favors changing the system. "The president obviously has very many things on his mind at the moment." 
But in an effort to push the effort forward, Mr. O'Neill has been canvassing leading tax thinkers like Joel B. Slemrod of the University of Michigan, David F. Bradford of Princeton, Michael J. Graetz of Yale, Ronald A. Pearlman of Georgetown and Alan J. Auerbach of the University of California at Berkeley.
The best-known approach is the flat tax, which has had prominent champions like Mr. Forbes and Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the Republican majority leader who is retiring from Congress.
In its purest form, the flat tax would look much like a single-rate income tax, at least to individuals. But it would actually be a tax on consumption, because it would exclude savings and investment. 
It would meld a value-added tax on business to a flat tax at the same rate on individual wage and pension income. Other types of income, like capital gains, dividends and interest, would be exempt from taxation.
But because the rate must be at least 20 percent, and probably higher, to raise the same revenue as the current tax system, it would amount to a tax increase for many people now subject only to the 10 and 15 percent rates. So most flat-tax proposals include a large exemption that would push many households off the tax rolls entirely. Mr. Armey's plan, for example, proposed a $35,000 exemption for a family of four.
Other tax proposals apply some of the flat tax's principles. Mr. Bradford's "X-tax," for one, would levy multiple rates on individuals and a value-added tax on businesses.
Mr. Graetz has developed a plan that would place a value-added tax on businesses and consumers and use the revenue to cut the corporate income tax as well as remove all households with incomes below $100,000 from the individual tax rolls.
The option least likely to be adopted by the administration is a national sales tax, a bigger version of the retail tax already levied by 45 states.
THE best known sales-tax proposal is one promoted by Leo E. Linbeck Jr., a wealthy Texas construction executive. His plan, which he calls the Fair Tax, would replace both the income tax and the payroll taxes that go to Social Security and Medicare. It says a revenue-neutral sales tax would be 23 percent.
Other economists said that the actual figure would need to be at least 30 percent and that a sales tax of those levels would lead to a thriving underground economy as buyers sought to avoid the tax.
Moreover, critics say, the burden would fall hardest on low-income people who spend everything they earn. The proposal would try to get around the problem of fairness by rebating taxes on purchases up to an amount equal to the poverty line.
If complete code revision is impossible, Congress and the administration are all but certain to address a few pressing problems in the current system. 
The biggest looming issue is the alternative minimum tax. It was created to ensure that high-income taxpayers would not be able to escape taxation by sheltering their income. But the income thresholds at which it kicks in are not indexed for inflation, and more and more middle-class taxpayers become subject to it every year, requiring them to make complex calculations and pay a higher tax than under the regular income tax.
A study this year by the Tax Policy Center, a joint venture of the Brookings Institution and the Urban Institute, found that the number of taxpayers subject to the alternative minimum tax would swell to 36 million by the end of the decade from several million this year.
Both parties see that as a ticking time bomb. But eliminating the problem would be expensive, perhaps prohibitively so; estimates run into the hundreds of billions of dollars in the next decade.
The administration has also signaled that it is intent on simplifying the current tax code if it cannot replace it. Citing an example of what he has often called the tax system's monstrous complexity, Mr. O'Neill noted earlier this year that there are five different definitions of "child" in the tax code; cutting it to one, he suggested, would be a good place to start a broader effort at simplification.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill is considering plans to redo the tax code, last overhauled in 1986.
