HEADLINE: Washington Insider, But Wall St. Pariah 

BYLINE:  By PATRICK McGEEHAN 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO 

 BODY:
BY almost any measure, Charles R. Schwab should be a hero on Wall Street. He made himself a billionaire a few times over by starting a brokerage firm and building it into a financial powerhouse whose low-priced Internet trading service helped fuel the boom of the late 1990's.
 This year, as disillusioned investors fled the market, it was Mr. Schwab who planted ideas with President Bush that might bring them back. At least among politicians in Washington, he is receiving credit for proposals to reduce taxes on dividends and to increase the allowable deductions for investment losses, measures that have taken root with some Republican lawmakers and that may well blossom into breaks for investors next year. 
 But despite his impressive resume and close connection to the Bush administration, Mr. Schwab is less popular than ever among his peers. He may be even more disliked on Wall Street than Eliot Spitzer, the attorney general of New York, who has vilified investment bankers, stock analysts and the executives who employ them. 
Some senior executives of other brokerage firms cannot contain their rage at the mere mention of Mr. Schwab's name. His repeated denouncements of the conflicts of interest at other big brokerage firms and his more-ethical-than-thou pronouncements have fanned the flames. When the microphones are turned off, top officials of competing firms call Mr. Schwab's behavior "disingenuous" at best, "parasitic" at worst.
If Mr. Schwab, 65, were to retire now -- he said last week that he had no intention of quitting anytime soon -- he might be remembered most by his competitors not for his accomplishments but for a single phrase: "Let's put some lipstick on this pig."
An actor portraying a Wall Street manager uttered that line in a television commercial that Schwab started broadcasting last spring; the manager was exhorting brokers to sell a weak stock to unsuspecting investors. The ad appeared just as Mr. Spitzer was making hash of Merrill Lynch's reputation by releasing embarrassing e-mail messages written by some of the firm's analysts. One of the messages referred to a recommended stock as a "dog."
Schwab, which does not underwrite stocks, stopped using that commercial last month, but the anger it generated persists.
"It was, frankly, a cheap shot," said James P. Gorman, who runs Merrill Lynch's brokerage operation. "There's a basic principle that you don't kick somebody when they're down. They violated that principle and they're getting a lot of heat over it."
The unique dual role Mr. Schwab plays -- a Mr. Inside-Mr. Outside of the financial world -- has placed him squarely in the spotlight as lawmakers and regulators struggle to find ways to rebuild faith in the American financial markets. But there is a subplot: Mr. Schwab's stature as a guru of democratic markets may have risen, but his stock as a visionary manager of his own company has sunk.
THOUGH not tainted by the conflicts of interest plaguing its competitors that own investment banks, the Charles Schwab Corporation is in financial distress. Even after its third round of companywide layoffs, Schwab reported a net loss of $4 million last quarter, when most big securities firms were able to squeeze profits out of the depressed financial markets. Last week, one analyst downgraded the company's shares, saying they were worth about 30 percent less than their current price of $11.70 because its prospects were "lackluster."
Some Wall Street executives have dismissed Mr. Schwab's criticism of them as the lashings of a competitor whose bull-market business model, largely dependent on individual investors, is failing in a prolonged slump. But in an interview in his office in San Francisco last week, Mr. Schwab said the outbursts aimed at him were misdirected.
"If they took the same energy and put it into the correction process, we'd be a lot further ahead today than being in denial," he said. "To this moment, I don't know of any grand mea culpa by our industry to say we've made a mistake, a bunch of mistakes, and we're now going to clean them all up and go forward so you can feel confident coming back and doing business with us." 
In letters this fall to President Bush and Harvey L. Pitt, the departing chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Schwab proposed a code of conduct for the top executives of financial services companies. He recommended that they be required to certify periodically that conflicts of interest had not motivated their employees to put the interests of corporate clients ahead of those of individual customers.
Mr. Pitt praised Mr. Schwab this month in a speech before Wall Street executives at their annual convention in Boca Raton, Fla. Speaking for the first time since announcing his resignation three days before, Mr. Pitt said Mr. Schwab had "laid out some thoughtful proposals." He mentioned no other industry officials.
John H. Schaefer, who preceded Mr. Pitt on the podium that morning, had trouble suppressing some less-charitable views, however. 
Mr. Schaefer, president of Morgan Stanley's Individual Investor Group, had written a speech that included a few shots at Mr. Schwab and his company -- "Enough is enough, Chuck" was one. But his advisers convinced him that those remarks would be inappropriate for an audience that included Schwab executives. Still, minutes before Mr. Schaefer stepped to the lectern, he reinserted one of those cracks and handed the revised text to the teleprompter operator. 
In his speech, Mr. Schaefer said investors were "at a time of intense dissatisfaction that will not quickly disappear," then added that he thought "commercials like 'Let's put lipstick on these pigs' " did more harm than good for efforts to restore investor confidence.
Mr. Schwab said last week that the ad that riled his rivals was not his favorite and that he would offer an apology to brokerage executives if they expressed their feelings to him. But Mr. Schwab, never one to mix socially with his peers on Wall Street, did not seem chastened.
And why should he? In mid-August, at a conference on the economy in Waco, Tex., President Bush sat next to Mr. Schwab, who ticked off ideas about how the government could help to restore investor confidence. Mr. Schwab proposed increasing the amount of investment losses that people can deduct from their taxable annual income, to $20,000 from $3,000, and ending the "double taxation" of dividends that companies pay to shareholders. He also took a swipe at his competitors on Wall Street, calling for "a crackdown on the conflicts that have left investors so distrustful of Wall Street brokers and banks."
None of Mr. Schwab's ideas are altogether original or revolutionary. Economists and financial executives have proposed similar changes for years. But Mr. Schwab's timing and sense of opportunity were excellent.
THE White House had invited him to speak not only because he was a generous contributor to Mr. Bush's campaign and a frequent contributor to the Republican Party, but also because he was an investor spokesman who was not seen as a Wall Street insider, Republican aides and campaign advisers said. In the midst of all the investigations into the behavior of investment bankers and analysts, one adviser said, "Wall Street is considered toxic."
Mr. Schwab, who has given more than $750,000 to Republican campaign committees and candidates since 1998, said that when he spoke in Waco, he did not know if there was political support for changing taxation of dividends. He said he simply thought companies should be encouraged to pay out more of their profits to shareholders and to spend less time and money trying to prop up or inflate their share prices.
"I just thought it was a fundamental idea that would really enhance investor confidence and reward long-term investing by getting some return on your investment," he recounted, sitting at the end of a conference table here, on the 30th floor of the company's modest headquarters in the financial district. Serious to a fault, he looked grayer and sounded less optimistic than he does in commercials.
THE Bush administration did not rush to embrace all of what Democrats on Capitol Hill call "the Charles Schwab proposals," but some of his suggestions have caught on. In October, the House Ways and Means Committee drafted a bill that would raise the capital-loss limit, but to $8,250, not the $20,000 that Mr. Schwab had proposed. That bill did not move through the House this year, but it could be revived when Congress convenes again in January.
Last week, Senator Jon Kyl, an Arizona Republican who is a member of the Senate Finance Committee, proposed a list of tax cuts that included increasing the capital-loss provision to $10,000 and eliminating what he called the double taxation on dividends. Some Republican strategists said they thought that there was momentum behind those ideas, though Democratic staff members in Washington dismissed them as beneficial only to wealthy people and unlikely to stimulate economic activity or even stock purchases.
Any initiatives that would spur investors to buy or sell more stock should be a boon to Mr. Schwab's business and to his own portfolio. He still owns 18 percent of his company, though the value of his stake has dropped as the share price has fallen 75 percent from its high of $50 in 1999. He ranked 59th on Forbes magazine's latest list of the wealthiest Americans, with an estimated net worth of $2.7 billion.
Since his appearance in Waco, Mr. Schwab has been mentioned as a possible future Treasury secretary. But he denies having any interest in going to Washington. Extricating himself from a company named after him and so closely identified with him would be tricky, and any nomination of him would probably be opposed by some Wall Street firms.
But leaving now would spare him the difficult task of reinventing his company again. Schwab is trying to shift from catering only to investors who feel capable of making their own decisions to also providing advice to those who need it. That switch puts Schwab in more direct competition with Wall Street giants like Merrill Lynch, Morgan Stanley, Citigroup and UBS that employ armies of financial advisers. Those competitors contend that Mr. Schwab's recent attacks on them are motivated by self-interest.
"They're good competitors, but to try to pull down the advisory model at the time when you're trying to get into it is seen as self-serving," said Mr. Gorman of Merrill Lynch, the only Wall Street executive interviewed who would speak about Mr. Schwab for attribution. "It's the pattern and the presumption that the financial adviser is not acting in the client's best interest, which is what is insulting."
Other Wall Street executives, irritated by Mr. Schwab's stinging barbs, point fingers at what they consider the Schwab company's own conflicts of interest. Most often, they criticize the way Schwab directs more than one-third of its customers' trades to an in-house unit that makes markets in stocks, a practice known as internalizing orders. By doing that, Schwab keeps more of the trading profit for itself instead of seeking the best price for its customers, the critics contend.
Mr. Schwab rebutted the charge, saying he did not think his company was shortchanging its customers. But he said that if Schwab had to divest itself of its market-making business to make the rest of the industry swear off conflicts of interest, it would be willing to do so.
Henry McVey, an analyst at Morgan Stanley, said he thought such practices might become an issue again next year, after Wall Street moves past the furor over how stock analysts behaved and how new stocks were sold during the boom of the late 1990's.
But Schwab is making so little money from its capital markets unit these days that investors would hardly miss it if the company did exit the business. Schwab took in just $47 million from what it calls principal transactions last quarter, down 80 percent from $245 million in the first quarter of 2000. All told, Schwab's revenue last year was $4.35 billion, and its profits were $267 million.
Schwab "has a good business model but it's not without flaws," said Mr. McVey, who raised his rating on Schwab's stock two weeks ago to "equal weight" from "underweight."
"Fundamentally, I think the Schwab model is about empowerment of the consumer and, in general, lower pricing," he said. On at least one point, he disagrees with Mr. Schwab's detractors on Wall Street. "The man's integrity runs deep," he said.

HEADLINE: The World; 
Of the People, By the Warlords

BYLINE:  By TOM ZELLER 

 BODY:
IN his 2001 book "Taliban," Ahmed Rashid writes of "bloodstains and pieces of flesh" in the muddy courtyard of Gen. Abdul Rashid Dostum, a Soviet-trained commander with a tight grip on several northern provinces in Afghanistan. 
 "I innocently asked the guard if a goat had been slaughtered," Mr. Rashid writes. "They told me that an hour earlier Dostum had punished a soldier for stealing." 
 Mr. Dostum is now Afghanistan's deputy defense minister. He is also considered by many to be the country's warlord par excellence, with thousands of troops and a reputation for frontier justice -- not unlike dozens of other such strongmen, from Kunduz to Kandahar.
Indeed, in the vacuum following the Taliban's defeat, many regional leaders who had, to varying degrees, cooperated with American forces (and with one another), became de facto kings of their respective slices of Afghanistan. Last June, several were tactfully folded into the fledgling government of President Hamid Karzai, turning warlords into provincial governors and strongmen into cabinet ministers.
It was a necessary move, and it followed the same logic that led American forces, in the early days of the Afghan war, to cooperate with -- and according to recent revelations, pay large sums of money to -- some decidedly unsavory characters: better they be allies than enemies.
Now, to extend his control from a few hundred square miles around Kabul to the 250,000 square miles and 25 million fractious inhabitants of Afghanistan, Mr. Karzai is trying to take the war out of the warlords.
"They're going to need incentives," said Barnett R. Rubin, senior fellow at New York University's Center on International Cooperation. "That means decommissioned soldiers will need jobs, a livelihood. And the warlords will need some form of legitimate power."
Building an economy from scratch is one thing. It's quite another to undo the loose system of regional strongmen -- one that has existed in varying degrees through much of Afghanistan's recent history, often with the nurturing of various foreign patrons.
Although many of the most powerful militia leaders have been placated with official government posts, the country is peppered with petty warlords who refuse to fall into line. 
Where they control roads, they finance themselves and their small armies with customs duties and tolls. Where they control villages, they charge taxes. 
In some cases, they have breathed new life into the opium trade, which the Taliban had cracked down on.
Even the newly knighted regional leaders come with baggage that may prove too heavy for the Karzai government to bear. One of them, Ismail Khan, the principal warlord in the west and governor of Herat Province, has been accused of ordering the torture of political enemies. Upside-down hanging, whipping and shocking with electrical wires attached to the toes and thumbs are reported to be among the favored techniques. But Mr. Dostum has the fiercest reputation. The United Nations is currently investigating charges that his troops killed up to 1,000 captured Taliban prisoners last winter by piling them into airless shipping containers.
STILL, the way of the warlord need not be the future of Afghan politics.
"I would not say that warlordism is a permanent attribute of Afghan society," said Dr. Antonio Giustozzi, author of "War, Politics and Society in Afghanistan, 1978-1992," "but rather it has been a recurrent feature, due to some geographical and social conditions that make it difficult to build a strong state there."
It is also true that the emerging Afghan government is not wholly made up of muscle. There are academics and former politicians with experience predating the Taliban and the Soviet occupation in the 1980's. 
Some warlords, too, have shown a proclivity toward broad-minded cooperation. Wide swaths of northeastern Afghanistan, for example, have been relatively calm. And Mr. Karzai's firing of more than 15 top officials earlier this month appeared to send a message that warlords need to get with the program. 
It's possible that the message will be lost on some. 
"I will never feel hurt if I am called a fighter," Mr. Dostum is quoted as saying in The Christian Science Monitor last June. "But if I am called a warlord, it hurts me."

GRAPHIC: Chart/Photos: "Afghanistan's Power Brokers"When the Taliban was overthrown a year ago, local Afghani warlords stepped into the vacuum. Some have since won positions in Hamid Karzai's government. Many continue to clash -- sometimes violently -- with one another, with dozens of lesser warlords and power-hungry thugs, and with the forces in Kabul seeking to establish centralized control. Here is a look at some influential regional players and their current status. Abdul Rashid DostumAtta MuhammadNORTH CENTRAL -- An ethnic Uzbek, Soviet-trained general and now deputy defense minister, Mr. Dostum has a reputation for ruthlessness. His forces are thought to have killed hundreds of Taliban prisoners last winter, and it was reported last weekend that Mr. Dostum may have jailed and tortured witnesses to the crime. He is also struggling for control of the north with a powerful rival (and former ally) Atta Muhammad, whose troops now control Mazar-i-Sharif. Ismail KhanWEST -- During the war with the Soviets, Mr. Khan was a storied resistance leader. He spent much of the Taliban years in jail, but quickly became the Northern Alliance's man in the west last November. Today he is the governor of Herat Province and the subject of a scathing report this month by the group Human Rights Watch, which suggests that Mr. Khan and his troops include torture, beatings and harassment in their politicking. Gul Agha ShirzaiSOUTHWEST -- Mr. Shirzai was governor of Kandahar from 1992 to 1994 before going into exile in Pakistan. He returned last December and has resumed his governorship. An attempt was made to assassinate him, along with Mr. Karzai, in September. Mr. Shirzai has a reputation for avoiding abuses as governor and working closely with rival warlords -- or, some reports suggest, buying their allegiance with foreign aid money. Karim KhaliliCENTRAL -- The head of one of Afghanistan's largest political parties, Mr. Khalili is less a warlord than a politician with several minor warlords among his followers -- most of them in the central provinces where the Taliban destroyed two giant Buddhas last year. Mr. Khalili became one of several vice presidents in June and has been, on at least one occasion, designated acting head of state when Mr. Karzai was out of the country. Daoud KhanNORTHEAST -- A Tajik and former Northern Alliance commander, Mr. Khan and his largely Tajik troops were quick to disarm Taliban sympathizers and establish firm control of the region. Mr. Khan and company are followers of former president Burhannuddin Rabbani, who is now often at odds with the new defense minister, Muhammad Fahim. International Security Assistance Force (ISAF), Hamid Karzai and Gen. Muhammad Fahim KABUL AND ENVIRONS -- President Karzai (right top) enjoys a security zone around Kabul established by ISAF, a multinational security force created after the Taliban were driven out. Requests to expand the force outside Kabul have thus far been unfulfilled. Defense Minister Fahim's followers have helped to establish control further out of Kabul and in the strategic city of Jalalabad, but the border regions east and south of the capital city remain fragmented by several petty warlords vying for power. HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: THE ALLIES; 
Bush Appeals To New Allies On Iraq Plans

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

DATELINE: BUCHAREST, Romania, Nov. 23 

 BODY:
President Bush extended a welcome to two future NATO partners today, saying that their experience of Communist tyranny equipped them to understand the dangers posed by Saddam Hussein of Iraq.
 Speaking before a crowd of tens of thousands here in Romania's capital, Mr. Bush said that because they had seen "the face of evil" in their former ruler, Nicolae Ceausescu, "the people of Romania know that dictators must never be appeased or ignored. They must be opposed." 
 Earlier in the day, Mr. Bush delivered a similar message in Vilnius, Lithuania, as the first American president to visit the Baltic country. This week, at a summit meeting in Prague, NATO invited Lithuania, Romania and five other former Communist states to join the military alliance originally established as a shield against the Soviet Union.
As a steady rain fell over Bucharest, Mr. Bush spoke in the city's Revolution Square directly across from the old Communist Party headquarters where, in 1989, a helicopter lifted Mr. Ceausescu off the roof as a mob surged through its doors trying to kill him. Three days later, Mr. Ceausescu and his wife, Elena, were executed by a firing squad.
"You value freedom, because you have lived without it," said Mr. Bush, his face drenched with rain. "You know the difference between good and evil, because you have seen the face of evil."
An "aggressive dictator," Mr. Bush said, "now rules in Iraq. By his search for terrible weapons, by his ties to terrorist groups, the dictator of Iraq threatens the security of every free nation, including the free nations of Europe."
The speech was one of the few that Mr. Bush has made to such a large crowd outdoors since the Sept. 11 attacks, and he addressed the gathering behind a screen of bulletproof glass. Sharpshooters were stationed atop buildings throughout the square.
The speech echoed one Mr. Bush made earlier today in Lithuania.
Before a much smaller crowd in City Hall Square in Vilnius, Mr. Bush compared the threat from today's terrorists to the Nazis and Communists who controlled much of Europe for parts of the 20th century. Like the Nazis and the Communists, Mr. Bush said, "the terrorists seek to end lives and control all life." 
Mr. Bush told the Lithuanians that "we must be willing to stand in the face of evil, to have the courage to always face danger."
"The people of the Baltic states have shown these qualities to the world," Mr. Bush said. "You have known cruel oppression and withstood it. You were held captive by an empire and you outlived it."
The president's two stops today, the last leg of a five-day trip to the NATO meeting in Prague and a meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in St. Petersburg, were another extension of his campaign to seek support for military action against Iraq.
Romania in particular is of strategic importance to that campaign because its ports on the Black Sea are a link to the Middle East, and could supply bases from Turkey to the Persian Gulf that are used by American and British forces. Although the country appeared an unlikely candidate a little more than a year ago -- it is still struggling with corruption and the transition to a market economy -- that changed after the Sept. 11 attacks.
"NATO membership will make Romania more secure," Mr. Bush said. "And Romania will add to the strength of the NATO alliance as we face unprecedented new dangers. Already, our troops are serving side by side in Afghanistan. Already, Romania has joined the global coalition against terror."
Mr. Bush's words also offered Mr. Putin reassurance that Russia had nothing to fear from NATO's expansion. "In the peaceful future we're building, Romania will strengthen our lives in another way -- as a bridge to a new Russia," Mr. Bush said. "For centuries, Romania's geography was a source of danger. Now, you can help our alliance to extend a hand of cooperation across the Black Sea."
Russia, Mr. Bush said, has nothing to fear from the growth of NATO because Russia needs peaceful, stable neighbors like Romania. "As I told President Putin yesterday, a Russia that is fully part of Europe needs no buffer zone separating it from Europe," he said. "America and Romania are friends to the Russian people, and so is the NATO alliance."
Although Mr. Bush praised Romania for choosing free markets over state control and democracy over dictatorship, he said the nation had to work harder toward change.
"NATO's invitation to join was also a vote of confidence that you will continue the hard work of political, economic and military reform," Mr. Bush said. "Your hardship did not end with your oppression."
The president also paid a tribute to those Romanians who had lost their lives in one of the bloodiest rebellions that swept Communism from Eastern Europe more than a decade ago.
"On this historic square, among the monuments to Romania's greatness, there's also a building left in ruins -- the former offices of the secret police," Mr. Bush said.
"It is a fitting reminder of all the cruelties done there, and the justice that rose up against oppression," he said. "That grim monument also recalls the many brave Romanians who did not live to see this day."
In both Bucharest and Vilnius, Mr. Bush promised the new allies that by joining NATO, an attack on one member of the alliance would be considered an attack on all.
"Our alliance has made a solemn pledge of protection, and anyone who would choose Lithuania as an enemy has also made an enemy of the United States of America," Mr. Bush said to applause in Vilnius. "In the face of aggression, the brave people of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia will never stand alone again."
Mr. Bush's appearance outside the Vilnius City Hall was a powerful and poignant sight for Lithuanians, and would have been an unthinkable moment for most of the past 60 years. From its annexation by the Soviet Union in 1940 into the early 1990's the nation was occupied by either the Nazis or the Communists. The United States refused to recognize its annexation and maintained that position up until the country achieved independence in 1991. 
He appeared on stage in Vilnius with Lithuania's president, Valdas Adamkus, as well as the leaders of the two other Baltic states, President Vaira Vike-Freiberga of Latvia and President Arnold Ruutel of Estonia.
In Bucharest, he appeared with President Ion Iliescu, who told Mr. Bush in a ceremony at the Cotroceni Palace here that "we have understood the concern of the American partners regarding phenomena such as corruption and bureaucracy."

HEADLINE: Suburbs to City: Drop the Attitude; 
Reminding Bloomberg That He Needs Commuters Just as They Need New York

BYLINE:  By DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
To: Michael R. Bloomberg and his eight million constituents 
From: James E. McGreevey, John G. Rowland, George E. Pataki, Thomas R. Suozzi, Andrew J. Spano and the rest of the metropolitan region's, oh, 11 million or 12 million people

Dear Mike:
 We need to talk about our relationship. Let's face it, we're all a bit stressed these days. Our budgets are under pressure, your budget is under pressure. In some places we know we've got to take another hit, i.e., some sort of an M.T.A. fare increase. In others, we're not so sure, i.e. your over-the-top commuter-tax proposal. But sometimes stress leads to reflection. This is one of those times. 
 You're saying that you want more of our money because we need you, you made us who we are. We're not unappreciative of the importance of New York City to all of us little people elsewhere. But we'd like to argue that we're more independent than you give us credit for, and that the relationship is far more nuanced and less one-sided than you may think. And this is a good time to try to figure out in what ways we need one another and in what ways you need us more than we need you.
So let's look at reality, and not just reputation, shall we?
Back when the commuter tax was first introduced in 1966, we were quite dependent on you because you offered the best, highest-paying jobs, and all the transportation networks flowed into the city. Whenever New York City sneezed, the rest of us caught a bad cold, and we recuperated far more slowly. But when you took a hit of unparalleled proportions last year, we helped you, a lot. 
Look at how we worked so well after Sept. 11 with your recovery, cleanup and security. We suburbanites rallied behind your musicals and your museums, taking up the slack left by many of the too-timid tourists. Through good times and bad, in fact, we have provided a steady 25 to 30 percent of the total Broadway audience over the last 20 years, according to the president of Audience Research and Analysis, George Wachtel.
Indeed, the dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University, James W. Hughes, said that we even "restrained" ourselves and were not "overly aggressive in taking advantage of New York City's misfortune" after Sept. 11. In plain talk, we didn't court your companies and your residents. (If they came to us, well, hey, that was a different story.)
Still, you've got to acknowledge that our suburban appeal is potent: in recent years, we've been quite successful in nurturing small businesses in cutting-edge fields like information technology and biotechnology. We have become more "recession-resistant" and have built a kind of "fire wall" between the suburbs and the city, according to Marc Goloven, senior regional economist at J. P. Morgan Chase.
That maturation helped cushion the suburbs from the double whammy that you suffered at the hands of the recent economic downturn, as well as the terror attacks, says Thomas J. Spitznas, a regional economist in Mount Vernon, N.Y. We have become less vulnerable, more diversified.
Many counties have kept their unemployment rates low, with little change, Mr. Goloven notes. Long Island's 3.7 percent, for instance, is the same as it was in October 2001. New York City, by contrast, has 7.8 percent unemployment, compared with 6.8 percent a year ago.
Over in New Jersey, Mr. Hughes points out that 80 percent of all the office space in the Garden State was built during the 1980's or later. And while New Jersey had only 1.7 million jobs in 1950, compared with 3.4 million for New York City, the comparable figures for 2000, he says, are 4 million jobs for New Jersey, versus 3.7 million for New York City.
Now, we're not disputing the notion that, as Mr. Goloven puts it, "the rising income tide of New York City tends to lift all the boats in the surrounding counties." Hence the impressive statistic, from New York City's Independent Budget Office, that the average commuter working in the city earned $99,400 in 1998. The average city resident's take? $33,700.
We're also not suggesting, necessarily, that we can prosper in the long run if you continue to stumble. Much as we tout our smashing successes in tourism, self-sufficiency, culture and whatnot, stereotypes die hard.
New York City "is still the engine of the regional economy, if nothing else but attitudinally," Mr. Goloven says. "You're not going to look at Westchester County and say, because they're doing O.K., everybody is doing O.K. You have to have New York City help to pull the rest of the train."
Still, Mark Zandi, the chief economist of the Economy.com Web site, says that more New York City residents are moving to the suburbs than suburbanites are moving in. Mr. Zandi also says that the amount of income earned by suburban commuters, which peaked at $22.1 billion in 2000, is expected to drop to $17.1 billion this year.
"New York is different from nearly every American city in that the core is central to its economic success, but I think it's fair to say that this is changing," he says. "It is becoming more like the rest of the country."
Forget about it, you might say. But some researchers go so far as to wonder why, aside from entertainment and cultural events, people really need to be in Manhattan, with its clogged traffic and exorbitant prices. Maybe only those who share the elitist, Manhattan-centric vision of the artist Saul Steinberg need face-to-face contact, says Joel Garreau, who wrote "Edge City: Life on the New Frontier" in 1991.
"Lunch is it," he says. "Otherwise, why bother?"
Now, many respected scholars, like Mitchell Moss, director of the Taub Urban Research Center at New York University (and an adviser of yours), and Fred Treyz, chief executive officer of Regional Economic Models Inc. of Amherst, Mass., take issue with some of our cheerleading.
Professor Moss, who has written about the rivalry between New York and New Jersey, notes that New York's vibrant economy has fueled booming housing markets in Larchmont, N.Y., Montclair, N.J., and other affluent addresses. And Dr. Treyz, like Professor Moss, says he adamantly believes that labor -- the diversity of the work force, and the access to that work force -- gives New York City (and the region) a huge competitive edge over the rest of the country.
We also cannot overlook the reality that your city has successfully marketed itself as the Center of the Universe. Prof. Saskia Sassen, a sociologist who is the author of "The Global City" says that the "glamour of Manhattan" creates a "sticky web" that is crucial to attracting foreign firms and international clients.
And it is a unique glamour, Dr. Moss contends.
"The suburban communities are basically interchangeable with any suburban communities in America, like Winnetka or Shaker Heights; the only thing that varies is the foliage," he says. "But there's only one New York City."
If there is one thing you take from this letter, though, Mike, it is that we should really be fighting these economic doldrums together. Talk to us before you unveil something like the commuter tax. You need us: remember, only 33 percent of Yankee fans and 39 percent of Met fans who go to the games live in New York City, according to a 1998 study by the city's Independent Budget Office.
We should be teammates, and equal (or near-equal) partners thinking of creative solutions. Myron Orfield, president of Ameregis, a research and geographic information systems firm in Minneapolis that has analyzed tax data for numerous metropolitan areas, says that revenue sharing is a far superior alternative to a commuter tax. It has worked in Boston and Minneapolis, for instance, to the betterment of both cities and their suburbs.
Of course, since we are professional politicians, and you are not, we understand how tough things must be for you right now. After all, New Jersey wanted to impose a commuter tax on Pennsylvania earlier this year. But no one liked that idea, either.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Commuters leaving ferries from Manhattan last week in Weehawken, N.J. They may face a new income tax. (Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: ALLIANCES; 
In North Korea and Pakistan, Deep Roots of Nuclear Barter

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 21 

 BODY:
Last July, American intelligence agencies tracked a Pakistani cargo aircraft as it landed at a North Korean airfield and took on a secret payload: ballistic missile parts, the chief export of North Korea's military.
 The shipment was brazen enough, in full view of American spy satellites. But intelligence officials who described the incident say even the mode of transport seemed a subtle slap at Washington: the Pakistani plane was an American-built C-130. 
 It was part of the military force that President Pervez Musharraf had told President Bush last year would be devoted to hunting down the terrorists of Al Qaeda, one reason the administration was hailing its new cooperation with a country that only a year before it had labeled a rogue state.
But several times since that new alliance was cemented, American intelligence agencies watched silently as Pakistan's air fleet conducted a deadly barter with North Korea. In transactions intelligence agencies are still unraveling, the North provided General Musharraf with missile parts he needs to build a nuclear arsenal capable of reaching every strategic site in India. 
In a perfect marriage of interests, Pakistan provided the North with many of the designs for gas centrifuges and much of the machinery it needs to make highly enriched uranium for the country's latest nuclear weapons project, one intended to put at risk South Korea, Japan and 100,000 American troops in Northeast Asia.
The Central Intelligence Agency told members of Congress this week that North Korea's uranium enrichment program, which it discovered only this summer, will produce enough material to produce weapons in two to three years. Previously it has estimated that North Korea probably extracted enough plutonium from a nuclear reactor to build one or two weapons, until that program was halted in 1994 in a confrontation with the United States.
Yet the C.I.A. report -- at least the unclassified version -- made no mention of how one of the world's poorest and most isolated nations put together its new, complex uranium project.
In interviews over the past three weeks, officials and experts in Washington, Pakistan and here in the capital of South Korea described a relationship between North Korea and Pakistan that now appears much deeper and more dangerous than the United States and its Asian allies first suspected.
The accounts raise disturbing questions about the nature of the uneasy American alliance with General Musharraf's government. The officials and experts described how, even after Mr. Musharraf sided with the United States in ousting the Taliban and hunting down Qaeda leaders, Pakistan's secretive A. Q. Khan Nuclear Research Laboratories continued its murky relationship with the North Korean military. It was a partnership linking an insecure Islamic nation and a failing Communist one, each in need of the other's expertise.
Pakistan was desperate to counter India's superior military force, but encountered years of American-imposed sanctions, so it turned to North Korea. For its part, North Korea, increasingly cut off from Russia and China, tried to replicate Pakistan's success in developing nuclear weapons based on uranium, one of the few commodities that North Korea has in plentiful supply.
Yet while the United States has put tremendous diplomatic pressure on North Korea in the past two months to abandon the project, and has cut off oil supplies to the country, it has never publicly discussed the role of Pakistan or other nations in supplying that effort.
American and South Korean officials, when speaking anonymously, say the reason is obvious: the Bush administration has determined that Pakistan's cooperation in the search for Al Qaeda is so critical -- especially with new evidence suggesting that Osama bin Laden is still alive, perhaps on Pakistani soil.
So far, the White House has ignored federal statutes that require President Bush to impose stiff economic penalties on any country involved in nuclear proliferation or, alternatively, to issue a public waiver of those penalties in the interest of national security. Mr. Bush last year removed penalties that were imposed on Pakistan after it set off a series of nuclear tests in 1998.
White House officials would not comment on the record for this article, saying that discussing Pakistan's role could compromise classified intelligence. Instead, they noted that General Musharraf, after first denying Pakistani involvement in North Korea's nuclear effort, has assured Secretary of State Colin L. Powell that no such trade will occur in the future. 
"He said, 'Four hundred percent assurance that there is no such interchange taking place now,' " Secretary Powell said in a briefing late last month. Pressed about Pakistan's contributions to the nuclear program that North Korea admitted to last month, Secretary Powell smiled tightly and said, "We didn't talk about the past."
A State Department spokesman, Philip Reeker, said, "We are aware of the allegations" about Pakistan, though he would not comment on the substance. "This adminsitration will abide by the law," he said.
Intelligence officials say they have seen no evidence of exchanges since Washington protested the July missile shipment. Even in that incident, they cannot determine if the C-130 that picked up missile parts in North Korea brought nuclear-related goods to North Korea.
But American and Asian officials are far from certain that Pakistan has cut off the relationship, or even whether General Musharraf is in control of the transactions.
Yet in the words of one American official who has reviewed the intelligence, North Korea's drive in the past year to begin full-scale enrichment of uranium uses technology that "has 'Made in Pakistan' stamped all over it." They doubt that North Korea will end its effort even if Pakistan cuts off its supplies. 
"In Kim Jong Il's view, what's the difference between North Korea and Iraq?" asked one senior American official with long experience dealing with North Korea. "Saddam doesn't have one, and look what's happening to him."

A Meeting of Minds in 1993
Pakistan's military ties to North Korea go back to the 1970's. But they took a decisive turn in 1993, just as the United States was forcing the North to open up its huge nuclear reactor facilities at Yongbyon. Yongbyon was clearly a factory for producing bomb-grade plutonium from spent nuclear fuel. 
When North Korea refused to allow in inspectors headed by Hans Blix, the man now leading the inspections in Iraq, President Bill Clinton went to the United Nations to press penalties and the Pentagon drew up contingency plans for a strike against the plant in case North Korea removed the fuel rods to begin making bomb-grade plutonium.
In the midst of that face-off, Benazir Bhutto, then the prime minister of Pakistan, arrived in Pyongyang, the North Korean capital. It was the end of December, freezing cold, and yet the North Korean government arranged for tens of thousands of the city's well-trained citizens to greet her on the streets. At a state dinner, Ms. Bhutto complained about the American penalties imposed on her country and North Korea.
"Pakistan is committed to nuclear nonproliferation," she said, according to a transcript issued at the time. However, she added, states still have "their right to acquire and develop nuclear technology for peaceful purposes, geared to their economic and social developments."
Ms. Bhutto's delegation left with plans for North Korea's Nodong missile, according to former and current Pakistani officials. 
The Pakistani military had long coveted the plans, and by April 1998, it successfully tested a version of the Nodong, renamed the Ghauri. Its flight range of about 1,000 miles put much of India within reach of Pakistan's nuclear warheads.
A former senior Pakistani official recalled in an interview that the Bhutto government planned to pay North Korea "from the invisible account" for covert programs. But events intervened.
Months after Ms. Bhutto's visit, the Clinton administration and North Korea reached a deal that froze all nuclear activity at Yongbyon, where international inspectors still live year-round.
In return, the United States and its allies promised North Korea a steady flow of fuel oil and the eventual delivery of two proliferation-resistant nuclear reactors to produce electric power. That was important in a country so lacking in power that, from satellite images taken at night, it appears like a black hole compared to the blazing lights of South Korea. 
But within three years, Kim Jong Il grew disenchanted with the accord and feared that the nuclear power plants would never be delivered. He never allowed the International Atomic Energy Agency to begin the wide-ranging inspections required before the critical parts of the plants could be delivered. 
By 1997 or 1998, American intelligence has now concluded, he was searching for an alternative way to build a bomb, without detection. He found part of the answer in Pakistan, which along with Iran, Libya, Yemen, Syria and Egypt was now a regular customer for North Korean missile parts, American military officials said. 
A. Q. Khan, the father of Pakistan's nuclear bomb, who had years ago stolen the engineering plans for gas centrifuges from the Netherlands, visited North Korea several times. The visits were always cloaked in secrecy.
But several things are now clear. Pakistan was running out of hard currency to pay the North Koreans, who were in worse shape. North Korea feared that without a nuclear weapon it would eventually be absorbed by the economic might of the South, or squeezed by the military might of the United States.
In 1997 or 1998, Kim Jong Il and his generals decided to begin a development project for a bomb based on highly enriched uranium, a slow and difficult process, but relatively easy to hide.

Talking, but Not Changing
They did so even while sporadically pursuing a better relationship with Washington. In the last days of the Clinton administration, the North negotiated with Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright for a deal to restrict North Korean missile exports in return for a removal of economic penalties, a de-listing from the State Department's account of countries that sponsor terrorism and talks about diplomatic recognition. The deal was never reached.
President Clinton even considered an end-of-term trip to North Korea, but was talked out of it by aides who feared that the North was not ready to make real concessions. The nuclear revelations of the past few weeks suggest those aides saved Mr. Clinton from embarrassment.
"Lamentably, North Korea never really changed," said one senior Western official here with long experience in the topic. "They came to the conclusion that the nuclear card was their one ace in the hole, and they couldn't give it up."
American intelligence agencies, meanwhile, suspected that North Korea was restarting a secret program. In 1998, satellites were focused on a huge underground site where the C.I.A. believed Kim Jong Il was trying to build a second plutonium-reprocessing center. But they were looking in the wrong place: after American officials negotiated access to the suspect site, they found only a series of man-made caves with no nuclear-related equipment, and no apparent purpose. "World's largest underground parking lot," one American intelligence official joked at the time.
Rumors of a secret enriched-uranium project persisted, however. The C.I.A. and the Oak Ridge National Laboratory in Tennessee evaluated the evidence but reached no firm conclusion.
But there were hints. One Western diplomat who visited North Korea in May 1998, just as world attention focused on Pakistan, which had responded to India's underground nuclear tests by setting off six of its own, recalled witnessing an odd celebration. "I was in the Foreign Ministry," the official recalled last week. "About 10 minutes into our meeting, the North Korean diplomat we were seeing broke into a big smile and pointed with pride to these tests. They were all elated.
"Here was a model of a poor state getting away with developing a nuclear weapon." 
When the Clinton administration raised the rumors of a Pakistan-North Korea link with Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, who succeeded Ms. Bhutto, he denied them. It was only after General Musharraf overthrew Mr. Sharif's government, and after Mr. Bush took office, that South Korean intelligence agencies picked up strong evidence that North Korea was buying components for an enriched-uranium program.
The agencies passed the evidence along to Washington, according to South Korean and American officials. It looked suspiciously similar to the gas centrifuge technology used in Pakistan. "My guess is that Pakistan was the only available partner," said Lee Hong Koo, a former South Korean prime minister and unification minister. 
A. H. Nayya, a physics professor at Quaid-e-Azam University in Islamabad, who has no role in the country's nuclear program, agreed: "The clearest possibility is that the Pakistanis gave them the blueprint. 'Here it is. You make it on your own.' " 
Under American pressure, Dr. Khan was removed from the operational side of the Pakistani nuclear program. He was made an "adviser to the president" on nuclear technology.
Here in Seoul, nuclear experts working for the government of President Kim Dae Jung say they were subtly discouraged from publicly writing or speculating about the North's secret programs because the Korean government feared that it would derail President Kim's legacy: the "sunshine policy" of engagement with North Korea and encouraging investment there.
By this summer, however, the C.I.A. concluded that the North had moved from research to production. The intelligence agency took the evidence to Condoleezza Rice, the president's national security adviser, who asked for a review by all American intelligence agencies.
Such a request is usually a prescription for conflicting interpretations. Instead, the agencies came back with a unanimous opinion: the North Korean program was well under way, and had to be stopped.

Telling the North, 'You're Busted'
After sending senior officials to Japan and South Korea in August to present the new evidence, Mr. Bush decided to confront the North Koreans. On Oct. 4, James A. Kelly, the assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs, was in North Korea and told his counterparts that the United States had detailed information about the enriched-uranium program. 
"We wanted to make it clear to them that they were busted," a senior administration official said. 
The North Koreans initially denied the accusation, but the next day, after what they told the American visitors was an all-night discussion, they admitted that they were pursuing the secret weapons program, several officials said. "We need nuclear weapons," Kang Sok Joo, the North Korean senior foreign policy official, said, arguing that the program was a result of the Bush administration's hostility.
Mr. Kelly responded that the program began at least four years ago, when Mr. Bush was governor of Texas. The Americans left after one North Korean official declared that dialogue on the subject was worthless and said, "We will meet sword with sword." 
Since then, the North Koreans have been more circumspect. They have talked publicly about having the right to a nuclear weapon, even though they have signed the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty and an agreement with South Korea to keep the Korean Peninsula free of nuclear weapons. 
The Bush administration has been uncharacteristically restrained. President Bush led the push for an oil cutoff, but also issued a statement on Nov. 15 saying that the United States had no intention of invading North Korea. His aides hoped that the statement would give Kim Jong Il the kind of security guarantee he had long demanded -- and a face-saving way to end the nuclear program. 
Mr. Bush's aides say the way to deal with North Korea, in contrast to their approach to Iraq, is to exploit its economic vulnerabilities and offer carrots, essentially the strategy the Clinton administration used. Many here in Seoul believe it may work this time.
"The North Koreans are a lot more dependent on us, and on the West, than they were in the 1994 nuclear crisis," said Han Sung Joo, who served as South Korea's foreign minister then. 
But the reality, officials acknowledged, is that Mr. Bush has little choice but to pursue a diplomatic solution with North Korea. 
Kim Jong Il has 11,000 artillery tubes dug in around the demilitarized zone, all aimed at Seoul. In the opening hours of a war, tens of thousands of people could die, military officials here say. 
"Here's the strategy," one American official said. "Tell the North Koreans, quite publicly, that they can't get away with it. And say the same thing to Pakistan, but privately, quietly."

Pakistan and North Korea Involved in Nuclear Barter
Pakistan has used an American-built transport plane to carry ballistic missile parts as part of a bartering operation with North Korea, intelligence officials have learned. The transactions now appear much deeper and more dangerous than the United States and its Asian allies first suspected. 1

North Korea asked South Korea to join in pressing America to sign a nonaggression treaty. The request comes as the United States, Japan and South Korea have initiated sanctions for North Korea's violation of nuclear arms control agreements. 20

President Bush, speaking in Bucharest, welcomed Romanians into the NATO alliance and the campaign against terrorism. He said their experience under Communism equipped them to understand the dangers posed by Saddam Hussein. 1

AIDS and Africa's Stability
No institution is more central to the stability of many African nations than the military, and few institutions in Africa are more threatened by AIDS. 1

Swiss voters will cast ballots on a measure that would give the country one of the most restrictive immigrant policies in Europe. The referendum, initiated by a right-wing party, has been condemned by all other parties, the government and the United Nations refugee agency. 17

The Justice Department, moving quickly to use its expanded powers for spying on possible terrorists, plans to assign federal lawyers in counterintelligence to terrorism task forces in New York and Washington to help secure secret warrants against suspects, officials say. 1

West Coast port operators and the longshoremen's union announced a tentative agreement, ending a dispute that had closed 29 seaports before President Bush obtained an injunction to reopen them last month. 30

Rash of Foreclosures
Home mortgages nationwide are being foreclosed at the highest rate in 30 years, according to a recent report. Nowhere is the problem more severe than in Indiana, a trend experts attribute to the state's relatively loose lender regulations and its sharply rising unemployment rate. 30

Rebound in Border Crossings

HEADLINE: CITY BUDGET DEAL INCLUDES 18% RISE IN PROPERTY TAXES 

BYLINE:  By DIANE CARDWELL 

 BODY:
The city's property tax rate, frozen for a decade, will rise by 18 percent on Jan. 1 under an agreement announced yesterday between the Bloomberg administration and City Council leaders.
 "It's a painful measure," the Council speaker, Gifford Miller, said in announcing the agreement in the Red Room at City Hall shortly after 4:30 p.m. The deal will also prevent the immediate closing of any firehouses. 
 "But when you are hemorrhaging money, you have to take painful measures," he said. "So we believe that this property tax increase is the lowest that we can go while still protecting the residents of the City of New York, addressing the budget gap and being able to freeze this rate and hold it there."
Faced with a deficit of $1.1 billion this year and $6.4 billion for the fiscal year that begins July 1, 2003, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg had asked the Council for an immediate 25 percent increase in the property tax rate in addition to about $844 million in spending reductions. 
But council members made it clear that they were seeking a tax rate increase of 12 to 18 percent, and to restore a fraction of the mayor's proposed cuts to various city agency budgets, including enough to prevent the immediate closing of eight firehouses that the Bloomberg administration had planned to shutter.
Mr. Miller said he and the mayor agreed to those requests as part of the broad outlines of what the speaker called the "agreement in principle," which restores nearly $50 million in proposed service cuts, on Friday night. The speaker then consulted with other council leaders, before spending about two hours yesterday in a rare Saturday session with most of the Democratic caucus discussing the particulars of the agreement over pizza. According to members who were present, the mood in the council lounge was somber, but resigned.
"We know that we have to step forward and raise revenues," said Bill Perkins, the deputy majority leader, who represents central Harlem. "It's not easy for the members to do what we have to do, but they're going to do it, and we'll be ready for Round 2 after we get past this round."
Councilman David Yassky, who represents Brooklyn Heights and Greenpoint, as well as parts of Park Slope, Williamsburg and Boerum Hill, said, "Nobody wants to go back and tell people to vote for us and say 'We're raising your taxes,' but I honestly think it's the right thing to do. 
"A couple of people wanted to gripe about it," he said, "but most of us recognize that we don't have a choice."
Mayor Bloomberg's chief spokesman, Edward Skyler, said the administration was not disappointed that the Council had not agreed to a higher tax rate.
"We're pleased that the City Council recognizes the severity of the city's fiscal situation and is willing to take the actions necessary to close the budget deficit," Mr. Skyler said. "We will continue to work with the Council to finalize this agreement as soon as possible."
The 18 percent increase, which the Council could vote on as early as tomorrow, would raise the overall tax rate to $12.28 per $100 of assessed value, from about $10.37. Mr. Bloomberg had said he would be happiest with a rate of $12.96. The new rate is expected to add roughly $343 to the annual tax bill of a typical single-family-home owner, and roughly $496 to the annual tax bill for the typical owner of an apartment in a large co-op building.
The increase will bring in about $839 million in the current fiscal year, about $300 million less than the nearly $1.2 billion that a 25 percent raise would have yielded. Next year, the city should receive about $1.7 billion from the higher property tax, council officials said.
The Bloomberg proposal would have yielded approximately $800 million to put toward next year's budget, which has a projected gap of $6.4 billion.
As expected, advocates representing people who would be affected by the budget deal voiced concerns, but their objections were so muted that they did not appear to seriously threaten the agreement.
John Doyle, vice president for government affairs of the Real Estate Board of New York, a trade group that had been lobbying against the increase, said yesterday that he would turn his efforts toward gaining a reduction in the rate for next year.
Saying that a 12 percent increase was more appropriate, he added: "A property tax is not based on one's ability to pay. It's based on the value of the asset. And so if you've been living in your home for a number of years and the value of that home could have increased, it could have doubled or tripled, certainly your income has not doubled or tripled. And so you're being taxed beyond your ability to pay."
Council officials said that for each dollar they restored to this year's budget, they cut a dollar from another area, but they could not say last night how much -- if any -- surplus the new plan would roll over into the next fiscal year.
Council leaders said they were still working out the details of the restored cuts. But under the agreement, the eight firehouses slated to close would remain open while a commission studies how to cut about $2.5 million from the Fire Department's budget. The administration also agreed not to privatize some ambulance service, which will cost the city $2.5 million.
Under the plan, the Police Department would still reduce its July 2003 class of rookies by 1,900 and the Department of Education would still be hit with $200 million in budget cuts. The new schools chancellor, Joel I. Klein, has promised that those cuts will not affect classroom instruction, and the feeling at the Council is that since Mr. Bloomberg won his much-prized direct control of the system, if the schools suffer it will be his political cross to bear.
At the Administration for Children's Services, about $18 million is slated to be restored through re-estimating costs and other administrative steps, according to the Council's finance staff. About $5 million of that will pay for 2,500 day care slots, $5 million for preventative services in special schools and $4.55 million to foster care providers.
About $9.6 million that was to be cut from the budget of the City University of New York will be restored, including a scholarship program, funds for community colleges and money for teachers at the Hunter College Elementary School and Hunter College High School.
The Council also won back about $885,000 in financing for a program that provides weekend meals for the elderly. Extra trash pickups in certain commercial districts would also be saved, at a cost of $700,000.
The plan restores $6.4 million to the Department of Youth and Community Development to cover various services, including sports, arts and after-school programs.
At the Department of Business Services, about $923,000 would be restored to various economic-development programs and to the city's tourism bureau, finance officials said. About $1.5 million would be restored to the city's libraries to buy books, and council leaders pledged to do whatever was necessary to keep the libraries open at least five days a week.
The finance officials said that they were able to pay for the restorations by reducing expenses that had been overestimated, including $15 million in subsidies to private bus companies, about $5 million in utility costs and $10 million in interest savings on the city's debt.
For now, city officials are concentrating on fine-tuning the agreement for the current fiscal year, which ends in June. Because the rate change would go into effect in the middle of that year, the 18 percent increase will add roughly $171 to a typical single-family-home owner's tax bill this year, according to members of the Council's finance staff. The typical owner of an apartment in a large co-op could expect to pay an additional $248 this year, while the owner of a lavish Manhattan office building would pay an extra $374,000 this year and $747,000 next year.
Mr. Miller said yesterday that the administration had agreed to help lobby state lawmakers to approve a new tax on absentee landlords of small residential buildings, defined as one-, two- and three-family homes. Part of the proceeds from the tax, which council officials estimate at more than $100 million a year, would go to offset higher property taxes for elderly people on fixed incomes.
And with next year's looming deficit of more than $6 billion, city officials said they were planning to spend the next several months lobbying Albany and Washington for other taxes and revenue enhancements.
"This doesn't solve our budget gap," Mr. Miller said. "We're going to need, as I said, support from Washington. We're going to need support from Albany. We're going to need to take other measures. We're probably going to have to do some more cuts."

HEADLINE: Tentative Deal Ends Dispute That Closed West Coast Ports 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
President Bush announced this morning that the West Coast port operators and the longshoremen's union had reached a tentative settlement, ending a dispute that had closed 29 seaports before he obtained an injunction to reopen them last month.
 The new six-year agreement, an official close to the negotiations said, includes a raise, a substantial pension increase and far-reaching measures to allow port operators to use new technologies. The two sides declined to disclose details of the agreement, enabling union officials to first explain the deal to their members. 
 "This agreement is good for workers, good for employers, and it's good for America's economy," Mr. Bush said.
Before the announcement, the dispute had threatened to close the West Coast ports on Dec. 27, when the 80-day injunction was to expire. Among shipping companies, stores and factories, there were fears that the International Longshore and Warehouse Union would strike when the cooling-off period ended.
On Sept. 29, the port operators and shipping lines closed ports and locked out 10,500 longshoremen, saying that the union was engaged in a slowdown, something the union denied. On Oct. 8, President Bush got the injunction to reopen the ports.
On Nov. 1, the union and the Pacific Maritime Association, which represents the port operators, reached agreement on the main issue that had long divided them -- new technologies. Throughout the dispute, the union said that it would accept computerized cargo-tracking systems only if management agreed to keep many jobs union as well as transform some nonunion jobs into ones under union jurisdiction. The introduction of more efficient technology would cost the jobs of more than 400 unionized clerks. 
In the agreement, management got the right to introduce the technology in return for a pledge not to lay off workers whose jobs were replaced by automation; the union will maintain jurisdiction over jobs it feared would become nonunion.

HEADLINE: Wait Till Next Year 

BYLINE:  By David Kusnet; David Kusnet, the chief speechwriter for President Bill Clinton from 1992 through 1994, is a visiting fellow at the Economic Policy Institute.

 BODY:
 THE EMERGING DEMOCRATIC MAJORITY
By John B. Judis
and Ruy Teixeira.
213 pp. New York:
A Lisa Drew Book/Scribner. $24.
 Most books of political prognostication enjoy a brief half-life from their publication date to the next election day, but even after the recent Republican gains, "The Emerging Democratic Majority" deserves much better than a trip to the remainder bin. It is an informative and intellectually adventurous study of how economic, demographic and cultural changes are affecting Americans' political behavior. Its provocative conclusion is that those changes are producing a "progressive centrist" majority that will give Democrats an advantage similar to the edge that Republicans enjoyed during the 1970's and 80's. 
Echoing Kevin Phillips's 1969 classic, "The Emerging Republican Majority," which saw the seeds of Republican ascendancy in Richard Nixon's narrow victory the year before, the journalist John B. Judis and the demographer Ruy Teixeira contend that the Democrats can build a base for future victories on what Bill Clinton and Al Gore won in the three presidential elections from 1992 through 2000: 20 states and the District of Columbia, with a total of 267 electoral votes, only three fewer than a majority. They say that three decades of social and economic change have shaped a society favorable to Democrats: "a new postindustrial metropolitan order in which men and women play equal roles and in which white America is supplanted by multiracial, multiethnic America." 
Judis and Teixeira find this future in metropolitan areas like California's Silicon Valley and North Carolina's Research Triangle, with high-tech industries and highly educated workforces -- seamless webs of cities and suburbs that they call "ideopolises." There, they locate three constituencies that are growing larger and more Democratic: racial and ethnic minorities, educated working women and skilled professionals.
With growing numbers of Hispanic and Asian-American voters to go along with African-Americans, the authors argue that it will be more difficult for "Republicans to cede the minority vote and still win elections." Female voters also increasingly support Democrats.
In their most original observation, Judis and Teixeira report that highly educated professionals have shifted from the Republicans to the Democrats. Not only do they tend to be social liberals, but professionals like physicians also find that their efforts to do their best work are thwarted by the market economy that conservatives uncritically endorse. 
Judis and Teixeira raise important issues, but they unduly emphasize the most educated, affluent and avant-garde constituencies. Thus, they lump together professional and technical workers of all kinds, and generalize from human service professionals, who tend to be more liberal than those in private industry. Similarly, their portrayal of ideopolises seems based on suburbs close to cities, like Bethesda or Brookline, not outer suburbs. They ignore the segments of middle America that Democrats neglect at their peril: people who work in midlevel technical, sales and service jobs and live in communities with more churches than Thai restaurants.
This stress on upscale voters is new for both authors, particularly Teixeira, whose previous book, "America's Forgotten Majority"(with Joel Rogers), argued that the decisive voters were moderate-income people without four-year college degrees. "The Emerging Democratic Majority" does discuss these voters, but usually as an afterthought. When they do address working-class concerns, the authors offer genuine insights, especially about persistent economic insecurity.
"The Emerging Democratic Majority" is an indispensable study. But it merits attention less for its prophecies than for its inquiries into the new ways that Americans live, work, think and vote -- changes more complex than any analysts, including these authors, have yet explained.
